In the matter of the Land Titles Act of the Province of Saskatchewan, and in the matter of a transfer of all Legal Subdivision fifteen (15) not covered by the waters of Round Lake, and the west half (W.½) of the west half (W.½) of Legal Subdivision sixteen (16), in Section fourteen (14), in Township eighteen (18), in Range three (3), west of the Second Meridian in the Province of Saskatchewan, containing twenty-two (22) acres more or less except one point fifty (1.50) acres taken for roadway as shown on Plan XL398, from The Board of Trustees of the Presbyterian Church in Canada to His Majesty The King as represented by The Superintendent General of Indian Affairs.

I, Robert Laird, of the City of Toronto, in the Province of Ontario, Doctor of Divinity, do solemnly declare:

1. That The Board of Trustees of the Presbyterian Church in Canada is the registered owner of the above described land.

2. That the Chairman of The Board of Trustees of the Presbyterian Church in Canada, the Treasurer of The Presbyterian Church in Canada, and the President of The Women's Missionary Society of the Presbyterian Church in Canada, are the proper officers to execute the transfer of the said land on behalf of the said The Board of Trustees of the Presbyterian Church in Canada.

3. That I am the Treasurer of the Presbyterian Church in Canada.

4. That John Kay Macdonald is the Chairman of The Board of Trustees of the Presbyterian Church in Canada.

5. That Janet T. MacGillivray is the President of The Women's Missionary Society of the Presbyterian Church in Canada.

6. That The Board of Trustees of the Presbyterian Church in Canada has been in actual continued possession of the said land for the last 17½ years.

7. That the said land is not leased to any person whomsoever.

8. That there are no mortgages or other encumbrances on the title to the said lands, and no persons whomsoever are entitled to any easements, rights of way, or any other right of any sort and nature whatsoever in the said lands.

9. That The Board of Trustees of the Presbyterian Church in Canada has not done anything whereby any person is entitled to a mechanic's lien or wage earnings lien, in respect of the said lands, and no buildings whatsoever have been erected on the said lands since the year 1920.

10. That The Board of Trustees of the Presbyterian Church in Canada has not purchased any lumber or building material in connection with the said lands since the year 1920.

11. That The Board of Trustees of the Presbyterian Church in Canada has not purchased any seed grain from any municipality in the Province of Saskatchewan, nor has The Board of Trustees of the Presbyterian Church in Canada purchased seed grain from the Province of Saskatchewan, or the Dominion of Canada, and has not encumbered the said lands or any part thereof in respect of any seed grain liens.

Ottawa, October 17, 1924.

Dear Mr. Learns:

I have your letter of the 6th instant, with reference to Indian Education cheque No. 6433, being a payment of $6,000 to the Presbyterian Church for the Round Lake Indian Residential School property which was transferred to the Crown.

In reply I have to inform you that the Presbyterian Church, in November, 1922, suggested a nominal price of $10,000 or $12,000 for the church property at the school. As was explained on the voucher, the property consisted of approximately 22 acres on which was situate the residential school, the barns and other outbuildings. The buildings alone represented an investment on the part of the Church of considerably more than either of these figures. The land is entirely in the valley and is quite valuable.

In the winter of 1923-24, a fire destroyed the classroom, which was one of the outbuildings. I learned that insurance, amounting to $2,000.00, was paid to the Church authorities. I immediately suggested that this amount be deducted from their lowest price and that the consideration for the property be $8,000.00. I discussed the question with Mr. Commissioner Graham, who is thoroughly familiar with the situation, and he considered this a fair adjustment and a satisfactory price.

Yours very truly,

Duncan C. Scott

Deputy Superintendent General.

Wm. Learns, Esq.,
Asst. Auditor General,

Regina, Sask., June 29th, 1925.

Dear Mr. Graham:

I have the honor to submit the following report of a visit which I made to the two boarding schools in the Crooked Lakes Agency on the 22nd and 23rd of the present month.

FOOD (Round Lake Boarding School)

I was present during the dinner hour and noted that the food supplied was ample and good food. The appearance of the tables after the meal showed a lack of judgment. There was altogether too much waste. At nearly every place there were large portions of meat, bread already buttered, pudding, etc. left over. This waste was so general that I had to comment upon it.

GENERAL

I regret that the Principal was absent as I would have liked to direct his attention to the conditions as I found them. I am of the opinion that his staff have not had the training or experience to enable them to carry on the work in the manner that it should be done at an institution of this kind.

(Sgd.) W. Murison.
Inspector of Indian Agencies.
Dear Mr. Graham:

I have the honor to submit the following report of a visit which I made to the two boarding schools in the Crooked Lakes Agency on the 22nd and 23rd of the present month.

ROUND LAKE BOARDING SCHOOL (Presbyterian)

STAFF

The Staff at this school consists of the Rev. R.J. Ross, Principal; his wife, Senior teacher; Mrs. Margaret G. Starrell, Junior teacher; Mrs. Munachers, Matron; Miss Otthon, cook; Mrs. Carlyle laundress; Mrs. Moss, seamstress; A. Moss, Farmer.

I visited this school on the 22nd and found that both the Principal and his wife were absent in Ontario. Mrs. Ross had been called away a few days previous to my visit owing to the death of her father.

Attendance.

There were 76 pupils present, 37 boys and 39 girls. They looked fairly healthy but in all my experience I never before saw such patched up and ragged looking clothing as that worn by the boys. The girls had better clothing but appeared listless and indifferent and had a frowsy look. They did not present.

W.M. Graham, Esq.
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6332, file 661-1, part 1)
present the alert cleanly appearance that we have a right to expect in the pupils attending our residential schools.

In going through the school building I was oppressed with an atmosphere of listlessness in everything and feel that the members of the staff with whom I came in contact have not the qualifications necessary to manage an institution of this nature. I was told that conditions were better when the Principal and his wife were at home, but surely their absence for as short a time should not disorganize the routine of the institution.

Building. A separate building providing two classrooms was built last year. This building is 40'x 48' and is heated with hot air. The classrooms are large, bright and cheerful looking. The ventilation is good and I am told that the building was quite comfortable during the winter months.

Main Building. This building has been described so often that the Department are familiar with it. The exterior has not been painted since the building was repaired in 1922 and in consequence has a patchy appearance. The basement floor provides room for a kitchen dining room, laundry and furnace room. I found the kitchen clean. The dining room looked untidy and

If money is available painting should be done this summer.

W.M.G.
showed a lack of orderliness. The laundry also was not in a well kept condition. Their equipment consists of a large power washer, a hand mangle and four set tubs. The first floor provides an office, staff sitting room and two playrooms. The second floor, girls' dormitory and staff bedroom, and the attic provides the boys' dormitory. Wash basins and sanitary closets are provided on each floor.

The interior walls are not clean. The bathroom walls are badly splashed and dirty. The girls' beds had white spreads on them and they looked clean. The boys' dormitory on the third floor is on a par with the girls' as regards condition. I noted that each pupil was provided with his or her own towel.

Sewing Room

The sewing room and store rooms are in the old part of the building. The sewing room was tidy and the work I saw in this department was very good. In the store rooms I found a large supply of new clothing. Two complete new outfits were being prepared for each pupil to take home for use during the holidays. The clothing in the store rooms seemed to be all jumbled up and the lack of orderliness was very evident in that department.
Water Supply

The water supply is pumped from the lake into a pressure tank. The supply is abundant but I noted that the pump is not in good working order. There is a broken cast iron washer in the pump head and it appeared to me that there was a loss of about 50% in efficiency through leakage. The Principal supervises the care of the machinery and the need of a man who is competent to take proper care of this department is evident.

Farm & Garden

Mr. A. Moss, a practical farmer, is in charge of the farm work. Their crop consists of 50 acres wheat, 50 acres oats, 60 acres barley, 25 acres green feed, 5 acres of potatoes and vegetables. The farm work has been well done. An improvement was noted in this department. They are well equipped with farm implements - excepting a drill and disc harrow which are done stock. They have 8 work horses, 50 head of cattle, 3 brood sows and 21 other pigs. They are now milking 12 cows among which are two pure bred Holsteins purchased last fall. After providing for the calves there are about fifty quarts of milk per day available for the requirements of the school which appears to be ample.

The farm stock is in good condition and has a well cared for appearance. Apart from the Holsteins the cattle are mostly scrub Shorthorns.

Food.

I was present during the dinner hour and noted that the food supplied was ample and good nourishing.
Sir:

I am enclosing herewith a report of an inspection made at the two boarding schools in the Crooked Lake Agency by Mr. Inspector Murison.

Mr. Murison first deals with his visit to the Round Lake School, which is under the auspices of the Presbyterian Church. You will note from the Inspector's remarks that he does not speak very highly of this institution, and it seems to me there is room for much improvement.

There is a matter also in connection with this report that I think should be brought to the attention of the Department. It is absolutely and entirely wrong for a Principal who has the responsibility of looking after 80 or 100 children, to leave the institution without advising the Department or this office. The building might burn down or accidents might happen, and so far as this Office is concerned we would know nothing about it. It is not until the Inspector goes in that I find out the Principal is away and has left the school in the hands of apparently incompetent help. At one time principals of schools were under the same regulations as regular officers of the Department, and leave of absence was granted through the Department. I speak very strongly on this matter. Something will happen some day, and we should at least know where our principals are and whether they have authority for being away from their work.

If the Department have any funds available I will have the school re-painted on the outside. I would say about $600.00 would do the work.

The report on the Cowessess School is encouraging and shows that everything is well looked after and that the children are getting a proper training.

Your obedient servant,

W.M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

The Secretary,
Dept.of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Reverend Sir:

I wish to draw to your attention the advisability of officially reporting to the local Indian agent any proposed absence from an Indian residential school on the part of the principal. The Department deeply regrets the circumstances which made it necessary for you to leave the Round Lake Indian Residential School during the month of June; but we should be advised through our local representative whenever it is your intention to be off duty. The name of the officer who will be responsible for the institution should be indicated when such notices are being forwarded.

DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS
CANADA

COMMISSIONER'S OFFICE,
REGINA, SASK., July 22nd, 1925.

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 9th instant in which you inform me that you are writing to the Principal of the Round Lake School relative to absenting himself from duty without reference to the Department.

The information you give me is, to say the least, very vague. Am I to understand that I am still to be kept in the dark with regard to this matter? Are we to send Inspectors to these schools and find that the Principals are absent in Ontario or British Columbia? Surely the Department can come to some satisfactory solution of this problem. Why should not these men make application for leave of absence through this office and have it forwarded on to Ottawa?

The report on the whole was very unsatisfactory. You make no reference to this in your letter to me. I do not know how we can run these institutions properly if this is the way in which reports of this kind are to be dealt with. I find it difficult to carry on with as little support as I get with regard to important matters of this kind. I do not know if the Principal has even been reprimanded for the condition in which this school was found.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Stockholm Sask., July 25th, 1925

Dear Mr. McKenzie,

I acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 9th inst. re my absence from Found Lake School in June. As this is my first absence from the school, I was unaware that it was customary for the principal to notify the Department of his intention to be away. I shall be careful to do so in future.

As a matter of fact, I wrote from Toronto to the Agent, reporting the absence of a pupil from the school owing to accident. He therefore knew of my own absence.

Yours sincerely,

K.J. Ross.
Ottawa, August 4, 1925.

Sir:

I have your 304-11A of the 22nd ultimo, with reference to the Round Lake Indian Residential School. As you were informed in my letter of the 9th ultimo, I wrote to the Rev. Principal relative to absenting himself from duty without reference to the Department. Under cover of the 25th ultimo, he replied that he would be careful to comply with our wishes in future.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.
Sir:-

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 4th instant #108-1-1, with reference to the Principal of the Round Lake School absenting himself without reference to the Department. I was perfectly aware of the contents of your letter of the 9th ultimo, but this, to my mind, did not clear the matter up, and I wrote you on the 22nd of July, pointing out that I would still be kept in the dark if this leave of absence was to be granted direct from Ottawa, and asked if the applications from Principals for leave of absence could not go through this office, as is done with regard to leave for all other officers in the field. To this you have made no reply.

You are aware that our Inspector visited this school and found the absent Principal absent. Had we known that he was away I would not have sent the Inspector there. Only a short time ago our Inspector visited Fort Alexander School for the purpose of conferring with the Principal regarding painting and repairs. He found the Principal absent. These are not the only cases where this has happened and it is very unsatisfactory and means a great deal of time lost. I have suggested a remedy, but for some reason you do not seem to wish to act on my suggestion, which is a reasonable one and would be applied in another business concern but the Indian Department. What I want to know now is this, is the leave of absence for these men to be recommended through this office or not. Kindly advise me.

Your obedient servant,

M.M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.
Ottawa, September 8, 1925.

Sir:

I have your 504-ll of the 20th ultimo, with reference to principals of Indian residential schools absconding themselves from duty without permission from the Department. It is the practice of principals to acquaint the local Indian office and church authorities to inform the Department if a principal is to be away from his school for more than a few days during the academic year. There have been no complaints of late from any of our officers in Canada, except yourself, in this connection and it may, therefore, be considered that the present arrangements are satisfactory in the main.

It must be remembered that principals of Indian residential schools are employees of the various churches more than of this Department and more discretion and tact must be exercised in the prescription of rules and regulations than if they were on the staff of the Department.

The Department is not prepared to ask principals to acquaint us concerning absences during the holiday months of July and August. At this season, principals quite properly feel themselves more or less free from their more onerous duties; and as all responsible gentlemen, I feel it can safely be left with them to make satisfactory arrangements for the management of the schools during the vacation weeks.

If your office has in hand during the summer any activity which requires the presence of the principal of a school, it would be well for you to acquaint him with your plans and to ask that you be notified as to who will act as principal when he is not on duty.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.

Regina, Sask. Sept 18th, 1925.

Sir,

I would particularly draw your attention to what the Inspector says about the Portage la Prairie School. I only wish all of our schools were managed in such an efficient way. We have too many inferior men in charge of our schools; men who have no idea of business, which is very essential in conducting institutions of this kind. At the Round Lake School our Principal has fallen far short of the mark. I regret this as the Indians on this reserve have not had a fair chance. This school should be called upon to do better work.

Your obedient servant,

W. M. Graham
Indian Commissioner,

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
Sir:

I beg to advise you that I received a long distance telephone call today from the Indian Agent at Crooked Lakes, informing me that the Principal of the Round Lake School is incompetent to handle the lighting and pumping machinery at that institution.

In looking over Inspector Hurison's report on the Round Lake School, dated the 29th of June, I notice he remarks that a man should be supplied to take charge of this branch of the work. It is absolutely wrong, in my opinion, for the Department to put in these expensive plants and hand them over to incompetent men to run. I hear this constantly from the men who go to these institutions to install the plants; they usually come back and say that the men who are left in charge are not at all qualified to look after the machinery. It seems to me that the Department have not dealt with this matter seriously.

Before authorizing the appointment of men to handle the electric lighting, pumping and laundry machinery at our schools, even temporarily, the Department should make very searching enquiry into their qualifications, as incompetent men can in a very short time do irreparable damage to this expensive equipment.

I have asked

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
I have asked Mr. Pugh to go down to the Round Lake School and look over the situation and make a special report.

Although a very adverse report was sent in on this School by Mr. Hurison I have heard nothing at all from the Department with reference to it. I do not wish to appear to be too insistent in this matter, but it seems to me that a report of this kind requires action on the part of the Department.

Your obedient servant,

W. M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.
Ottawa, December 19, 1925.

Sir:

I have your 304-11A of the 11th instant, in which you draw attention to inefficiencies in the management of the Round Lake Indian Residential School. I note that there is on the staff no one competent to supervise mechanical plant. As soon as you forward a report, following Mr. Pugh's special inspection, I will take the matter up with the Church authorities and will also draw attention to general conditions at this school.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.
Sir:-

I beg to state that I have recently visited the Round Lake School, and while there looked over the plant as instructed.

The Fairbanks engine has been installed and was running well when I was there. There is an extra pulley required for this but I understand this has been ordered. This is required to run the line shafting as this engine also supplies power for the washing machine and a water pump.

I went into the care of the plant with the Principal, and he informs me that his is giving his personal attention to it, with two older pupils doing the regular running. He also states that in the event of a breakdown he gets assistance from Goldsby who is a good man with machinery. I might add that I have mentioned to Mr. Ross that he really requires a man to take care of the plant, and as I stated to you on the phone, I am of the opinion that if a good man was obtained to look after the light and water plant, that it would be economy.

The water pumping has given a lot of trouble, causing shortage at the building of water supply.

If it was decided that a man be placed there I would suggest that he had some supervision duties of the older boys, as I am of the opinion that the older boys under supervision, might be made much more useful, and their time occupied to good training advantage, both in cleanliness of premises, repairs etc., that are always to be found at an institution of this kind.

With the addition of another pressure tank for the water supply, which I understand has been ordered, I see no reason if a good man was employed there, why there should be any trouble with either of the plants at this school.

Your obedient servant,

(Signed) Jno. E. Pugh,
Indian Agent,

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina.

Dear Dr. Edmison:

Thanks for copy of Dr. Scott's letter from Ottawa, re Round Lake efficiency.

Last June Mr. Ross came east for General Assembly, the first time he left the work there since his appointment. In his absence, Mrs. Ross received a wire that her father had passed away very suddenly. She left at once to be with her Mother and a substitute teacher was provided in her place.

There was a disturbing element among the remaining staff that our W.M.S. asked to resign with a month's notice. During the absence of Mr. and Mrs. Ross, three Government Officials made an official visit to the school - Inspector, Agent and Nurse. Our Matron wrote me that the pupils were clean but were wearing their old clothes, which were patched but whole and clean. They were to leave for their vacation soon and she wanted them to wear their better clothes going away. She also said that the staff member who was asked to resign did not help matters but made the situation harder. This School has abundance of good clothing for every day wear, and also serge middy suits for Sunday. We send in each Fall sufficient for the year, with shoes included. If there is a shortage in any line the Matron writes us and we send in what is lacking. Of course the Inspector's report was not up to usual but I believe he made an excellent report on his next visit to the school.

Last winter they had trouble with the sewage system freezing up and a shortage of water. Also the electric lighting plant was not adequate. This caused much discomfort to the staff and pupils. As the school is now owned by the Government I wrote Mr. Graham and pointed out these deficiencies and asked him to have them looked after before the present winter set in. I also wrote our Principal, Mr. Ross, and said he must have a handy man with mechanical ability to supervise all the plants and our W.M.S. would pay his wages if necessary, but he must provide the right kind of help. Mr. Ross is not mechanical, but has many other admirable talents.

Mr. Ross wrote me some weeks ago that Mr. Graham was helping them re sewage, better water supply and in some other ways. Mr. Ross was quite hopeful for the outlook for the future. They require the addition to the school which was to have gone on last summer.

I would prefer that the Secretary of Home Missions write direct to Mr. Ross and find out from him how things are at this time.

Sincerely yours,

Dear Dr. Edmison:

I received your letter of the 11th inst. re Round Lake School.

As soon as Commissioner Graham promised us an extension to our School, we began increasing our attendance. The result was that in 1925 we had the children but the extension was not built. We had to carry on with what accommodation and what conveniences we had.

Then during my absence at the Assembly, Mrs. Ross' father died suddenly and she was called to Ontario. While we were both away, the official visit was made.

I discussed thoroughly with Commissioner Graham the report of this visit, having him call in the inspector that I could question him. The result was that I advised Mrs. Clark (you were away at the time) to replace me with some person who would be in favor with the Commissioner. I had offended him by going away to the Assembly without asking his permission. I had offended him by trying to save one of the officials he had dismissed. And then I had this very adverse report to contend with. I was afraid that Round Lake would suffer and that the best way to help the school would be to get out. Mrs. Clark referred me to you.

By this time the inspector had spent another day with us and reported improvement, had made plans for the erection of three out-buildings, an ice-house, an implement shed and a poultry house, and had indicated to us that we were likely to get a lighting plant and also a large pressure tank for water. All these improvements have been made. The pressure tank is on the ground but not installed. I discussed with our matron the report as to the untidy condition of the children. She said they were wearing their clothing, much of it, for the last time, (the visit was made in June just before the holidays) and that she gave them new clothing for going home.

We have had a second man since December and he understands the mechanical part of the plant. He has been accustomed to electric lighting and steam heating in his own home.

I have purposely refrained from writing you details of our work because I thought you were too busy. I shall be only too glad to give you information at any time.
We are following a very simple plan. We give the child what we think is best for him, and regardless of cost. For instance, this year we bought 25 barrels of the best Ontario apples. We give instructions, to the shoe manufacturer to give us the best article he makes having regard to the use to which we put it. We buy sleighs and toboggans and skates for them in winter and balls and bats in summer. We are trying to carry out the Department's instructions not because it is their instructions, but because we believe it is best for the child.

I came here at your request to help out a situation entirely different from what I imagined it to be. I want to remain just as long as I can help satisfactorily but no longer.

Yours sincerely,

Signed- R.J. Ross.

Dear Mr. Graham:

I beg to submit a short report on the Round Lake School, inspected July 7th, 1927. I also spent a few hours at this school on July 13th when inspecting the Ochapowace valley.

Here, as at Cowessess School, all the children were home on holiday. The Principal, the Reverend R.J. Ross, was the only member of the staff in the building. He is assisted outside by a young man, a mission, who was employed as mechanic, but now is doing all the outside work as the Farming Instructor. Mr. Ross has left. At present the wife of this young foreigner is doing the cooking. She is unable to speak English.

The farm crops were weedy. I understand that considerable of the crop had been diseased in this spring, which is poor farming and certainly does not tend to improve the weed situation. I feel that where we are instructing young boys how to farm, that only the best methods should be employed. The grounds and gardens about the school were weedy and certainly needed attention.

On my second visit, Mr. Ross had secured another foreigner to assist with this outside work. I do think that sufficient help ought to be kept so that the work is properly carried on.

The school building, with the exception of the old wing, is in good repair except for some work needed on the plaster in the dormitories and play rooms. This work would not cost much and perhaps could be best done now while the children are absent.

I received complaints while on the reserve as regards the way Mr. Ross sent the boys home for holidays. They were furnished with one suit of combination overalls, one shirt, cap, boots and one pair of stockings. The parents claimed they were unable to take their children any place in such clothes. I do think the Principal might furnish these boys with a decent suit with which to go home. I do not say he need give them their best but they surely have a second best which they might at least have.

The bridge which crosses the river just outside the school gate is a source of worry to the Indians. They claim Mr. Ross allows the children to play on it and
on it and are afraid of an accident. Mr. Ross resented my request that the children be kept off this bridge. He says they spend many pleasant hours on it. I do not think he realizes his responsibility in the care of these children. A bridge is no place for any child to play and I strongly advised Mr. Ross to see that in future no children played on it.

A new teacher has been engaged for the junior room, and I believe Mrs. Ross intends holding the senior room. Mr. Ross suggested that his wife would likely be matron as well as senior teacher. I admitted to Mr. Ross that Mrs. Ross could quite well fill either position but I felt she could not do both satisfactorily. If she tries to carry on both, either the children or the work will be neglected, or else part of her work will be pushed unto others. I believe a full staff is necessary at these schools and that well qualified people should be employed. If Mr. Ross moves into his house, I fail to see how Mrs. Ross could teach, do the duties of a matron, and also keep her own home. Dear Mr. Ferrier,

I thank you for your courtesy in writing me of the appointment of a matron at Round Lake Indian School.

We appointed Mrs. Margaret Heron to the staff of the school in July 1927. We started her on a matron's salary and expected that in a month's time, as soon as we were sure she was making no mistakes, she would undertake the full responsibilities of matron.

We also appointed a dietitian to take charge of the kitchen. This young lady, however, disappointed us, going to the university instead. We then put Mrs. Heron in charge of the kitchen and gave her the young wife of our farm instructor to help her. After some delay, we secured a suitable officer for the kitchen, but she was not accustomed to institutional work and it was necessary to leave Mrs. Heron with her for a time.

Then the lady in charge of the laundry resigned to prepare for her approaching marriage. Mrs. Heron had to remain in the laundry for a time until the lady we placed in charge there became accustomed to the working of that department.

Dear Dr. Manning:

The Department has recently received a report from one of our inspectors concerning conditions at the Round Lake Indian Residential School, and I am satisfied some changes will have to be made before really successful work can be expected. Mr. Heron, the teacher in the junior classroom, is without professional qualifications, and our inspector is doubtful of his ability to make progress. There is a very large class in the junior room and an expert primary teacher is required. The farm instructor appears to be quite capable of doing a good job, but is reported as wholly incapable of giving proper instruction to Indian boys. The stockman is a young Scotchman, who has had practically no previous experience with a milch herd. The woman in charge of the laundry is now learning to speak English and, of course, cannot be a capable instructress.

The report, on the whole, is rather discouraging and the Department is taking steps to effect some improvements in connection with the building and other physical equipment. It is the opinion of Mr. Commissioner Graham that some of the unsatisfactory conditions should have been noticed and the necessary alterations made by the Reverend Principal, himself.

I believe the Rev. Mr. Ross could show much better results if he had an efficient staff under him and I should be grateful if you would take whatever steps are necessary to this end.

I understand Mr. and Mrs. Ross live in the school building. You will remember that the Department purchased the MacKay residence for the use of the Principal. I believe that the appointment of a proper staff at this school would make it possible for Mr. Ross to purchase this house which is quite suitable for the purpose. Dear Mrs. Clark:

I have your letter of the 8th instant and also a copy of Dr. Scott's letter re the inspector's report on the staff at Round Lake. You have asked me to deal with the situation, and I am doing so by acceding to Dr. Scott's wishes as much as possible.

Mr. Donald Heron belongs to the very finest type of young Canadian manhood and the Indian boys and girls have had a great privilege in associating with him. But he has, as you say, no normal training. I am therefore taking steps to put a fully qualified teacher in his place. It will likely take a month at least to make the change.

The young Scotseman who was looking after the stables was working under the direction of the farm instructor. This young man expects to leave in two weeks' time.

Mrs. Louis Bartha has been working in the laundry under the close supervision of our matron who reports that her work is very satisfactory. She is the wife of our farm instructor. But she does not speak English well. I have therefore offered the position to a young woman in Manitoba.

Mr. Louis Bartha is in many ways the best all-round man we have had as farm instructor. He is industrious and thorough and prompt. He has been here now nearly a year and a half. At first he appeared to be diffident about exercising his authority over the boys. That may be accounted for by the fact that he was subordinate to Mr. Moss. He has however lost his diffidence and is making the boys toe the mark.

We very often employ an extra man or two in order to let all the boys have a half day in school. We think we have reached the stage where we should have two men permanently. With this object in view, I have been in communication with some likely men and am now waiting a reply from an Ontario man who is highly recommended.

Fear of fire more than anything else has kept us from enjoying the comforts of the home purchased for us by the Department. We have already extinguished two fires in the main building. These both took place, however, during the day. If it were not for the kindness of our staff in doubling up, two using the same room, we should be compelled to occupy the principal's residence.

Mrs. Ross is gradually improving. She was downstairs for the first time yesterday but we had to carry her back again. There are no fresh cases.

Yours very sincerely,

(signed) R. J. ROSS.

Reverend Sir,

A departmental auditor visited the Round Lake Indian Residential School on the 8th ultimo and found considerable difficulty in making a proper audit owing to the manner in which the books are kept. His remarks in this regard are, as follows:

"It should be mentioned that Mr. Ross lacks business experience and is not very methodical in recording the school business; no files or folders are used to keep vouchers, invoices or cancelled cheques, but they are scattered about in different drawers, baskets and parcels, and are not in order of date, consequently, to make a detailed audit for the fiscal year at this time was not considered."

The Principal never balances the Bank Account or records outstanding cheques. During long periods when deposits are not made, he continues to issue cheques and, in order that the Bank account be not overdrawn, he phones the Bank to transfer a sum from his personal account to the Trust account to cover the cheques issued. Exchange is hardly ever recorded, either of cheques paid or received, and, at present, there is an apparent surplus, presumably his own money, of $127.48.

"If there was cash on hand at March 31st, then the surplus would be increased by such an amount, but Mr. Ross does not remember whether he had cash on hand at that time and, when questioned, could not say how much the Trust accounts owed him. Two Trust accounts are kept as shown on Bank Adjustments - one a Savings Account (in the name of the School) and the other a Current Account, and when the latter becomes exhausted, he phones the Bank to transfer from the Savings A/C.

"The entries of expenditures in the cash book are not made from the cheque stub or when the cheque is written but are entered the following month from the cancelled cheques when they are returned from the bank. Ottawa, September 11th, 1929.

Madam,

I have your letter asking certain questions regarding the administration of an Indian residential school. I note that you have recently been appointed to the staff at our institution at Round Lake.

The per capita grant of $155 per annum is for the school's current expenses and the Principal must be prepared to account for the school's finances whenever requested by either the Department or the Missionary Society that is associated with us. The amount of the grant is determined by the average attendance. The school's books are not open to the public but, of course, may be shown by the Principal to any whom he wishes.

It is the Department's intention that the half-day system be in use at all Indian residential schools, i.e., one-half day in the classroom and the other half in one of the vocational departments.

The Indian Agent or the Principal of the school must secure the permission of the Department before formally admitting children. Those under the age of seven cannot be compelled to attend. The authorities of the school or the Department's representative may refuse holidays to pupils for disciplinary or other reasons if they consider it in the best interests of either the pupils or the school. A classroom teacher in an Indian residential school must teach whatever children the Principal admits. He is responsible to the Department. A classroom teacher's work is under the supervision of the Principal of the school, of the Department's Agent or other representatives, and of the Provincial Public School Inspector who visits the classrooms at our request.

In future, I believe it advisable for you to direct your questions to either the Principal himself or to the Indian Agent. Both are acquainted with the Department's wishes and regulations.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,

The junior room is in charge of Miss Afflick, who is a qualified experienced teacher, and I think the Department can count on much better work being done in this room than during the past few years. Mr. Ostrander informed me that on his visit the previous week to the school Mr. Ross was busy trying to repair a number of the toilets which were not in working order. I was surprised to find on our visit that he was still busy at this job, and that a number of the toilets could not be used. I believe a lot of the trouble is due to carelessness on the part of the children, and I have no doubt that if a proper mechanic were on the job that no trouble would be experienced in making these repairs. In trying out the toilets on the various floor of the building, I found no water supply. I might say that I was informed by one of the members of the staff that such is the condition a great part of the time.

- MR. ROSS -
Mr. Ross explained that water was pumped night and morning, but that on some days more water was used and, consequently, at times no pressure existed. No doubt this condition exists due to the fact that all this work falls on the Principal, who really cannot attend to everything. I pointed out the necessity of always having plenty of water, and asked Mr. Ross what he would do in the case of fire. His reply was that it was only a matter of a few minutes to start the engine and get 20 pounds pressure which he considered sufficient. I had the pump started and in about ten minutes when the pressure reached twenty pounds, I tried the fire hose on the ground floor and found that the pressure was not sufficient to force the water up to the roof of the school. The hose was then shut off and I requested Mr. Ross to increase the pressure to at least 75 pounds, but before it reached 30 pounds the belt came off and on examination I found it to be too slack and to have the lacing at two points partly broken. On further examination I found this belt to be past repair and it certainly should be replaced. In fact all the belts in connection with the engine and dynamo are too slack, and I would say the plant needs a general over-hauling. The department will perhaps recall that a stand-pipe was placed in this school a year ago in order to give better water protection in case of fire. It can be readily seen, had a fire occurred previous to my visit, how useless our equipment would have been when it was impossible to get pressure sufficient to put the water on the roof of the building. I also pointed out to Mr. Ross the condition of the boiler room, where undoubtedly the greatest danger of fire exists, and he made the remark that it was in a much better state than usual. I do not think Mr. Ross is really aware of the condition in which we expect these buildings to be kept, and I am more convinced than ever that it is only by having a man qualified to do this work that the...
Department can feel that the school is in the condition that it should be in.

The fire escape from the girls' dormitory on the west side of the building is so situated that a child in sliding down the pole can hardly avoid coming in contact with the railing along the steps leading into the boys' playroom. This railing is about six or eight feet off the ground, and a child striking it coming down as swiftly as they do is liable to meet with an accident. I would suggest that this fire escape be moved North to the next window which would then give plenty of clearance to anyone coming down the escape. The pole of this fire escape is secured at the top by a brace against the school. This brace I found to be detached and the pole was swinging free. I pointed this out to Mr. Ross, who was aware of it, but as this fire escape has not been used for fire drill he has neglected fixing it. Since the return of the children, the Principal has had no fire drill. Upon my request this was carried out, but, as a number of the staff were unaccustomed to the proceedings, it was necessary that they be told and consequently I did not consider that the drill was a real test. I instructed Mr. Ross and the Agent, Mr. Ostrander, to have fire drill regularly, so that in case of necessity the children and the members of the staff would know exactly what to do.

Authority was granted a year ago for the purchase of material for the erection of a root cellar, which no doubt is badly needed at the school. The work I understand was to be carried out by the school authorities. As yet this cellar has not been built and what few vegetables they have had have necessarily been stored in the old cellar which is in the basement of the school and adjoining the dining-room. Although the school will have no great quantity of vegetables this year, I think this work should be proceeded with at once, so that it will - not be -
not be necessary in the future to use the store-room in the basement of the school.

The yards around the buildings were tidy, but there has been no effort made on the part of the Principal since I have visited the school to seed down any of the grounds in an effort to beautify and improve the surroundings. Immediately in front of the school the ground is used as a vegetable garden, which is also the case at the side, except for a small triangular block which is used as the girls' playground. I noted that the children's playground had little equipment for their amusement, and I was informed by some of the members of the staff that practically no supervision is given to the children in regard to amusement.

The crop threshed this year was very light and amounted to about 400 bushels. At the present time ten cows are being milked which should supply sufficient for the needs of the school. Mr. Ross informed me that he was disposing of all the cattle except the registered Holstein stock. Shortage of feed made this necessary.

In discussing conditions with the Principal, he agreed that undoubtedly the fault lay in not having a properly qualified staff with which to carry on the work. He realized that a matron was necessary and also a first class man as farming instructor and engineer. However, he stated he was not prepared to pay more than $80.00 per month, and as long as Mr. Ross feels this way he cannot expect to get men who will assume responsibilities of this nature. Mr. Ross is a capable man, but it is impossible for him to act as engineer, plumber, and general repair man about the building, as well as farming instructor and stockman, and also carry on the general management of an institution such as this. In the majority of cases we find...
cases we find principals assuming the general management of an institution and not actually going about in overalls doing the work themselves, and it is in such institutions that we find the best work being carried on.

I have the honour to be,

sir,

Your obedient servant,

A. G. Hamilton,
Inspector of Indian Agencies.

Dear Mr. Scott:

I have the honour to enclose herewith a report on the two Boarding Schools in the Crooked Lake Agency. This report was written by Mr. Inspector Hamilton and the inspection took place between the 29th of August and the 6th instant.

The report on the Cowessess School shows that everything at this institution is in first class shape and good work is being done.

You will take notice of the Inspector's remarks regarding the readers that are being used at this institution. I am not prepared to say whether they should or should not be used. The Department should, however, be aware of this fact.

The hog pen, which is needed, is provided for in the Estimates which have recently been submitted to the Department.

I would particularly draw your attention to the Inspector's report on the Round Lake School.

The repairs required in the classroom have been provided for in the Estimates which have been recently forwarded to Ottawa.

I would draw your attention to the class of men that Mr. Ross has employed to assist in instructing the Indian boys how to become farmers and citizens. To me it is almost a joke, and the Department should insist, without delay, to have these men replaced and proper men

proper men put in their place. Giving supervision of this kind is doing the Indian more harm than good, and he would be better off if he had never been to school, so far as receiving instruction in agriculture and the care of animals is concerned. I would ask the Department to insist on this change being made at once. The general conditions of the farm appear to be very bad.

There is also great room for a matron at this institution.

This school has never been satisfactory, and I consider Mr. Ross a very bad manager and not the type of man who should be in charge of an Indian school. He might be saving money, but he is saving it at the expense of efficiency.

I would also draw your attention to the way Mr. & Mrs. Ross are living - in a little room overcrowded with their clothes. I also wish to direct your attention to the picture Mr. Hamilton paints of this man's desk. A poor example, indeed, to Indians or to a staff.

With regard to the suggestion that a new chimney be built, we would first have to ascertain whether the existing chimney is defective. The plumbing and drainage at this school has always been unsatisfactory and always will be as long as Mr. Ross is there.

I would also draw your attention to the unsatisfactory manner in which the Inspector found the fire apparatus, pressure tanks and pumps. I feel satisfied that we are taking a great risk in having Mr. Ross in charge of this school in view of the fact that he is so careless about everything. Anything that is broken about the place is let go until it is completely ruined.

Authority
Authority was granted to build a root house, it is true. The Principal has not taken advantage of this, and as there are very few roots around the place this year, I doubt whether it is needed.

I would also draw your attention to the wages which Mr. Ross pays to a Farming Instructor - $50.00 a month. He could not get an ordinary boy for this. The question is, are the Department going to go on paying out money for this kind of supervision. I would suggest that a change be made at once. I have always thought we could well afford to close this school up and take the children to the Brandon School where they would receive proper attention, medical care and training. The United Church could establish a Mission at Round Lake and could look after their interests there, but the children could be sent on to Brandon. This should be seriously considered by the Church and the Department.

I may say that I am in receipt of a letter from the Provincial Dept. of Public Health, complaining about the unsanitary manner in which Mr. Ross kills his beef animals. This is a further proof that all I say regarding this man's incompetency to manage an institution of this kind is correct. He can save money, but he cannot instruct Indians.

I cannot recommend any alterations or repairs. The original building, which is joined on to the addition which was built a number of years ago, is unfit for school purposes.

Yours very truly,

Dear Sir:

I am addressing this letter to you in the interests of the children of the Round Lake Indian Residential School, Stockholm.

In August of this year I was engaged as Junior teacher. On Nov. 8th I was dismissed by the principal, Rev. R. J. Ross, because of my "disloyalty" in writing to Dr. Barner, Toronto, the Superintendent of Indian Missions under the United Church, re conditions in the school which ought not to exist. May I report to you the situation as I saw it in my intimate association with the work for the past three months? It is difficult, however, to point out specific conditions that are outstandingly bad, as the entire administration under Mr. Ross is such that an atmosphere of suspicion, sordidness, and slackness exists throughout, due, I believe, to the indifference and inefficiency of the principal.

I think, perhaps, the greatest lack from which the children suffer is the lack of a qualified and efficient matron, and farm-instructor. Mrs. Ross, who is Sr. teacher and who is in the school-room from 9.00 A.M. until at least 5.30 P.M. each school day, is the head of the matron's department. From last autumn (1928) until May (1929) her mother was matron, nominally. From May until October there was none. In October, the farm instructor's wife was given the position. She is quite inexperienced and of the type who is quite willing to be subservient to Mrs. Ross, doing any task to which Mrs. Ross assigns her in any department. She has nothing to do with the clothing of the children, with supplies for her department, or with the assigning of tasks etc. The children need a "house-mother" who would be intimately in touch with their needs both physical and otherwise, a woman with some vision and an understanding of children, and in control of her department. As Senior teacher, Mrs. Ross can not get time to act as matron, even if she had an understanding of their needs, which she certainly has not. The majority of the 78 pupils are young, 48 being in my department at school and so in Grades 1 and II only. Hence the need for a "house-mother" is greater. In all my 18 years experience as a teacher, I never had in my school a dirtier, more ill-clad - or more like-able - class of little folk. Yet, when I went to the

- matron to -

matron to talk it over with her, she said she could do nothing without going to Mrs. Ross about it.

I do not know much about the farm instructor's department. When I went there the office was held by three young, ignorant, (very) immigrant boys, the oldest 22 years, two of them were dismissed shortly after and the other left on his own accord. They were most uncouth and illiterate and I know that there had been no other farm instructor for at least a year previous. The present farm instructor, an ex-gardener from Scotland, keeps the grounds, outbuildings, etc., very clean and neat, and makes a good janitor. He is absolutely honest, a good man, and good to the children, but very illiterate. He too gets all his instructions from Mr. Ross regarding the farm work etc. Neither he nor the matron know anything about the financial receipts or expenditures in their departments, of course. Knowing how very loath Mr. and Mrs. Ross are to spend money on clothing, fuel, supplies, repairs, etc., and how keen they are to increase the number of pupils attending (although ten girls are already sleeping double in the single beds of the girls' dormitory) and how little is raised on the farm, one cannot but suspect that there is a reason why the principal wishes to keep the control of all departments absolutely in his own hands.

There are a great many things about the school that spell indifference and slackness and that make for unlovely and unsanitary conditions. In the boys' dormitory, bath room, neither of the two closets can be used, an open pail being used. They will not "flush," nor drain away and have not for months, so I tied them up to prevent their being used, as I supervised the children's work in that dormitory. The open pail has been in use for a year, but Mrs. Ross did not approve of my tying up the closets. She said, "What will the Nurse say when she comes around." When not tied up, they look all right, you see. Of the 5 basins, only 1 has a plug and yet 26 boys wash. In the girls' dormitory (the "show" dormitory) the closets are almost equally bad. In the playroom lavatory, the single closet there has been completely out of commission for some weeks, all the children using the outdoor closets in all weather, at all hours. No combs are ever provided in either playrooms. Dining room conditions are very unlovely. The children sit on benches around bare tables, all their dishes being granite, "chipped" and ugly. A bowl of lard sits in the centre of each table. (no butter is ever used) - the lard is bought by the barrel) and the senior girls pass the bread around, carrying the big thick slices piled in their hands or arms from table to table. The tea (a cheap variety) is put on the table in big granite pitchers holding about a gallon. Only two tables (about 20 pupils) get milk. I do not know that the children are underfed and I think they get considerable variety. I do not think the food is well chosen, and it is most unattractively served. Breakfast always
means porridge, bread and lard and tea - nothing else. When I asked the cook why so little porridge for each child (about 3 thps) she said, "The children don't like it and besides the pot isn't big enough to make more", I do not wonder that they do not like it. It is always "stone cold" when they get it, and badly made. The washing for the school (twice each week) is hung in the dining room to dry, from end to end. Children who leave Round Lake school will take away with them a very poor ideal of what a home should be. Of personal cleanliness and neatness they see very little. Of course, they get a bath and clean clothing once a week, but, after that, run wild for another week, with no one to care what they look like. Mr. Ross himself has complete charge of the foot-wear for both boys and girls, and he gives them the most ridiculous outfits. The little girls go teetering around in pumps with outlandish heels, or those old fashioned very high boots with high heels, sizes too large, or silly little sandals that won't stay on their feet - cheap lots that he buys for next to nothing, or second-hand misfits that come in bales. The boys have to wear theirs until they can scarcely keep their feet in them, with binder twine for laces, and garters, quite often. Of course, each child has a better outfit, the one he puts on for "church" and takes home with him at holiday time. To almost everything at Round Lake, there is the two sides, the side that goes in the report and that inspectors see, and the side that exists from day to day in the actual working out.

The staff at the school find conditions so unpleasant that they are constantly changing, especially if they are the better type of staff-member. The cook is leaving about the 20th of this month, and, when she leaves, only one member will be on the staff who has been there more than 3 months. Nothing is done to make it pleasant for the staff. We had to almost fight to get the furnace going this fall. The staff sitting room is occupied by the farm instructor and his wife, as their bed-room. Mr. and Mrs. Ross sleep in the office, where he also keeps his store of apples, oranges, candy, etc., which he sells to the children (buys apples by the box and oranges by the crate and sells them at double the price, and more). No one ever gets any use of the radio excepting himself. The car or truck never leave the place except when he drives (even to haul supplies in or out) and he never invites the staff to accompany him. More often than not there is no water on either dormitory floor. (Mr. Ross has sole charge of the engine).

Re the education which the children get in the school, I need say little. It is a secondary consideration with Mr. and Mrs. Ross, secondary always to getting the work done in and around the institution. The children are in low grades for their years owing to the frequent change of teachers and the hiring of unqualified teachers in the junior room. They leave the school usually in Grades 3 and 4, and when Senior Grade 2 is reached, they are only half-day pupils. In the years since Mr.
Ross has been principal, only one boy has gone through Grade VIII and five girls. I believe that the school education that a child gets who leaves school in Grade 3 or 4 to go back to the reserve is almost of no use to him. He has just laid the foundations and builds nothing on them afterwards.

Of the religious training which the children get from Mr. Ross, I shall say nothing beyond the fact that it is little - very little more than the formal observance of many customs (as the family worship twice daily) prayers repeated in concert, graces sung before and after meals, etc. He has no oversight over the children in any way. Mrs. Ross is the disciplinarian, and she is right in her element there.

Re the health of the children, I shall say little. There are several children needing medical attention, but I suppose a nurse will report such. There was no nurse visited the school in the three months that I was there. Dr. Allingham visited the school at more or less regular intervals, but his visits were purely formal. He examines only such cases as Mrs. Ross takes to him.

I am sorry that this report has grown so lengthy. It has been most difficult to condense it and still give you a true picture of things as they are. As I said before, it is not so much that bad conditions exist, as it is that the children might and should be getting so much more than they are, with the same expenditure of money and effort. There is a lot of very fine "human stuff", second to none, in the Round Lake school, and I know that our Government desires only the best for them while they are its wards.

Sincerely yours,

(Miss) Lucy L. Affleck.

P.S. Until Tuesday next my address will be Y.W.C.A., Regina.

On the 15th instant I forwarded to you Provincial School Inspector Winter's report on the Round Lake Indian Residential School, and in my covering letter made mention of the fact that Miss Affleck, whose work was favourably spoken of by the Inspector, had been in my office complaining bitterly of matters in connection with the management of the school. She had a great deal to say and I asked her if she would submit in writing anything she wished to have brought to the attention of the Department. I am now attaching a copy of her report, which I should be glad if you would read.

There is no doubt a great deal in what Miss Affleck says. Mr. Ross's management of this school has not been satisfactory. In February, 1928, when forwarding Inspector Hamilton's report on the Round Lake School, I drew your attention to the fact that Mr. & Mrs. Ross were occupying sleeping quarters in the school, which I did not consider they should do, and in a letter dated March 2nd, 1928 you stated you were hopeful that with a proper staff Mr. Ross would be able to move into the McKay residence. Dear Mr. Graham:

I beg to submit the following report on the Round Lake Indian Residential School, inspected on June 19th while on the Crooked Lake Agency.

The boys' dormitory was clean. There are 12 windows and only 3 had screens on. The storm sashes were still on some of the windows. The cubic feet of air space figures to about 12,000 and the boys number 26. The toilets were not in working condition.

The girls' dormitory is bright and was clean, with all the beds neatly made. There are 11 windows with screens on 5, while on the others the storm sashes still remained. This room measures 12,160 cubic feet and at present accommodates 53 girls and in eight or ten cases two girls are obliged to sleep in a single bed. None of the toilets were in working order.

No screens are provided for the laundry which is small, and can only be ventilated by the windows. Screen doors are also needed for all outside doors, and the woodshed adjacent to the boiler room should be properly provided with doors and repaired.

The toilets throughout the building were out of working order, except the one in the staff bath-room. The children are obliged to use outside closets, which are very unsanitary. The girls use one, built on their playground about 75 yds. from the school. This is open all around the bottom. The boys are provided with one at the

J.M. Graham, Sec.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.
barns, and this is even in worse condition than the girls'. I think both these toilets should be destroyed and the toilets in the school put in proper repair. At present I consider the condition serious, as the flies are bad and have access to the filth and dirt as well as to the kitchen and dining room of the school.

The girls' play-ground is small. It is on the side of a hill and extends to the road near which the septic tanks empty and from which a very offensive odor was noticeable. The only equipment for amusement is a swinging platform, which I do not consider safe. This platform is about 12 ft. square and when in motion with 10 or 15 children on, it moves back and forth with considerable force. If a child falls off and is hit, serious results will occur. I have already seen two girls badly hurt. I think a new play-ground should be provided, as well as proper swing and teeter-totters, also a soft ball outfit. I also think these children should be supervised during recreation and taught to play wholesome games.

The class-rooms are both in need of interior painting, as they have become badly smoked and are dark and gloomy. The outside of this building should also be painted.

A play-ground is being arranged for the boys. They have no equipment for amusement, and I understand are given little supervision during recreation. I think training along this line is essential, as a game fairly and honestly played is a credit to any group of boys, and contains a training which serves well at all times.

The fire protection is not good, as the new engine provided by the Principal is too small. It is impossible to get sufficient pressure, as the engine will kill down. I think as a rule, the pressure ranges from about 30 lbs. to 50 lbs. and at this it would be impossible to throw a stream of water on to the roof. A pressure tank, to be used for fire pre-
protection only could be installed and if properly looked after would greatly improve conditions. Mr. Sinclair, who is termed the mechanic, is really the assistant farmer and spends most of his time on the engine plowing. He is capable to look after the machinery, and boiler, as well as all general repairs about the buildings; but does not have the opportunity. Mr. Ross claims he cannot afford to keep a man around the building as mechanic.

Mrs. Young is still acting Matron. She really has no authority and takes all instructions from Mrs. Ross. Her salary I understand is $400.00 per year, while all the other ladies on the staff receive $500.00; so the Department can readily understand that a real matron cannot be secured at such a salary - less than the ladies she supervises.

Mr. and Mrs. Ross still reside in the school. I understand they go across if any official happens along and, if necessary, Mr. Ross said they entertained in the home, but in no sense are they occupying it; nor do I think Mrs. Ross has any intention of doing so, as she claims she has a right to a room in the school, being a member of the staff. This home is well furnished throughout, and ready at any time to be occupied. The beds are all neatly made, the curtains clean, and the house throughout bright and cheerful. I doubt if Mr. and Mrs. Ross will ever consent to live in this home as long as she holds a position on the staff.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

I beg to enclose herewith Inspector Hamilton's report on the Round Lake Indian Residential School, which was inspected by him on the 19th June. The report, like former reports, is very unsatisfactory, and it seems to me that we are getting nowhere whatever with this school. It is certainly discouraging to myself and the Inspectors to go back year after year and find no improvement, although suggestions have been made to the Department.

At first I would like to draw your attention to the unsatisfactory air space in the girls' dormitory, which should afford twice as much fresh air per pupil. Two girls are sleeping in one single bed in several instances, a condition which Mr. Ross has been told time and time again not to have exist. You will note that there are several windows without screens, and that most of the windows in the dormitories still have the storm sashes on. The temperature in the valley has been anywhere from 85 to 95 degrees during the past couple of weeks. The toilets throughout the building are out of order. I think this is injurious to the health of the Indians, and if this condition of affairs were made known to the public, I think there would be trouble. The outside toilets are disgusting. There is no excuse for such a situation at all. How any man could see this before his eye every day and take no action is beyond me. The fire protection is not in good shape. A new engine was bought, but it apparently is not what is required. You will also note that the Matron is not satisfactory. We ought to be able to get a proper staff here. You have provided a residence for the principal of the school, and, I believe, furnished it, but he does not occupy it. This matter has been brought to your attention so often, but I feel I must do so again. The fact that he remains in a room 14 x 14, which is used as a storeroom, office, etc., indicates the type of man he is. I would ask again that you insist upon his living in the residence. I feel that if conditions are not changed at this school, we will have an accident at this school through fire or something else.

Dear Sir,

I wish to bring before you a matter in which there is considerable interest shown around here.

There is a small summer resort on the shores of Round Lake, in the Quapelle Valley, one mile from the eastern end of the Ochapaquace reserve. For some years these people have kept a small store open both summer and winter, mainly depending on the Indian trade, and from this derive a goodly share of their living.

Now right across the Quapelle River from the reserve is an Indian school, a boarding school, in charge of which is a minister by the name of Ross, who for some years has been selling supplies to the reserve populace, at a great increase over cost price. Now this is greatly damaging both to the Indians and the trade of this small store, for when these ones bring wood or hay to sell at the Mission Mr. Ross induces them to take their pay in trade, where, as if he paid them cash they could purchase the same amount of groceries elsewhere and still...
be cash ahead due to the difference in prices charged.

Also when these Indians are hard up and needing groceries any person who gives them credit has to depend on the honesty of each Indian to pay their debts. While I've been told by people both outside and on the reserve that Mr. Rosses bills of outrage prices are collected in full and the other accounts ignored.

This Mr. Ross is supposed to be a minister of the Gospel and as such is receiving a steady salary that never fluctuates through hard times. And whereas there are only two in his family both receiving high salaries, this little store I spoke of is owned by an elderly couple the man being seventy-five, and they have one daughter and four grandchildren dependent on them, with the store their sole means of support during the winter.

Do you think it fair or just that this supposed to be brother to all men should be allowed practice the profession of storekeeper, and exploit such exorbitant prices from his parishioners, as well as a salaried minister to them. If he has this right, then I'm nothing further to say, if not I only ask that you look into this and that keep to his own position and not seek to displace these honest storekeepers from their living. Also the Indians whom he is supposed to befriend but him cheat and continually complain of his unlawful sales.

Susting you will consider this fairly. Remain

Yours respectfully Pearl J. Carter

TUESDAY, OCTOBER 9, 1934

HISTORIC INDIAN SCHOOL MARKS 50TH ANNIVERSARY

Cairn Is Erected This Year to Memory of Rev. McKay, School Founder

STOCKHOLM, Sask., Oct. 8—Established by Rev. Hugh McKay in 1884, the Round Lake Indian residential school this year marked the start of the second half of a century of existence.

Two months ago, to commemorate the 50th anniversary of the school's founding, the Indians erected a cairn on the spot where the first school was built in 1884 just south of the present school building which is 15 miles south of Stockholm off the Ochapeawace Reserve.

Entering its 51st year, the school, operated by the Women's Missionary Society of the United church, has seen through long years of Saskatchewan's side-long-building and is today a monument to the work of early pioneers.

A few days ago a service was held marking the anniversary when 30 girls of the C.G.I.T. group attended the "Rainy Day" service held by Miss Kirkpatrick, director of girls' work under the Religious Education council and on Sunday Miss Kirkpatrick presided for Rev. William Ross. Mrs. Ross and Miss Ross Weywell are in charge of the C.G.I.T. group in the school.

STUDENTS WIN PRAISE

The old school has won recognition in several ways during its 50 years of service to the natives. The 76 boys and 45 girls who attend are mostly from the St. Sauveur and are from five to 16 years of age. Twenty of the girls went high praise from Sir Robert Borden's adjudicators at the Medicine Hat musical festival this year, as did their leader, Mrs. Therrien.

Cherrywood Fancy Colantha, too, has brought fame to the school. She is the purebred Holstein cow that won the grand championship prize at Yorkton, Portage la Prairie, Brandon, Regina and Saskatoon exhibitions in 1933, and which will be sent to England for the fair in Toronto soon. There is also on the farm a prize herd of Holsteins owned by the W.M.S. The farm buildings and property belong to the department of Indian affairs at Ottawa.

REVIVAL BY INDIANS

For 25 years Rev. Mr. McKay was principal of the school, until 1922 when he retired because of old age. Devoted and loving to his church and to the Indians he served, there stands today a monument to his work. Built by the Indians themselves, the cairn was unveiled in the presence of a number of friends from Neudorf, Indians of the reserve, and Dr. Sahmara, a brother of Mrs. McKay, who spoke at the ceremony. Ex-chief Walter Ochapeawace spoke to the people through his interpreter, Joseph Bear.

Today the following comprise the school staff: Rev. R. J. Ross, principal since 1922; Mrs. R. J. Ross, senior teacher; Mrs. W. Weywell, junior teacher; Mrs. F. W. Therrien, matron; Miss F. W. Therrien, night supervisor; Miss Lloyd French, herdman; Mrs. Lloyd French, cook; Miss K. Currie, seamstress; Mrs. Fred McKay (native), laundress; Walter Anderson, mechanic.

The Honorable Minister of Justice,

Dear Sir:

Re: Percy Ochapawace, #22.

For your information I would advise that I have been requested by Walter Ochapawace, the father of the above Indian boy who was recently found frozen to death on the Crooked Lake Agency in the Province of Saskatchewan. The father has instructed me to take the matter up with you with a view of having a public enquiry instituted under the Enquiries Act, being Chapter 99 of the Statutes of Canada in 1927.

The facts are briefly this: This Percy Ochapawace was an inmate of the Round Lake School in the Province of Saskatchewan to which many of the Indian children of the Crooked Lake Agency are sent. This is a boarding school. It appears that at the time an Indian child is accepted into this residential school, written consent is given by the parents and the School or its officials are thereby constituted as guardians to the respective children.

This lad was thirteen years of age and had been going to the Round Lake School for several years. On Sunday, the 13th of January he, with two other boys ran away. Whether it be true or not, I do not know, but it is claimed that they were unnecessarily hard worked. Apparently from the information in my hands, the Principal of the School was warned that these boys were leaving. Sunday, the 13th, of January, was very cold and I believe well over twenty below zero. The boys left thinly clad to walk many miles to their homes.

The facts appear to be that after the departure of the boys no enquiry was made for them nor a search. I am informed the first the Principal of the School knew about the situation was on the 17th of January when he was communicated with and advised that this boy's body had been found. The immediate cause of the death was exposure from cold is of course beyond question and as far as the father is concerned he realizes that. What concerns him chiefly and the parents of the other children now attending the School is that there must be extreme laxity or carelessness either in the interpretation of such rules as there may be or in the rules themselves that it does seem to be inhuman that if it be true, no enquiry or search was made for the boy for three or four days in extreme weather, that such a state of affairs could exist such as described.

May it be stated to you that this case has caused much uneasiness and dissatisfaction among the Indians generally on this Reserve and they feel that the time has now arrived in justice to them and particularly to their children that a most rigid enquiry of a public nature should be instituted on the facts surrounding the death of this boy and particularly into the whole scheme of control of the children in this School.

It...
It is, I think, quite possible to have such an enquiry under the Enquiries Act and I am satisfied that is the only thing that will take place that will satisfy the people generally, both Indian and white.

I might just add for your information that this matter was first taken up with the Department of Indian Affairs with the object of it taking such an enquiry and they have refused. Therefore, in making this request to you, it is all that appears to be left to the unfortunate father of this boy to attempt to at least see not only an investigation of the School but an attempt to make as a result of such an enquiry, proper regulations to be put into effect and without question, the lives of their children safe-guarded.

There are other instances on the Crooked Lake Agency where there has been unfortunate deaths without any investigation. I am not suggesting there should have been in the cases just mentioned but certainly that is the impression among the Indian people.

Therefore, I shall be glad if you will look into the matter and if you require any further information or data I shall be glad to furnish it insofar as possible.

Yours truly,

(Sgd.) G. C. Neff.
