Sir:—

I regret to have to report that Percy Ochappowace, a pupil of the Round Lake I.R. School was frozen to death on the night of Sunday the 13th instant.

This boy with two others ran away from school some time during the afternoon of the day in question and the Reverend Principal found he was missing about 5 p.m. The weather was extremely cold about 25 below zero and the roads were very bad. Soon after the boys left the school a blizzard sprung up and they made their way with great difficulty to a point on the Ochappowace Reserve about 7 miles S.W. of the school reaching that point about 5 p.m. The boys then separated the deceased going south towards his home and the other two travelling west towards their own homes. These two did not reach their homes that evening but arrived at the home of Alec Belanger another Ochappowace Reserve Indian about 8 p.m. in a state of exhaustion but not badly frozen.

The deceased travelled about 1½ miles after he left the other boys and his body was found late Thursday evening (17th) in a willow bluff about ¼ of a mile from the nearest Indian home. He had apparently become exhausted and laid down and went to sleep and froze to death.

The matter has been thoroughly investigated by the Coroner, the R.C.M.P. and myself and the Coroner decided no inquest was necessary. These three boys were last seen by a member of the school staff about 1.30 p.m. Spnday and were not missed until milking time about 5 p.m.

In view of the extremely cold weather and bad roads the Revd. Principal would have been well advised to have an immediate search made as the boys tracks could have been followed in the snow but apparently as the boys ranged from 13 to 15 years of age he thought they would reach their homes in safety. He wrote me a letter dated 14th. instant informing me that the boys were truant and this letter reached me on the 16th. My first intimation that the boys were missing was by a telephone call to the R.C.M.P. at Broadview by the Ochappowace Reserve Farm Instructor on the morning of the 17th. The farm instructor had first been advised of the matter at 10 p.m. the previous evening.

The information came to him in the following manner. The boy's elder brother Daniel Ochappowace happened to call on Alec Belanger at whose home the other two boys had arrived as previously mentioned and Belanger casually asked him if Percy had got home safely on Sunday evening. Daniel replied that no one at home had seen Percy and then Belanger told him about the three boys leaving school and the two that stopped at his house Sunday night. Daniel immediately drove to all neighbouring Indian houses enquiring if anyone had seen the boy but without any result. He reported to the Farm Instructor and search was immediately instituted. Immediately I received the telephone call on the 17th. I drove with the R.C.M.P. to Ochappowace Reserve and we organised a search with the result that at 5 p.m. that day the body was found frozen to death.

As would be expected the father of deceased as well as other Indians who have children in this school are considerably upset and are inclined to place the blame on the Revd. At 8:30 A.M. this date, a telephone call was received from Leander Carlson, Farm Instructor, on the Ochappowace Indian Reserve, to the effect that the above named boy had run away from the Round Lake Mission School on January 13th, 1935, in company with Glen Gaddie and Alec Wamasee. The latter two had arrived home but Percy had not been seen since they had parted on the Reserve, eight miles south of the Mission.

Sub-Division

I immediately took the matter up with J.P.B. Ostrander, Ind. Agt. of Broadview, and after he had communicated by telephone with Rev. R.J. Ross, Principal of Round Lake Mission School, also W.J. Ball, Indian Clerk, nothing could be learned concerning Percy OCHAPOWACE, than was already known.

At 11 A.M., this date patrol was made in company with J.P.B. Ostrander by team to the Ochappowace Reserve, where Alec Wamasee who had left the school in company with Percy OCHAPOWACE, on Sunday January 13th, 1935, was interviewed. He stated as follows:

"I am 14 years of age, attending school at Round Lake Mission. On Sunday, January 13th, I ran away from the School at 2 P.M. in company with Glen Gaddie and Percy Ochappowace. We were going to our homes. We walked south from the mission, across Lonesome Prairie, to where Joe Mar attacked hay this summer. We were cold and made a fire in the snow. After the fire Percy left us travelling south towards Jim Assiniboine's on his way home. It was about sundown when we parted from Percy. We were all tired as the snow was deep and it was very cold and stormy. Glen Gaddie and myself left, going west towards the home of Alec Belanger. We travelled about one and one half miles and were cold and tired again, and built another fire. We lay down for awhile and went to sleep. I woke up and could not see Glen Gaddie. I found him covered up in snow. I got him out and found we had lost a light. We walked towards the light and reached the home of Alec Belanger. We found Mrs Belanger home alone. She had something to eat and went to sleep. We stayed there over night and the next morning went home."

5. On the night of January 16th, 1935, Alec Belanger was at the home of Nasacase's when Daniel Ochapowance, brother of Percy Ochapowance, came there. Alec asked Daniel if Percy had arrived. Daniel stated that he had not, and that he was at Round Lake Mission School. Belanger then informed him what had taken place on Sunday.

6. Daniel Ochapowance then set out on horseback, travelling from house to house making enquiries about Percy but was unable to gather any information as to his whereabouts. He then informed Mr Carlson, Farm Instructor.

7. A search party was then organized of approximately 25 Indians on horse-back, and in company with Lee NASACASE, we proceeded to where they had the first fire, where Percy had left them. Travelling a mile south of there, we left the body of Indians searching. In company with J.P.B. Ostrander we proceeded on to the Round Lake Mission School, where Rev. R.J. Ross, was interviewed and stated to the following effect:

"On Sunday, Jan. 17th, '35, I did not miss Glen Gaddie, Alec Nasacase or Percy OCHAPOWANCE, until about 5 P.M. On questioning some of the boys I learned that they had left the School about 1.30 P.M., telling the other boys that they were going home. The boys had had about 3 hours start. I did not think it worth while sending after them, as they would have nearly reached home by this time. It is not customary to follow boys, 12, 13, or 14 years of age, after they get a 2 or 3 hour start on us, from the school. I did not get in touch with anyone outside of the school to let them know the boys had left, but I wrote a letter to Mr Ostrander, on 16th, Jan./35, informing him that these three boys had run away from the school. The letter was posted in Stockholm on Jan.17th, 1935. I did not know that the boy had not arrived home safely until I received the telephone call from Mr Ostrander this morning."

8. We returned to where the Indians were searching and the body was found around 6.30 P.M. about 1½ miles south of where the boys had parted, a half mile south from the road which he had travelled on. His foot prints and tracks could be followed into the bush where he had lay down; he then had crawled on his hands and knees for about 15 yards into some willows. Here the snow had been partly scraped away and he lay in the hollow, face down. His hands were held up under his face with his mitts off under his hands. He was frozen solid. He was dressed in a pair of blue bib overalls, black and red sweater, fleece lined underwear, one pair of grey socks, gum rubber boots size 9 and no overcoat. The rubbers appeared to be too large for him and the snow had packed in around the tops of them, making his feet wet. There were no tracks in the snow around him other than what had been made by him. Alec Belanger, Bert Francis and Joe Boar were left to guard the body until I returned with the Coroner.

9. I returned to Broadview Detachment at 12.15 A.M. of the 18th, Inst.

10. At 8.30 A.M. this date, in company with J.P.B. Ostrander, and Dr. A.W. Allingham, Coroner, a further patrol was made to the Ochapowance Indian Reserve, where the body of Percy Ochapowance was examined by Dr. Allingham. He stated that death was due to Exposure and Freezing. After interviewing Rev. R.J. Ross, of the Mission School, and Walter Ochapowance, Father of the deceased, Dr. Allingham, stated that no inquest was necessary.

Dear Sir,

During the past year the teachers of our school have been wondering what the attitude of the Government is towards Indian education. Do they consider that those who are capable of taking higher education should be given every opportunity to do so? Do they want the pupils encouraged to take advantage of their educational opportunities? Are they willing to stand behind the teacher who is making an effort to raise the standard of scholastic training among the Indians? If so, there are a few difficulties to which we would like to draw your attention.

We feel that a half day at school, and no study periods outside school hours is insufficient for those pupils in Grade Eight, where they are faced with a Departmental exam. In this limited time, it is almost impossible to cover the prescribed amount of work, let alone give them the amount of drill work needed to give them a thorough grasp of their work.

Experience has shown us that there are a number who are capable of attaining high school standard. For example, in our own school during the past twelve years we have had eighteen successfully pass their grade eight exams (eleven with honors). One year there were seven in the grade eight class. All seven passed, and all seven passed with honors. This surely shows that the Indian children have the ability.
We feel that education is a very strong factor in raising the standard of living and the ideals on the reserves, and in aiding the Indian in becoming eventually self-supporting. We willingly admit the necessity of education for our own race. If it is necessary for our own race with their background of civilization, how much more necessary is it for the Indian who has only the present from which to draw? Teachers in Indian schools are faced with many difficulties that do not present themselves in white schools.

First there is the half day already referred to. Although these pupils attend school but half the time they are expected to complete a full year's work and pass exams set for the Inspectorate. Furthermore, as there is no time allowed for study periods outside of school hours, all the work must be done during this half time at school. As the pupil progresses in his grades the amount of work he must cover increases accordingly. Consequently it becomes increasingly difficult for him to cover his prescribed amount of work in this limited time. And by the time he has reached grade eight it is almost impossible to get over the work let alone teach it thoroughly.

Then there is the matter of texts. The authorized Primer for this province is The Highroads To Reading Primer. But the Department do not supply these. They do offer two alternative Primers but, as these were not intended as preludes to The Highroads To Reading Readers, they are naturally not as suitable. The work in the Highroads Primer has been carefully selected so that the child may easily make the transition form the Primer to the Grade One Reader. Why are these not available for use in Indian Schools?

We also consider that inspection by the Provincial Inspector just once a year is not sufficient, and, as the teacher has no access to a copy of the report he submits she has no means of benefiting from his criticism.

Then, too, there is no superannuation scheme for teachers in Indian schools. When a teacher with a provincial certificate assumes duties in a school under the Dominion Government she is cut off from the benefits of superannuation. Should she later return to a Provincial school she is given
no credit for time spent in that Dominion school. And in the case of Saskatchewan, if she has been absent from a Provincial school for a period of two years she loses all credit for any years of previous teaching experience she may have had. Teachers can hardly be expected to remain permanently when they are thus penalized. And yet, permanent teachers are what Indian schools need for it takes time to adjust yourself to the Indian pupil, and to the conditions prevailing in Indian schools.

In view of the above facts we feel that teachers in Indian schools work under many difficulties and have many barriers to contend with. Is the Department sufficiently interested in Indian education to want the teacher to make every effort for better educational standing in spite of these difficulties? Or do they adopt the 'laissez faire' attitude?

We would appreciate your reply.

Yours very truly,

Mary B. Ross.

Dear Sir:

The Department is in receipt of your letter of the 23rd ultimo, enclosing letter received from Mrs. R. J. Ross, senior teacher at the Round Lake Indian Residential School. The Department cannot understand why Mrs. Ross writes as follows:

"We feel that a half day at school, and no study periods outside school hours is insufficient for those pupils in Grade Eight."

As far as the Department is aware, all Indian residential schools provide a study period, and the Department considers that the Principal of the Round Lake Residential School should make the same provision.

With reference to the Readers, the Department gave very careful consideration before deciding to supply the Pre Primer "Two Little Indians" and the Primer "Friends". It is felt that when a pupil has mastered these two books there should be no difficulty in proceeding to Book I of the "Highroads to Reading Series".

Owing to the cost involved, the Department is not prepared to arrange for the provincial inspectors to visit Indian schools more than once a year.

The Department has given consideration to the question of arranging for teachers in Indian schools to participate in the provincial teachers' superannuation fund, but as this would involve a heavy expenditure on our part, due to the fact that we would have to make arrangements with each province in Canada, it has been found necessary to defer taking any action.

Indian School Has Champion Holsteins

The Qu'Appelle Valley in Saskatchewan offers many picturesque spots to the traveller and the present site of the Round Lake Indian Residential School with its beautiful expanse of lake, its wooded slopes and high table lands, is one of the most pleasing. At this point the valley is much wider than it is farther west giving room for a number of up-to-date highly productive farms. The soil is of the best and the climate is more temperate than it is up on the prairies.

A comparatively few years ago the voyager to this country would have probably encountered only Indians chasing buffaloes. Today he will find a bunch of Indians working hard at farming or a herd of Holstein cattle which by its show ring performance has demonstrated itself to be one of the finest in Western Canada.

There is quite a difference between hunting buffalo and milking Holstein cows yet the Indians are making good use of both under the watchful eye of Rev. R. J. Ross, Superintendent of the school.

The School was founded in 1884 by Dr. H. McKay, a missionary sent out by the Women's Missionary Society of Canada. Serving several groups of Indians in the Reserves which are found in the Qu'Appelle Valley southeast of Regina, the school which is connected with the School has gradually come to play an important part in the Round Lake mission to the Indians.

Foundation from Strathmore

In 1922 Dr. McKay retired and his place was taken by Rev. R. Ross who brought the first herd of Holsteins into the herd in 1924, when he purchased two pure bred heifers from the farm near Strathmore, Alberta. Today there are 90 head of registered black and white at Round Lake, and today at the same time other cows are kept. About 50 gallons of milk are used daily and some of the children drink it twice daily.

The buildings of the school belong to the Department of Indian Affairs. Besides the school, the farm and the herd of Holsteins are all maintained by the Women's Missionary Society of the United Church of Canada. The school is provided for the girls and boys of the Reserves in the district. Public schools in the Reserve possess texts and practical equipment science for the girls, and practical agriculture for the boys are on the curricula. The experience gained at the school makes the better citizenship and self-reliance when they return home to their homes on the Reservation. A choir of Indian girls from this school has won "1st honours" in provincial musical festi-

King, Regina; Man-O-War Return Lassie, bought by Mr. Ross; Senor Peter, new junior herd sire; Cherrywood Franzy Pouch, senior cow and champion at one or two shows; Round Lake Florrie, winner of D.R.O.K. two-year-old heifer; and Cherrywood Franzy Colantha, champion at many shows. How applicable is all this to the Work among Indians? The mere fact that we have been dealing with Indians and not with their more aggressive white brethren explains in part why conditions have not been subjected to periodic change. Surely the time is ripe for a review of our whole approach to the Indian problem.

Last Winter we did think that something was about to be done when Mr. Doucet under authority from your Department visited several schools in the hope of adjusting the curriculum to help meet in a fuller way the special needs of the Indian Child who would in time become a citizen of his home reserve. We liked Mr. Doucet and we also liked what he had to say but alas what has come of it?

Every five years the Department should send out, not one man but a small representative commission. They should come not primarily to the schools but to the Reserves. In any approach to the Indian work as a whole we must keep in mind that each Reserve must be considered by itself and that everything that is done for the Reserve must be done keeping its people and no other people in mind. Everything that is done should be contributory to life on that certain Reserve and no other interest should predominate. It is not uncommon to find even in a Residential school machinery functioning more for its own interests than for any special thought that has been given toward the people on the reserves from which the children come or the future welfare of the pupils when they return to those reserves. I know a Residential School in the Prairies teaching children coming from the far northern wilderness how to farm. This is but one example of how we can care for the Indian and err because we have not in mind either the reserve from which he comes or his future when he shall have to return to it. This I feel is one folly growing out of our loose jointed arrangement between church and the government.

The small committee just suggested let it be made up of Educated Specialists sufficient in number to approach the problem with a balanced view. In this sense they would be your department seeing things first hand and through unbiased and unprejudiced minds. This commission would consider each reserve by itself, spend time enough to fully acquaint themselves with every detail, satisfy themselves that they have an intimate knowledge that they have discussed their findings with end in turn heard the judgment of the General Superintendent, the Indian Agent and the principal of the school within the area under inspection.

Among those composing this commission there could be an Economist, a Psychologist, trained Social Worker, perhaps a civil engineer. I could describe the expected contribution of each toward making a complete report but rather than take more of your time I will try to illustrate by describing the field covered by the Economist in this special investigation. First and foremost among problems in any section of our country is the economic one. Let scientific investigation reveal the adequacy or the inadequacy of the present means of making a livelihood on each reserve toward supporting life not only now but under future conditions that may arise in a state of existence or living. If the means is found to be inadequate then it is high time something is done about it. On the other hand if the means is adequate, incentive whatever angle it may take should be fostered to get the full and complete co-operation of the Indian.

The main thing in all this is not the size of the commission but its composition, its vision and its intelligence and its sympathies. Once a project like this is set on foot we will be on our way to a modern and sane adjustment of existing difficulties and future programs.

The future of Indian affairs in Canada I fear hardly admits any of the things I had hoped for it. Rather than spend more years in work where the maintenance of the status quo seems the chief interest I have decided after giving sufficient notice to join the army as a Chef-lain. Trusting you will interpret this letter in the same spirit with which it has been written. I remain,

Yours sincerely,

A. C. Huston

Dr. McCallum:

When you were at Norway House in July 1934, Mrs. Huston and I were attending a conference of workers among Indians conducted at the Residential School in that place. We were also waiting a plane to convey us to the remote northern post of Nelson House. After four years at this isolated Mission during which time Mrs. Huston as nurse and I as missionary travelled thousands of miles by canoe and dog toboggan, the church called me to accept my present work on the Prairie. As far as I know, none of the Missions may to accept the responsibility of an Indian Residential School and came to the work with enthusiasm and a vision of its possibilities. The war intervened to prevent me from visiting several schools in the United States in search of ways and means for the better conduct of my duties.

Frustrated in this I set about to find with limited facilities way of helping Graduates to find a place in life. I also introduced into the school those different factors that I hoped would measure the child's future in a world larger than the confines of his own Reserve. I felt at the time there were certain graduates who with help could adjust themselves into this wider citizenship. After four years of working among the children and having contact with their parents in the homes on the Reserves I have come to the conclusion that something fundamental is amiss in our whole program.

Adjoining to our school there are four Reserves from which our children come. It seems to me that the churches apply to every aspect of life to be seen there you could find none more applicable than the word—Indifference? This to be sure has always been the besetting affliction of the Indian. Still I do believe that proper diet and an adequate incentive would work wonders as a corrective. Let me add that incentive need not always express itself in attractive garb but at times must be made especially with Indians to take the form of co-operation. The Department of Indian Affairs has gone far beyond the letter of the law in keeping the treaty obligations and has been content at the detriment of the Indian with the bare minimum from him.

The churches have within reason been given a free hand to do what each denomination saw to be right under existing circumstances. Each in turn has had its wants financed not always on the basis of necessity but sometimes on the power or its representation. On the other hand the government itself has kept almost entirely to secular matters. It is easy therefore to see how under this loosely knit arrangement there has and still can exist many shortcomings that impede the work and how hard these will be to overcome.

Any Constructive criticism should come from Ottawa. Yet it is almost always easier to procure money from the sponsor of an existing order for its maintenance than to secure from them the application of courage, intelligence and vision sufficient for striking an axe at its roots.

Church as well as state has often acted on the assumption that there is but one way to reward long and faithful service. They hand out high authoritative positions as one might confer a degree with the result that the work over which the appointment has been made is often conducted in a fashion that is conservative rather than progressive. These men as a rule have sound judgment but they lack the ability to untangle themselves from the past. They lack enthusiasm and the capacity for quick and decisive action in the face of a new set of circumstances. They lack the vision and the healthier, more hopeful outlook of younger men. Surely we would be wise to take a page from the experiences of our army in this regard. They are continually setting their house in order. They have learned that change is a law of life and that the old order as well as the old men who created it must go and give place to new.

DEPUTY MINISTER

I am sending forward herewith, for your consideration, copy of a letter received by this Branch from the Reverend A. C. Huston, Principal of the Round Lake United Church School, Whitewood, Sask. I am sending forward also copy of my reply to this communication.

Mr. Huston was born on an Ontario farm, took his high school course at Peterborough Collegiate Institute and took an Honours Course at Toronto University in Arts and a Theological Course at Victoria College, Toronto. Immediately following his graduation he volunteered for missionary work at Nelson House, Manitoba. He is still a man in his early thirties and his wife is a qualified nurse. He is just the type of man that we should retain in our service. If such men as Mr. Huston are permitted to leave the service, the outlook from the educational standpoint is in no sense promising. As requested in your above letter I visited Round Lake School yesterday and investigated the complaints of Mrs. Geo. Gaddie regarding mistreatment of her son Bruce.

This boy is 14 yrs. of age, and while is puny and small for his age, he appears in good health.

The strapping was administered to him for refusal to do his assigned morning chore, which was filling up the lackett heater, making up the furnace and sweeping up in the furnace room in the main building. This was given him as a light job because of his size. He had neglected to do this work for a week and hence the punishment. When I examined him there were no signs of any marks, though the boy told me that his arms had been marked on the inside of his forearm from wrist to elbow. Mr. Huston stated that there was only a slight discolouring which is usual immediately after a strapping.

This boy, along with some others, was punished last year for going into the girls' dormitory. He stated that on that occasion his arm was black and the strap cut his wrist. The strap used is the regulation strap.

As regards Mr. Osborne, the farming instructor, he does not appear to be very popular with the boys. A large number of the older boys used abusive and obscene language to him. He had some trouble with Douglas Gaddie (Bruce's brother) three or four months ago and wanted to resign but Mr. Huston persuaded him to stay.

I wish to inform you that Mrs. George Gaddie, of the Cowessess Reserve in the Crooked Lake Agency, who is a widow and has a son Bruce attending the Round Lake School, came in to see me a few days ago.

This woman informed me that last year the Principal of the Round Lake School, Mr. Huston, had given Bruce a strapping on his hands and the strap used had cut the boy's arm causing it to bleed and become black and blue. This makes me think of our own four Reserves where farming is the one means within the Reserves for the maintenance of life. When White people with ancestors whose farming experiences go back for generations have among their number men who find no interest or incentive to farm how can we expect an Indian population with only experience in hunting behind them to take to farming as a group. The child like mind of the Indian demands as a reward for his effort immediate and visible results. Nature almost always rewards the hunter that way. The farmer on the other hand has learned to wait and hope for the uncertain reward of the harvest. It is easy to see how the Indian accustomed to the one way would find little incentive to put forth his best as a farmer when the reward seems so far away and so uncertain. What I am trying to say is that immediate and visible rewards provide for the child like mind a real incentive.

This idea has caused me to ponder the wisdom of placing a factory or shop on Reserve similar to ours. The weekly pay envelope would provide the immediate and visible reward for effort expended and we hope, the incentive to continue. Not long ago I was in a small factory in a local town and the thought struck me that Indians could have performed every operation that was being done as readily as the whites. I take it that the Indian has a certain skill. The type of workshop or factory that would be placed on the reserve would have that in mind. It could be managed by a White man serving under the Department in much the same capacity as the Agent.

It seems to me that work of this type would provide employment for those with no desire or aptitude for farming. It could offer part time employment to the Farmer in need of ready cash. It would or could be a means of developing workers for a similar type of work elsewhere. Surely in these days when so many peace time industries are on war production it would be a good time to start on a peace time product and build up a market before post war competition becomes an issue.

It is my intention before long to work out on paper my ideas for the new school that will we hope be erected after the War. Recently I have been down lecturing in Winnipeg and addressed seven audiences in three days. Everywhere I go I speak hopefully of the future among Indians because I believe there is a way of tackling our Indian work aggressively and that the Department will after the war face the issue in real style. I remain,

Yours sincerely,

Dear Mr. Hoey:

It has been my intention on several occasions to reply to your very considerate and helpful letter of December the twenty second written on behalf of Dr. McGill. I waited knowing that time would eventually enable me to unravel and settle within my own mind the problem as to whether I should enlist as a Chaplain or remain at my present task. There seems to be at the present time a shortage of men to fill that position. Indeed I would have been permitted to have remained at the school until June thirtieth so as to have given The Woman's Missionary Society sufficient opportunity to secure a successor. At long last after much debate I have decided to remain at my present post.

In reading the last issue of The Beaver published by The Hudson Bay Company I was interested in the investigations made by Dr. Moore and his associates. I knew well the country also the various types of maladies which they described. All resulting from the lack of proper nutrition. In my letter referred to above you may recall how I said to Dr. McGill that if one was looking for one word that could explain the condition of every phase of life on the average Indian Reserve one could find none more applicable than the word "Indifference". I then hastened to say that proper diet and an adequate incentive would work wonders as a corrective. I am very glad to note that our Department of Indian Affairs is attacking this problem with gloves off and in a scientific way. I used to say to the Indians on the trail If I had your grub box and you had mine I would be dead and you would be super men. Proper nutrition would remedy many of the ills that afflict them and this should lead us to go still further and investigate the ways and means available by which a livelihood can be made.

You may recall that when speaking of incentive I said it need not always express itself in attractive garb but at times it must be made, especially with Indians to take the form of compulsion. In other words I meant that when the ways and means of making a livelihood were found on a certain reserve to be adequate for the maintenance of life according to a decent standard of living that the Indian should be made to work. To-day there is plenty of work outside the reserves being offered to Indians, yet ninety percent of those who could do otherwise live far below par because there is no inner or outer compulsion to make them lay hold on this special opportunity.

When peace comes these opportunities will vanish and then the various reserves will have to have within their own boundaries the means for providing a livelihood. Surely the means must be made available and the Indian must be presented with an incentive that will call forth his co-operation.
Ottawa, March 23, 1943.

Dear Sir:

We have your letter of June 22 with reference to the insurability of employees of Indian Residential Schools. We note that a specific case has arisen in the case of the school at Round Lake.

The letter, from which you quote two paragraphs, written by the Rev. George Dorey, Associate Secretary of the Board of Home Missions of the United Church of Canada, indicates that Mr. Dorey is under a misunderstanding regarding the insurability of Government employees. It is not correct to say that the Dominion Government does not insure its employees. As you are aware, all employees of the Dominion Government within the insurable classes are insured unless their employment is certified to be permanent in character.

This privilege of certifying as to permanency does not extend to private employers, such as churches. Churches are, however, considered to be charitable institutions, and exception is, therefore, granted to employees of a church under the provisions of paragraph (g) of Part II of the First Schedule to the Act.

The question of insurability of employees of the Indian Residential Schools seems to depend, consequently, on who is in fact the employer, the Dominion Government or one of the churches.

Section 9 of the Indian Act reads:

"The Governor in Council may establish

(a) day schools in any Indian reserve for the children of such reserve;

Report on Round Lake Residential School

Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, OTTAWA.

I visited this school on the 21st instant.

I was informed there were 80 children in residence and I believe this is about 5 children over the quota.

I found this school in very good shape since both the interior and the exterior of the building had been painted this year. The grounds were also in good shape. They had a very fine garden and the returns have been good this year as they had ample rain.

This school is short on staff but there seemed to be a sufficient number to get along with.

They had 240 acres under crop and the returns are good. 65 head of cattle are there at present and they are milking 15 cows. They have quite a number of chickens, geese, and turkeys, also 30 hogs.

You will recall that we spent considerable money last year on equipment at this institution. This year the equipment, as a whole, is in very good shape.

The Principal, Mr. Huston, informed me he was being transferred some time this Fall to the Portage La Prairie School.

Everything around the place seemed to be in good order with the exception of the barns. The barn is getting old and dilapidated and they intend to put some money in it from the proceeds of the crop. When I was there they were hauling gravel to put in some cement work in repairing the walls and foundation.

The school was busy harvesting and threshing when I was there and I can only add that everything seemed to be going satisfactorily around this institution.

Report on Round Lake Indian Residential School

I have made two trips to the Round Lake Indian Residential School, on September 5th and October 11th respectively. My visit on September 5th was just at the opening of school and not a favourable time to judge any school as the staff is often made up of new members and the children have just returned from their holidays.

When visiting the school on September 5th I found many things unsatisfactory and drew them to the attention of the Principal, Reverend Mr. J.A. Card. He had many excuses to offer chief of which was that he had not been at the school very long and that everything was in bad shape when he started. I was inclined to accept his excuses and expected to see considerable improvement on my next visit. However, when I visited the school on the 11th instant I regret to say that I found no improvement whatever in the many things which needed improvement.

Mrs. Menzies, the Provincial President of the M.M.S., one of whose chief interests is the Missions and Schools under the United Church, happened to be at the school the same day. This had not been arranged between us but was a fortunate coincidence as I had told her following my visit to the Round Lake School on September 5th that there were many things about the school in which I was dissatisfied. She informed me that she was going to make a trip to the school to investigate my complaints.

Mrs. Menzies informed me that she had written to the Reverend Principal of the school about two weeks previous to her visit advising him of the date she would visit the school. Either from intention or carelessness Mr. Card had arranged to be absent in Winnipeg on the date of Mrs. Menzies' visit. I did not advise him of the date of my visit because I wished to visit the school without special preparation having been made for my visit.

I took Mrs. Menzies around the school buildings to see the many instances of neglect and carelessness about the school. Mr. Kerley, the Indian Agent, was, of course, present also.

As the Department is aware, the Round Lake School is a fire trap if fire ever breaks out in it. The only fire escape which had been in operation on the west side of the building, being that part of the building which is most likely to afford a means of escape from the dormitories, if there was a fire, had been eliminated by building at the foot of it an outer porch over the door to the boys' play room. I was annoyed when I saw this on my visit to the School on September 5th and drew Mr. Card's attention to it. He said he would have it moved to another window on the same side of the building where it would allow an immediate exit from the porch. The fire escape has not been moved when I again visited the school on October 10th. The broken panels of glass at the time of my visit on September 5th ran into dozens. Every building on the premises had some broken windows and some of them had many. None of these had been repaired on October 10th, in fact I believe even more had been added to the number in a little over a month. The school grounds are receiving no attention whatever and there are tall weeds in front of the main school building which have been growing all summer, and were still there on October 10th. All the buildings of the school needed painting but broken boards here and there and other damage resulting from...
resulting from carelessness and lack of discipline with the children have rendered the buildings unsightly and unfit for painting until considerable repair work has been done. The flooring of the boys' play room had dangerous holes in it and many boards of the flooring ready to break through at any moment. Mr. Kerley, the Agent, informed me that there has been flooring at the school for some months for repairs to these floors but nothing has been done to repair them. Some of the dormitory floors are practically worn through in spots, also, and much repair work is needed.

A new school building is certainly needed at the Round Lake School and I believe should be the first one built in this province if the Round Lake School is to continue in operation. I do not think, however, that Mr. Gard is a suitable Principal and he would have to show me a great deal of improvement before I would feel inclined to trust him with the supervision of a new school and the costly equipment which would go with it.

I am quite aware that Mr. Gard has staff difficulties and has had difficulty in replacing undesirable members of his staff with people who have the right qualifications, but many of the repair jobs and the school grounds could receive attention by the older boys of the school if the school was properly supervised and I see no excuse whatever for having weeds everywhere about the buildings with many Indian boys in the school well able to perform such work if properly directed.

J.P.B. Ostrander,
Inspector of Indian Agencies.

Superintendent of Education:

Day schools to replace Round Lake Residential School:

With Mr. Ostrander and Mr. Kerley I discussed and examined sites on the reserves on June 20 and 21.

Our view is that four schools will be necessary.

The sites suggested have been selected with regard to probable future concentration of homes on the better farming land.

Mr. Kerley is to finalize the map of the reserves showing the four points:

(i) In the valley at the north end of the reserve, on the road leading to Dubuc, near Stanley's house. There should be water.

(ii) At the corner of sections 2, 3, 35, 36 across the big slough from Alexson's near a good spring.

(iii) About five miles east of (ii) on a knoll near Mrs. Assumption's house. A community field likely to be settled soon is nearby. It is not far to a spring and a well.

(iv) In the SW ¼ of section 6 on the Raddemacher. Water has been encountered here but has to be verified. Not much settlement nearby, but it is the area where the Indians should farm.

Some children will for the present be too far from any day school. Mr. Kerley is to prepare nominal rolls of those who must have residence.

Mr. Kerley is also to approach Broadview Unit Trustees regarding admission of pupils to white schools.

Regional Supervisor,

Supt., Broadview.

Superintendent of Education:

Round Lake Residential School:

An early decision regarding this school's future would facilitate disposal of pupils and staff. Some of the latter are already looking for new employment.

With Mr. Ostrander and Mr. Kerley today I toured over part of the school.

It would be possible to struggle along for another year, despite the handicaps in the kitchen and laundry, but now is as good a time as any to abandon this decrepit establishment. In order to continue it would be necessary to build a small barn for horses and in lieu of cows to supply milk, liquid or powdered. And there are other changes that would incur difficulty and expense.

But it is too late to hope to get the pupils into new day schools by even the end of the coming September.

I foresee obstructions to the admission of a significant number to white schools.

The continued schooling of these children may, therefore, require adjustments at Berilo, Brandon, Portage la Prairie, and perhaps Gordon's residential schools.

If the upper grade pupils go to Brandon I again recommend that pupils of that school begin their course at Brandon High School in Grade Seven. Manitoba education officials support this idea.

Regina, June 29th, 1949.

Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, OTTAWA.

The Department will have received the report of Mr. C.A.F. Clark, dated June 21st, 1949, in connection with the future of the Round Lake Indian Residential School.

Mr. Clark's letter was written after a discussion between us, and, of course, I agree with its contents.

Certainly some definite decision will have to be made at a very early date, and I do not see how the Round Lake Residential School can continue for another term without a large expenditure. A barn and other out-buildings will have to be built, unless it is proposed to carry out the farm work with a tractor and buy milk for the children.

The equipment in the kitchen, laundry, and boiler room is in very poor shape, and there is no space in these rooms to permit installation of suitable equipment, in addition to which, the whole of the building being a terrible fire hazard, we would not be justified in installing expensive equipment in it.

It is my opinion that, as there is small likelihood of day schools being built this year to replace the Round Lake Residential School, certainly not in time for the beginning of the next term, Mr. Kerley should be given information as to the number of children who can be accommodated for the next term at the Birtle, Brandon, and Portage Schools, in order that he may discuss with the parents the matter of sending their children to those schools, and have a definite decision with regard thereto at least by the middle of August. I believe that a few of the children from the Round Lake Area could be placed in the Gordon's School, when it opens, if there is no objection to the United Church children being placed in an Anglican Residential School.

We had hoped that a number of the children, particularly of the Ocharowace Reserve....
of the Ochapowace Reserve, could attend white day schools which are reasonably close to their homes. However, Indian Superintendent Kerley has been definitely informed by the Broadview School Unit Board that they will not permit the Indian children to attend their schools. This question may be settled to our satisfaction later, but at least accommodation at the white schools will not be available at the beginning of the next term.

I agree with Mr. Clark's recommendation that pupils of the Gordon's School with a standing of Grade 7 or higher, should be sent to Brandon for the purpose of attending Brandon High School at the beginning of the next term.

May I be given definite instructions with regard to these matters, as soon as possible.

J.P.B. Ostrander,

Saskatchewan.

Dear Colonel Neary:

I have made a report today in connection with the re-opening of the Round Lake Residential School but did not mention therein a matter which in my opinion is deserving of serious consideration by yourself and whatever action you consider necessary.

In my opinion Reverend J.A. Card, the Principal of this school is entirely unfit physically and mentally to continue as principal if the school is to continue in operation. I would suggest that you discuss him with Mr. Clark who visited the school with me recently. When appraising the school I mentioned to Mr. Clark the mental state in which this gentleman has been for some time, and the fact that whether he was undergoing nervous breakdown or for some other reason I do not know, I have to introduce myself to him every time I visit the school as he does not remember me from one visit to the next. I asked Mr. Clark to take particular notice of this when he got to the school and he will remember the fact that I had to introduce myself. He will also remember the fact that Mr. Card could not recall whether or not there had been a visit of a School Inspector during the term.

Actually it is practically impossible to do business with Mr. Card because of his mental condition, therefore you will imagine how unfit he is to manage the institution. You are also aware that there has been considerable difficulty in controlling the children and dealing with the parents of the children. This is mostly due to the fact that Mr. Card is completely incapable.

I did not previously bring this matter to your attention because I expected that the school would close and the matter would right itself. However now that it seems quite possible that the school will re-open very serious consideration will have to be given to replacing Mr. Card as Principal. How that is to be done I do not know, nor am I willing to officially state that Mr. Card's mental condition is as bad as I have indicated in this letter. However if Dr. Dorey and the Ladies of the W.M.S. are so anxious to continue operating the Round Lake Residential School they will certainly have to do something about its management.

J.P.B. Ostrander,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies,
Saskatchewan.

Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, OTTAWA.

Enclosed is copy of a letter from Indian Superintendent W.J.D. Kerley, of the Crooked Lake Agency, and a petition signed by many of the parents of the Kahkewistahaw and Ochapowace Bands protesting against Mrs. Linton, senior teacher at the Round Lake School, remaining as teacher for the next school term.

I may say in this connection that when Mrs. Loveys was at the Round Lake School recently I mentioned to her that I had been informed that this petition was circulating, but that I had not yet received it. I know nothing particular against Mrs. Linton, and I believe she is fairly successful in the classroom. I believe that perhaps she is rather strict with the children, and the strap is too much in evidence. I mentioned this to Mrs. Loveys and she, in turn, mentioned it to Mrs. Linton. Mrs. Loveys afterwards informed me that Mrs. Linton stated that she does not punish the children, and that any necessary punishment of the children is done by Reverend Mr. Card, the Principal. I cannot argue this point, but I doubt very much that he imposes much punishment on the children. In any case, I think Mr. Clarke will tell you that there was a strap on display in Mrs. Linton's room on one of his visits. If she does not use it for punishment, at least she keeps it on display as a threat of punishment, which does not promote harmony in the classroom.

I do not feel inclined to recommend the removal of Mrs. Linton as I believe that many of the difficulties at the Round Lake School will be overcome if Reverend Mr. Card retires and an efficient Principal is placed in charge. I understand that there is quite a possibility that this will be done.

J.P.E. Ostrander,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies,
Saskatchewan.

Attention of Colonel Neary

Dear Dr. Dorey:

Could you please let me know whether there is anything new concerning the situation at the Round Lake Residential School.

I realize your difficulties in locating such a Principal but would be very pleased to know if Mrs. Loveys or yourself have anything further to report on this situation.

Bernard F. Neary,

We find that he is now perfectly able to return to his usual work but feel that he should slow down in his usual activities and not undertake too heavy a load. Regular hours of work and rest would be recommended.

Wishing him further success in his work.

A. A. Dick, M.D.

Your interest in my case would be much appreciated.

Yours sincerely,

J.A. Card.

ROUND LAKE INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL.

Dear Mr. Ostrander:

I have just received a letter from the Reverend Mr. Card, reading as follows:

"There seems to be some doubt in Ottawa as to my health and ability to carry on my work in the Round Lake Residential School. I wish to allay any fears that might be held by any in Department.

"To assure you I enclose a bill of health from the Doctor who had my case. Others were called in as consultants in my case. I have enclosed a copy and would like the original when you have done with it.

"Your interest in my case would be much appreciated."

Mr. Card attaches a Doctor's report signed by Dr. Dick. I enclose a copy of the Doctor's report.

I have been in conversation with Mr. Dewar, the local Member, concerning the future of this school and he is prepared to approach the United Church with reference to its closing at the end of the next school term.

We have included in our 1950-51 Estimates the four one-room day schools requested for this reserve and it is presumed that these will provide for most of the Indian children now attending the Round Lake Residential School.

Yours sincerely,

Bernard F. Neary,
Superintendent of Education.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for whose grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

Re: Round Lake Residential School

Dear Mr. Graham:

I have the honour to submit herewith a report of an examination of the books at the above school, which I visited May 12th., while at the Crooked Lake Agency.

You will recall that I had some difficulty on previous visits in preparing a statement of the School's affairs owing to the poor book-keeping and lack of system in filing invoices or cancelled cheques, etc. Much the same conditions prevail at present, so a detailed audit was not attempted, but the Bank Pass Book was examined, a few invoices and cheques, and also the synoptic cash book.

Certain suggestions and recommendations which I made last year to the Principal, Rev. R.J.Ross, had been complied with, regarding the balancing of Bank A/c's and the school cash book. The book had been written up to March 31st. only, and some of the totals and entries were in pencil and others in ink. Two Bank Accounts are kept, as previously reported - one a Current Trust A/c, and the other a Savings A/c, and transfers take place from one Account to the other as funds are depleted. The Principal sometimes draws a personal cheque on the Trust Account in error and then adjusts it by either paying cash or drawing another cheque, necessitating more book entries which inflates the "miscellaneous" column. Mr. Ross apparently dislikes doing the office work, does not file anything methodically or have any uniform system and cannot get anyone to help him or do it for him.

No statement had been prepared for the fiscal year, or sent the Department, so I compiled the attached statement from the cash book totals covering the year. The items may differ somewhat in their classifications, but the totals were balanced. A detailed audit would have taken several days.

Total Revenue appears to have been $17,757.74. The proceeds from Farm & Garden include large quantities of meat sold to Indians, and I understand some beef and pork was also traded for fuel wood, which accounts for the large supply on hand, and the heavy expense of $2,002.75 under "Expenditures" for "Fuel & Light". About 800 loads of wood were purchased and there is-

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.
and there is considerably more than a year's supply on hand at present. Clothing, tobacco, candies and confectionery are also sold to adult Indians and the children, and the revenue recorded.

The item of "collections & donations" includes collections at church services and concerts, and is disbursed under "miscellaneous" to the Church societies, which inflates that item under expense.

Under 'Expenditures', the salaries exceed half of the per capita grant, and the list of staff and salaries at present totals $6,540.00.

The clothing item is low, $704.92, as I believe most of the clothing is supplied by the Church authorities, but some, as above mentioned, is sold to Indians.

The "Farm & Garden" item is very high, $5,275.89, but includes a carload of feeder cattle purchased last year and wintered up to the present in the hope of selling at better prices and realizing a higher price for grain indirectly. However, if the original price were considered, together with cost of feed to date, and the present price of the cattle, it would appear as if a considerable loss will result.

This item also includes a grinder $400.00, (not all paid for), for crushing grain, a cultivator, truck expenses, hay and feed for cattle, the purchase of a bull, and pedigreed calves.

The Principal informed me that he had at present 80 head of cattle (more than the total pupilage), 13 horses, 34 pigs, and 50 poultry. About 200 bushels of potatoes were raised last year, but a poor garden crop and insufficient root vegetables for the School's requirements were grown.

Compared with the previous year the cost of operations is slightly less, and would have been considerably less if such large amounts of money had not been invested in cattle and other livestock, as well as wood. A certain amount of food from the Farm and Garden has, of course, been consumed by the children and staff, so this item would be greater if an estimate were made and added to the actual food cost.

Dear Mr. Scott:

Re Round Lake Residential School
Crooked Lake Agency

I am herewith forwarding a report of an examination of the books made at the above school by Mr. Rayner.

Under date of June 28th, 1930, I wrote you enclosing the Auditor's report for that year, and a reply was received, dated July 8th, from the Supt. of Indian Education, stating that the Department was writing the Principal concerned.

I was not advised the nature of that communication, but apparently not much notice has been taken of it, as you will see by the enclosed report that it was practically impossible for the Auditor to make a detailed check.

It appears none of the documents supporting the book entries, such as cheques and invoices etc., are filed in order so that they can be compared with the books. I do not know whether the Principal has made his annual report and submitted a statement to the Department or not, but there are certain matters in the administration of this school of which I do not approve or think proper.

You will note the last paragraph of Page 1 of the report, regarding the trading with Indians. I have been informed that the Principal has more than once requested the Agent to assist him in making his collections from the Indians. The matter of the Principal trading with Indians has been recently brought

Duncan C. Scott, Esq.,

Dept. of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA.

brought to the attention of the Department by me, and upon your instructions being received, they were repeated by letter to the Principal. Apparently these instructions have been disregarded - not a very satisfactory situation, I should say, and it appears to me that the Department will now have to take steps to stop this, in view of their instructions being disregarded.

On Page 2 of the report, it will be seen that there are over one hundred head of live stock at this school, including 90 head of cattle, some of which were purchased from the grant with the hope of selling at a profit.

Apart from using the per capita grant for the purchase of feeder stock, which could be regarded as speculation, I do not consider there should be more than a milking herd sufficient for the 75 pupils in attendance. It means that the Indian boys are working too hard looking after this stock, the feeding and herding of them, and also using the farm buildings, which would be overcrowded in the severe part of the winter.

I would be glad if the Department could see their way to request Mr. Ross to keep his books and documents so that they could be audited properly, and also point out to him the matter of trading with the Indians and venturing too much in the cattle business.

Yours very truly,

Sir:

I have the honour to submit herewith a report of an examination of the books at the above school, which I visited June 26th.

Over the past three years I had some difficulty in inducing Mr. Ross, the Principal, to keep the records in good shape, and have reported accordingly. Upon this visit I am pleased to report that a great improvement has taken place, practically all my suggestions having been carried out. The cash book is balanced monthly with the Bank Accounts, and a Bank Journal now used. Cheques for expenditures are written instead of cash paid, and they are numbered, and those numbers recorded in cash book. The statements and vouchers are attached to the cheque for which it is in payment, and these are filed for future reference, which was not done previously.

The Principal, Rev. K. J. Ross, now keeps his own personal funds and expenditures from being mixed with the School Trust Account, and states that by following the above methods he has been enabled to correct the Bank at times, and keep closer control over his expenditures.

The books were written up to date and found in good order, so a statement was prepared for the past fiscal year and is attached hereto. I have continued from the previous period which was submitted May, 1931.

Total receipts, £16,190.24 include £1800.00 received from the W.N.S. as grant for clothing, etc. Proceeds from the farm and garden, chiefly cattle sold, amounted to £1619.42; the per capita grant £1,461.86, and over £1200.00 from other sources as listed.

The expenditures total £14,726.31, compared with £18,632.47 for the previous year, reductions being noticeable in food, fuel and light, farm and garden, extra labour, and miscellaneous expenses.

Although the crop, both for grains and vegetables, was a complete failure, and much of these products had to be purchased, care has been taken in financing, and at the fiscal year end, £1462.92 was the unexpended balance on hand. Sufficient wheat had been retained from 1930 crop for the purposes of 1931, and this was gristed to flour for the school's consumption.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

COMMISSIONER'S OFFICE

REGINA, SASK., 3rd August, 1933

Re: Round Lake Residential School (United)
Crooked Lakes Agency

Dear Mr. Allen:

I submit herewith a report of an examination of the books at the above school which I visited July 29th, 1933.

I am pleased to report that a considerable improvement is evident in regard to the keeping of the records at this school compared to previous visits I have made. During the past three years I had some difficulty in inducing Mr. Ross, the Principal, to keep the records in good shape and have reported accordingly. The cash book is now balanced monthly with the two Bank accounts and a Bank Adjustment statement is recorded. Cheques for expenditures are written instead of being endorsed. Vouchers are made from the proceeds and these are all numbered and those numbers recorded in the cash book. The statements and vouchers are attached to cancelled cheques and these are filed for future reference, which was not done previously.

The Principal now recognizes the value of keeping his own funds and personal expenses from being mixed with the school Trust Account and states that by following the above methods he has been enabled to correct the Bank at times and keep closer control over his expenditures.

The books were written up to date and found in good order and a statement was prepared for the past fiscal year and is attached hereto. I have continued from the previous audit which was submitted June 25th, 1932.

Total receipts were $16,082.51, of which amount $11,367.40 was the per capita grant. A grant of $1,750.00 was received from the W.M.S. at Toronto and the proceeds from farm and garden and other items are as shown under the heading of "Receipts". Many of the items under "Expenditures" have been reduced compared to previous years, the total being $14,536.56 with a balance on hand as at March 31st last of $1,545.95. This amount agreed with the Cash Book figures for the month of March as shown on the Bank Adjustment Statement attached.

Two Bank accounts are kept for the purpose of earning a little interest from a Savings Account. As the current Trust Account is reduced, transfers are made from the Savings Account in order to meet current expenses. It will

- be noted that last -

be noted that last year $56.63 was obtained from Bank interest.

The "Cost of Operation" statement also shows proportionate reductions compared with the figures previously submitted. Salaries have been reduced by over $430.00 and the Principal informed me that he had been advised from his Headquarters in Toronto that, effective January 1st next, there would have to be a further reduction of 15% from the salaries of the Staff.

Under the item of "Farm and Garden" expenses $1,150.00 is included which was payment for farm lands purchased from the Canadian Pacific Railway. These payments were made in settlement throughout the year and it will be necessary to erect approximately six miles of new fence, for which the Principal will pay from the grant.

New seats have been installed in the Chapel at an expense of $162.60, which is included in the item of "Miscellaneous Expense". Also included in that same item is the sum of $435.00, remitted to the Church Authorities and which appears as a receipt under the heading of "Collections from Staff for Church funds", and part of the proceeds from the sale of candles etc.

Last year the crop returns included 1,400 bushels of wheat, 1,500 bushels of oats, approximately 40 tons of barley and green feed, and 250 bushels of potatoes, which quantity was insufficient for school requirements, so the necessary purchases increased the food item to some extent. However there were ample roots and vegetables obtained.

The livestock at present includes 80 head of cattle, 50 of which are pure bred and registered; 15 horses; 11 hogs; and about 50 poultry.

I questioned the necessity of having 80 head of cattle on hand, although perhaps it does not come within my jurisdiction to do so. However 80 head of cattle for a pupilage of 75 children appears to me excessive, as there is the necessity of furnishing ample feed for such a number and it entails extra work upon the older boys. The Principal informed me that a Holstein cow which he had and which had obtained first prize at the Yorkton fair had been valued by the Saskatchewan Livestock Commissioner at approximately $1,000.00. Mr. Ross was of the opinion that if he could obtain an offer of that sum at the Regina Exhibition, he would probably sell and the proceeds would be credited to the school funds.

Crop prospects at present are very good. All of the school lands are in or adjacent to the Qu'Appelle Valley and it is estimated that about 200 tons of green feed will be obtained this year compared to about 40 obtained last year.

Mr. Ross takes a very keen interest in the

- raising of pure bred -
raising of pure bred cattle and the school certainly has a reputation for raising very good herds.

Holstein Owned
By Indian School
Has Fine Record

Tuesday's judging at the World's Grain Show brought the grand champion award to the Cherrywood Prancy Colantha, 186290, Holstein female.

The cows won similar awards at Brandon, Portage and Yorkton this year.

Cherrywood Prancy Colantha was purchased from J. H. Haggard, who owns the herd at Round Lake Indian residential school at Shellbrook. She is the dairy branch fieldman of the Saskatchewan branch of the Canadian Dairy Council.

She had never been shown until taken to the show grounds here and was pronounced by the judge, Mr. Axe, to be the best cow in the show which would do credit to the province and bring the consideration of the Toronto show.

Operated by Church.

The Round Lake school is operated by the Women's Missionary Society of the Methodist Church of Canada, and a fine herd of 50 purebred Holstein cows has been kept up at this school during recent years.

The herd has been tested for milk and butterfat production and the school has completed two records in which the cows have been given certificates in butterfat production under the new regulations. To qualify for a black seal certificate, the minimum yield of butterfat is 400 pounds for a mature cow.

Mr. Haggard purchased Lakeview Lillian, 84445, the grand champion Ayrshire female, from Roland Ness of Trewinton, Alberta. He also bought two cows, Spice and Anderson, of Saltcoats No. 360, from Mr. Ness, resident of the Round Lake Indian school, near Shellbrook. These cows were not entered in the show but were purchased and delivered to their respective owners.

Dear Sir:

I submit herewith a report of an examination of the books at the above school covering a period of two years, dating from April 1st 1933 to March 31st 1935.

Accompanied by Mr. F. W. Holmes, I left the Inspector of Indian Agencies' office at Regina on the evening of the 16th inst., and arrived at the school Thursday morning the 16th, completing my examination on the afternoon of the 17th, returning to the Crooked Lake Agency to complete this report.

As there was but a small balance on hand at the end of the fiscal year ending March 31st 1935 very few transactions had been recorded in the Cash Book for April, and I therefore confined my examination to the period previously mentioned.

The Bank Pass Books for the Trust Account, and Savings Account, as well as all cheques paid by the Bank to March 31st last were on hand. The revenue as shown by the Dr. cash book entries was checked to deposits in the Bank.

The cancelled cheques were checked to the expenditure items in the cash book, and the items compared to accounts and vouchers which were attached to the cheques. I found many payments to local and wholesale grocery concerns were entered in the cash book under "Food" expense, but on examination of the accounts I found many of them contained items of clothing, house equipment, etc. Some time was spent in adjusting these entries, and correcting the monthly totals and yearly summary.

I explained these matters to the Principal Mr. Ross, and how such entries, if left as entered, would increase his food expenditures, and in the future he will examine the accounts more closely and summarize them before making his cash book entries. My instructions applied also to the Ashdown hardware accounts, which included items of expense relating to Farm, or House Equipment but which had been charged to Buildings and repairs.

Some confusion exists at the schools as to what items should be entered in the column Building and repairs. Some schools enter any repairs even those on Farm buildings, machinery or passenger auto in this column, and I would like to be advised on this point, and would suggest that the schools be given a circular in this connection. Also a few schools charge freight on coal to fuel expenses, on groceries to food, while others charge all such items to freight.

Bank Adjustment statements were prepared as at March 31st 1934 and March 31st 1935, the cash book balances agreeing with those shown on Statement 2, which is a comparative statement of Revenue and Expenditures for the two fiscal years.

Although the statement of Revenue would appear self explanatory, I might state that the proceeds from Farm & Garden $2,102.99 for the fiscal year 1934-35 includes $907.01 from the sale of wheat and other grain, $486.40 from sale of cattle & pigs, and $156.42 from

and $642 from sale of butter, milk and eggs. For the previous fiscal year the Farm and Garden Revenue of $657.45 included sale of grain $162.20, cattle and pigs $278.58, milk, butter and eggs $164.00. The latter sales were to a C.G.I.T. camp which locates near the school each summer, and at a time when most of the pupils are away on their vacation.

For the year 1933-34 revenue under the heading of Donations and Sundry refunds consists of $391.92 contributed by the school staff to Church Missions and the balance sundry refunds by the staff for purchases made on their behalf from school funds. The donations were remitted quarterly by cheque to the officer in charge of the Mission Fund for the United Church, such cheques being included in Expenditures under the heading Miscellaneous.

During the year 1934-35 the method of accounting for donations was changed, and instead of paying salaries in full and accepting their donations, deductions of such donations are now made at quarterly periods and only the net salary paid to the staff. A separate cheque is issued to the Mission Fund and charged to salaries. As a result the revenue under the heading Donations and Sundry refunds for 1934-35 consists of $91.16 collected from the staff before accounting procedure charged, $164.25 for sale of potatoes purchased for the school and later found to be surplus to requirements, $63.75 for refund of Provincial gasoline tax covering twelve months to March 31st 1934.

The Expenditure items are shown comparatively for the two years, and for the most part appear normal. The small clothing item of $405.26 is due to the school receiving a quantity of second hand clothing from the W.M.S. in 1935.

During the year 1933-34 the school had a quantity of fuel on hand, but from their own land, while in the year 1934-35 most of the fuel had to be purchased.

As to the Farm & Garden expense of $2,743.01 in 1933-34 the chief item contained therein was the purchase of a section of pasture and wood land for $1,200.00. Purchase of implements cost $109.00; hay and feed $287.00; purchase of and registering of cattle $238.10.

During the past fiscal year $1,643.75 was spent for feed and seed, as the crops last year were very poor, the school having to buy most of their hay and feed. Livestock purchases amounted to $415.30.

For the year 1933-34 extra was employed at the school, as the harvest crop that year was exceptionally heavy, but last fall the crops were very light. This accounts for the larger expense of $714.95 when compared to $75.20 spent in 1934-35.

The costs of operation statement 3 is based on an expenditure of $15,776.90 in the year 1933-34 and an average attendance of 76 pupils; the costs for 1934-35 on an expenditure of $16,880.56 and an average attendance of 75 pupils. Increases appear in the cost of clothing, the smaller expense in the former year was due to the donation of clothing as before mentioned.

On statement No. 3 is listed the members of the staff, their occupations and salaries as at May 1st 1935.

The Principal informed me that the livestock at the school consisted of 80 cows and calves; 19 horses; 15 pigs; and about 50 poultry.

The returns from last
The returns from last year's harvest were 500 bushels of wheat, and 40 loads of hay. No oats nor barley were obtained.

The potato crop was a failure, but fair quantities of other root vegetables were secured.

Dear Mr. Scott:
