Dear Mr. Scott:

The Round Lake Indian Residential School has, I understand, been under the management of the Woman's Missionary Society of the former Presbyterian Church.

The W.M.S. of the United Church, into which the various Women's Missionary Societies of the uniting churches have been merged, is pressing for a forty foot extension to the main building of the Round Lake School.

The statement submitted to me is to the effect that there are at least twenty children of school age on the reserve served by the school for which there is no accommodation in the present building. The proposed extension would provide more dormitory space and also more room in the dining room, and it is also desirable that there should be at least one more staff room for an engineer. The laundry could be enlarged by this extension and a proper sewing room provided. The kitchen could be placed in the basement of the new building and the present kitchen used as a store-room. It is also hoped that by this extension a small dispensary and a couple of rooms for sick children could be made available.

Trusting that an appropriation will be made in the near future for this extension,

I am,

Very faithfully yours,

Dear Mr. Graham:

I beg to submit the following report on the schools inspected by me in the Crooked Lake Agency.

ROUND LAKE INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL.

This school was inspected on January 28th, 1927. The class rooms were first inspected. Mrs. Ross, wife of the principal, teaches the senior room. She holds her Second Class, non-professional Ontario, no Normal training, and is about 35 years of age. The senior room is made up of grades 4 to 6, with an enrolment of 34. According to the register, the attendance is good. Mrs. Ross keeps splendid order, and her manner and methods of teaching are good. Grade 6 attends all day and I believe has done so for two or three years. In view of this, Mrs. Ross should be able to make a good showing of her work. I understand there are other children who also attend all day.

The junior class room is in charge of Mr. Smith, who does not hold a certificate. He is about 26 yrs. of age. The grades taught are from 1 to 3, with an enrolment of 35. The work in this room is only fair. Mr. Smith is not a good teacher; his style and methods are very poor. I feel that the junior room should have a teacher with good qualifications, who will get the children started right and only by so doing can the best results be obtained in the senior grades. This foundation work is very important. The children in both rooms.

both rooms were clean and tidy, and the class rooms were in first class shape.

The dormitories were clean and well aired. All the beds had white spreads and were neatly made. These rooms showed care and attention. In this school they have no room where the sick may be cared for; the dormitories in which the children sleep must also accommodate the sick. There was at the time of inspection one case of Pneumonia and several of Chickenpox, as well as those with the 'Flu. This is certainly very bad for the children and difficult for the lady in charge.

The dining room is rather small, and is a poor shaped room. The ceiling is very low. The children's tables have recently been covered with a linoleum, which is very easily cleaned and looks well.

The laundry is very small and cramped. On wash day it is necessary to hang the clothes in the dining room to dry as there is no room in the laundry. They have no clothes dryer at this school.

The kitchen is also small. It is in the basement and the ceiling being so low makes it very hot to work in. In addition to this inconvenience, it is overrun by cockroaches, and these have spread to the second floor. This building is old, and I doubt if these pests will ever be entirely exterminated.

I might mention here that the old wing on this school is in very poor condition, in fact, is beyond repair. The second floor is used as a store room, and I was surprised to find it very untidy and poorly kept. The Matron tried to excuse this on account of the recent sickness, but I fear it was purely a case of neglect and
neglect and poor management.

The new chicken house is very satisfactory and greatly appreciated. The barns are very poor and far from being adequate. A new barn is badly needed and it should be a good size, so as to accommodate all the cattle and horses needed to carry on the work of this school.

The Principal's residence is not in use. Mr. & Mrs. Ross live in the school. This appeared to me to be a very poor arrangement as it required him to have his office, bedroom, and living room all in the one small front office. It is nearly as crowded as some of the Indian homes. This is unnecessary and if Mr. Ross had a proper staff he would not be required to reside in the school.

Considerable repair work is needed to the plaster in the school room, girls' dormitory and girls' playroom. On all the ceilings patches have fallen off and no doubt considerably more will have to be removed before the patches can be satisfactorily repaired.

The following are the members of the staff:

- Mr. Ross - Principal
- Mrs. Runniger - Matron, about 50 yrs. old
- Mrs. A. Moss - Sewing Teacher, about 58 yrs. old
- Mrs. Hudson - Kitchen Matron, " 54 "
- Mrs. Best - Laundress, " 50 "
- Mrs. Ross - Sr. Teacher, " 35 "
- Mr. Smith - Jr. Teacher, " 26 "
- Mr. Ross - Farming Instructor" 59 "
- Mr. Barthu - Mechanic, a young Ruthenian.

I have already discussed the work of the school teachers. With regard to the other lady members of the staff, they appeared to carry on the work quite satisfactorily, although I feel that some of these women are really too old to handle such positions. The Farmer,

Mr. Ross.
Mr. Ross, knows farming, but is too old for the position. He appeared to fill the position of a "hired man" rather than Farming Instructor. A young man who can handle boys and who is alive to agricultural advancements is badly needed here. The mechanic is a young Ruthenian, not the type of man I would care to hire, although Mr. Ross claims he is a good worker and cheaper than Canadian labour. I do not think a few dollars should be considered in securing proper help for these institutions if we are to expect the best results.

The Principal, Mr. Ross, is a good worker and desirous of making a success. However, I believe he is only just realizing the big responsibility which has been his, and whether or not he will ever measure up to this responsibility, I am not prepared to say. I consider his methods are very far from the best, and until he is prepared to change them, the best results will not be obtained. He informed me that his resignation had been handed in to the church and that he was prepared to leave as soon as his position could be filled.

Dear Mr. Scott,

I beg to enclose herewith a report on the two Residential Schools in the Crooked Lake Agency, which were inspected by Mr. Inspector Hamilton during the latter part of January and the first week of February.

Round Lake School

The work in the Senior classroom at this school seems to be progressing favourably, but I agree with the Inspector that we should have a better qualified teacher for the Junior room.

It is pleasing to note that the dormitories were clean and well aired. It is regrettable, however, that there is not a separate room in which to nurse cases of sickness. This difficulty will be overcome when the new addition is built to the school. As you are aware, there is an item of $15,000.00 in the Estimates for this purpose.

A new barn is needed at this school, and this matter has been under consideration for some time now. There is a small item in the Estimates for repairs to the buildings, but not sufficient to do all that is necessary.

With regard to the staff, I cannot say that I agree with the Inspector that these people are too old to carry on the work successfully. The Inspector is of the opinion that the mechanic should be a Canadian, or British born. However, I do not know that we can interfere very much in a matter of this kind if a man does his work well.

Sir:

I am advised by Mr. J.P.B. Ostrander, Indian Agent at Broadview, that the play rooms at the Round Lake Residential School are unfit to be used in cold weather as they cannot be kept warm enough, even with full steam turned on, and consequently are useless when needed most. Two small steam radiators are provided in each of the two play rooms. He suggests that if these four were installed together in one room and two larger ones purchased for the other, there would then be sufficient heat. The school would do the work of installation if the Department would provide the radiators, and I have ascertained that the latter could be procured at a cost of approximately $100.00, plus carriage to Stockholm. I would recommend making the change suggested. I shall be glad if the Department will grant the necessary authority.

The Agent reports further in connection with this school that the old cattle barn could be serviceably converted into a hog pen at a cost of about $50.00 for material. As a hog pen would be useful and the cost would be small, I would recommend the incurring of the expenditure mentioned.

Your obedient servant,

W. M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

I am enclosing herewith a report on an inspection of the two Boarding Schools in the Crooked Lake Agency which was made by Mr. Inspector Hamilton during the latter part of January and the first week in February.

The first school reported on is the Cowessess Indian Residential School, which is under the auspices of the Roman Catholic Church and the Principalship of the Rev. Father Carrierie. With reference to the barn needing paint, I may point out that an amount has been asked for in the Estimates to have this work done and if the amount is authorized the work will be carried on during the coming summer. Regarding the Inspector's remarks concerning a henhouse and pigsty, an amount to provide for these buildings was placed in the Estimates, also for a root house. It seems to me, however, that it would not have taken much of an effort on the part of the principal and his staff to have a root house erected, as there are a great many Indians living right near the school. A good root house was built at File Hills by the Principal.

Mr. and Mrs. Ross giving up their room in the school, I would point out that the Department bought a splendid residence for Mr. Ross and this building has not been used since the purchase was made some years ago. This is a mistake and the Department should insist on his going over into his own house and making room in the school for the accommodation of pupils and staff.

You will notice that the entrance to the root cellar is from the dining-room and on the occasion of the Inspector's visit the roots were being picked over, and frozen and rotten ones gathered up, with the result that the building was permeated with a most offensive odour. This arrangement is most unsatisfactory and the Department should not allow it to continue.

You will note that there is no standpipe in this building to supply water in the event of fire, and this is a most unsatisfactory and dangerous situation. A standpipe should be put in at once and hose attached to same. The exits on to the fire escapes from the dormitories are most unsatisfactory. As the arrangement stands now it means that the children would have to go out of a window, slide down a portion of the roof and then reach over and catch hold of a pipe to come down. Doors should be cut down to the floor level, landings built outside and pipes running through the floors of these landings. It looks to me as though a larger and heavier style of pipe should be used for this purpose than that which is in use at the present time. The fire drill that was called for during the Inspector's visit was, as you will notice, unsatisfactory, and indicates that the children have not been getting the proper instructions along this line.

I do not think that the staff at this school are at all what they should be.

I note that the children are not dismissed in the afternoon for recess and that the work in the classroom is carried on until 5 p.m. If the classroom work is carried on from 1.30 to 5 p.m. this practise should be stopped at once. This is too long an interval and the children cannot stand the long confinement. I should be glad to know if you wish this to be changed. I am of the opinion that it must be a system they have adopted themselves without the knowledge of the Department.

Yours very truly,

ROUND LAKE INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL.

I inspected this school on February 1st, 1928.

I first visited the senior classroom where Mrs. Ross, the wife of the Principal, is in charge. In this room
ROUND LAKE INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL (Cont'd.)

this room the work of grades 4 to 8 is being carried on. Mrs. Ross is a splendid teacher and puts a great deal of effort in her work. I noticed that the children were not dismissed at recess and that the work of the classroom was carried on until 5 P.M. Whether this is wise or not I am rather doubtful, as very often the children are unable to stand so much classroom work. The room was well ventilated and clean. The children were all neat and tidy.

In the junior classroom, which is in charge of Mr. Heron, the work of grades 1 to 3 is carried on. These little children go to school all day, with the result that the work in this room is very heavy, even for a well qualified teacher as the roll calls for 51 pupils, 60 of whom were present on the day I inspected the school. I was informed by Agent Ostrander that little progress had been made and that the discipline was very poor, but that he had spoken to Mr. Heron as regards this. I must say that on the day I inspected the classroom, very little fault could be found with the discipline and Mr. Heron appeared to have the situation fairly well in hand. He is a well meaning young man, and if he had his normal training, I believe he would make an excellent teacher. However, the lack of this training is quite apparent in the manner in which he carries on the work.

As pointed out in previous reports, the room where the laundry work is carried on is very small and cramped. They have no dryer with which to dry the clothes, and the Principal informed me that to get the clothes dry, it was necessary to hang them in the dining room where the children and staff eat. On the days when this washing is hanging in the dining room, as it was on the day

I suggested to the Principal that more beds be put up, but he informed me that he had no more beds and that the dormitory would not accommodate six extra beds. In looking over the situation, I found that the dormitory would accommodate two extra beds and that if Mr. and Mrs. Ross gave up their room and moved over to the residence provided for them, there would be sufficient room to accommodate the other four beds and perhaps more. the school, so that ten beds are really needed. Mrs. Heron agreed with me that the room now occupied by Mr. and Mrs. Ross would be suitable to be used as a small girls' dormitory, and as it is just opposite her own room could be quite well looked after.

The room now used as a root cellar opens off the dining room. This is very unsatisfactory and unhealthy as all the odors from spoiled vegetables escape into the dining room. On the day of my inspection, this root cellar was being cleaned out and the potatoes sorted over. Apparently, when they picked the potatoes, frozen ones were also gathered, with the result that now a great many of them are rotten, and the work of picking them over was not only unpleasant for the ones carrying out the task, but also to the entire school as this disagreeable odor not only entered the dining room but passed out through the halls and permeated the whole building. In fact, I would not care to use the potatoes which were picked out from the bad ones as they were all wet and smeared by the decayed potatoes. A root cellar could easily be built outside the school as the ground slopes readily towards the lake, and a cellar could be dug in the bank. It would, however, cost something to cement the walls and put a roof over it.

FIRE PROTECTION.

This school, as is known to the Department, is a frame building. In view of this fact, I went carefully into the question of fire protection, and was certainly surprised to find that no water is obtainable, in case of fire, except from the small taps which supply the wash basins in the various bathrooms. I do not

Fire Protection (Cont'd.)

consider it would be a difficult matter to put a pipe from the boiler room up through the bathrooms, on each of the three floors, to which a fire hose could be attached. There is abundance of water by keeping the windmill pumping constantly, and the tank in the boiler room holds about 1,000 gals.

In the girls' dormitory there are two fire escapes, one on each side of the building. The exit from the dormitory on to the fire escape is by means of a window. On both these windows I found outside windows, and it would be necessary for the children to climb out over the window sill, which is perhaps 2 ft. off the floor. I think the one fire escape, properly fixed, on the side facing the classrooms, would be sufficient for this dormitory. It would allow the children to escape by this way if the fire were in the front of the building. Should it be in the rear of the building, the children could then escape by the front stairs. To make this fire escape convenient and satisfactory, the window sill should be cut out on a level with the floor and a door placed in the opening to open outwards on the fire balcony. The present balcony would need to be re-built as it is only about 2 ft. wide and this would not allow for the opening of the door. The pipe leading down from the balcony is too small being only 1½" pipe, and it already shows signs of bending as a result of the weight of the larger girls. This pipe should be at least 2". It would also be much easier for the children to slide down than the small pipe. The fire escape on the other side of the girls' dormitory might be left as it is at the present time, as it is also used by the boys who are on the floor above.

A door opens from their dormitory where again a light pipe of 1½" leads down on to the flat roof of the old school, which they cross and then slide down the fire escape which leads out from the window of the girls' dormitory. This gives the boys an opportunity to get out at the back in case the fire is in the front part of the building. They have also a way of escape through a window on the front of the building where there is another 1½" pipe which they can slide down on to the roof of the verandah across the front of the school. They must then go to one end of this verandah, climb over a 3 ft. railing, and slide down another 1½" pipe to the ground. There is no platform on which to stand, either at the top where they step out of the window or at the side of the verandah after they have climbed the railing. I consider this arrangement very dangerous, especially for the small children, and at the present time a large percentage of the children are very small. This window should also be cut down on a level with the floor, and a proper door built to open outwards on to the fire escape balcony. The railing should also be cut on the roof of the verandah. At the present time, it seems as if we are placing obstacles in the way of these children, rather than assisting them to escape, in case of a fire. In all cases, I consider the 1½" pipe too small, and feel that it should be replaced by a larger pipe.

Two new 5 gal. fire extinguishers have recently been supplied by the Department. They have a number of old fire extinguishers, all of which, I understand, have never been re-charged, and are now 10 or 12 years old. It is doubtful whether these old fire extinguishers would be

In going over the building, I found that the floors in both the girls' and boys' playrooms were worn through in places, and in fact, the entire floors needed to be renewed. Both the doors leading from these playrooms have been continually repaired until now they are past...

are past repairing and new doors are needed. The walls in the playrooms are plastered, with the result that considerable of the plaster is falling off. Plastered walls do not appear to be satisfactory for playrooms, and I would suggest that these walls be covered with V Joing or wallboard.

I found the new barn in good condition and well filled with stock. The other outbuildings were in good repair.

There was no sickness in the school at the time of my visit, and the children all appeared healthy and were certainly well clothed. I cannot help but feel that these children receive good attention and plenty of well prepared food.

Again, I was rather disappointed with the staff which the Principal has employed to carry on the work at this school. The Farmer, known both by the children and the staff as Louis, is a Ruthenian. He is a good mechanic, and to the ordinary farmer would be a first class labourer, but I do not consider him a Farming Instructor capable of instructing Indian boys in the best methods of farming.

Recently, the Principal secured from the Old Country a young Scotshman, about 20 years of age, to look after the stock, etc. I asked Mr. Ross if he considered this man suitable to instruct the boys in the care of stock, and he replied that in the Old Country this man was a miner, but he hoped to train him so that he would make a good stockman. It seems to me that what is needed at these schools is practical, experienced men who understand farming in this western country and also stock raising. Many of these Indian boys know more about this work.
this work than the men who are employed to instruct them.

The lady in charge of the laundry is the wife of Louis. She is a very nice woman, but is only now learning to speak English. I suppose it is quite possible to show girls how to do laundry work without telling them. However, I think it would be more satisfactory if the woman could speak English fluently so that the children might be instructed verbally, as well as being shown how to carry on the work.

The kitchen matron appears quite capable, and I believe serves the food in a better manner than any matron the Principal has yet been able to secure.

The work in the sewing room appeared to be carried on satisfactorily, although the sewing teacher apparently had very little time for instruction as she herself was busy mending and darned a great deal of the time, due to the fact that a number of the senior girls are kept in the classroom all day. However, I would say that these women are quite capable of carrying on the work over which they have charge.

Mrs. Heron, who is supposed to be acting as Matron, is a very capable woman, and I have no hesitation in saying that if she were given a free hand, as matron of the school, that the work would be carried on very satisfactorily.

Mr. Ross, the Principal, is, I believe, quite earnest in his endeavours to carry on the work successfully. He appeared to take a different attitude this time to suggestions made, and assured me that they would be carried out. I cannot help but feel that in the matter of hiring help, Mr. Ross is very often willing to try out inexperienced and unpractical men and women, if such
labour can be cheaply secured. My own feeling is that a poor officer in such an institution is really expensive at any price, and I believe Mr. Ross could carry on the work of this school with less officers if they were of a proper type and calibre.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

A. G. Hamilton,
Inspector of Indian Agencies.

Dear Mr. Graham:

I have your 304-11 of the 16th ultimo, with reference to Mr. Inspector Hamilton's report on the schools of the Crooked Lake Agency. I have written to the United Church authorities, asking them to take steps to provide a proper staff at the Round Lake Indian Residential School.

Please make arrangements to install a stand pipe in the Round Lake School, for fire protection, and arrange for more satisfactory exits to the fire escapes, as recommended in your letter and in the inspector's report. Rev. Mr. Ross should see that there are more regular fire drills. Four 5 gallon fire extinguishers are being ordered by the Department.

Instruct Mr. Ross that Mr. Hamilton's advice in connection with a dining room should be followed. The clothes should not be hung up in the dining room. You may purchase cement and heavy timbers for a root house at this school. Ask Mr. Ross to be responsible for the labour. This last mentioned improvement should be effected as soon as weather conditions permit.

You may supply two doors leading from the playrooms, and, if you consider the walls in this part of the building require repainting, you might let me have an estimate of the cost. Instruct Mr. Ross that classroom exercises should not last until 5 o'clock in the evening. 1:30 to 4 o'clock is the recognized period, with a 15 minute recess.

I am hopeful that, with a proper staff, Mr. Ross will be able to move into the MacLay residence, and this will permit of increased dormitory accommodation, which evidently is needed.

Yours very truly,

Duncan C. Scott

Sir:

I beg to report that a fire started on Sunday last, in the floor of the staff bath-room at the Round Lake School, but by prompt work with the fire extinguishers, the fire was put out with very little damage being done.

I investigated the matter yesterday, and there seems to be no doubt that the fire started by an overheated chimney. The chimney is in good shape and there is no hole in it from which flame could come. Where the floor boards touch the chimney they were all charred and axes had to be used to chop the floor away in order to stop the fire. If this fire had started at night, it is obvious that the result might have been much more serious. The day in question was very cold and the fire in the furnace had been kept going briskly all day. The fire was found about 4.00 o'clock in the afternoon, and apparently the chimney had been getting hotter from the time the first fire was put on in the morning. When I was investigating the matter yesterday, I found that the chimney was so hot that I could not keep my hand on it for any length of time and Mr. Ross informs me that, when the fire started the chimney was much hotter than it was yesterday.

The chimney in question is the ordinary brick chimney and I do not suppose the furnace carried any more heat than any other furnace in similar circumstances, therefore it would seem that the ordinary single ply brick chimney is not safe with this type of furnace unless the woodwork close to it is protected in some manner.

Your obedient servant,

(Sgd) J.P.B. Ostrander,
Indian Agent.

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.
Sir:

I would ask you to sanction the necessary expenditure in having the flooring repaired in such a manner as to obviate the possibility of recurrence of fire from an overheated chimney.

I beg to inform you that the 6 h.p. gasoline engine that was installed at the Round Lake Indian Residential School in 1924 is reported to be in bad shape, in fact beyond repair. The jacket was cracked, and the mechanic who went down there to overhaul the engine states that the block is so badly worn it would be a waste of money to repair the engine without getting a new block.

The reason advanced for the short life of this engine is that it was always overworked. The Agent states he visited the school for the purpose of seeing for himself if it could not be used for a time. While he was there it was started and ran for a time, when a bolt came out of a connecting-rod bearing, with the result that the piston was broken and the connecting-rod bent.

A new engine will have to be supplied, and I may say there is no doubt in my mind that this machinery has been in incompetent hands, and, as has been the case at many other places, the Department is called upon to pay for this inefficiency. The children of this room have been unfortunate during the past few years in having several changes in teachers, consequently progress has been slow.

Previous to Miss Stromgrem, Miss Afflick was in charge for a couple of months and made excellent progress, so the children got away to a good start. I am pleased to say Miss Stromgrem, who has taken over the work from which Miss Afflick was discharged, is doing splendid work, and I would expect the junior grades to show marked advancement under her supervision. The children were clean and neatly dressed.

The classrooms need to be kalsomined and painted. At present the walls are very dark and the room has a gloomy appearance. The floors have never been oiled and when swept the dust is very bad. The outside of this building needs to be re-painted.

The girl's dormitory was bright, clean and well aired. I would again point out that it is overcrowded, and I found that in several cases two girls were obliged to sleep in a single bed. The dormitory will not accommodate any further space for beds.

The boys' dormitory was also well aired, clean and all beds nicely made.

The work in the sewing room, laundry and kitchen is all carried on under supervision, and the work is well done.

Fire drill is observed, and the children are familiar with their duties in respect to it. A small fire occurred in the girls' washroom a few days ago, but was located in time. I found that the fire extinguisher used was still unfilled and drew the Principal's attention to it.
to it. I would again mention that I found no water pressure throughout the building, but Mr. Ross explained that the boy who attended to the matter was away hauling hay. It is strange that my visits should happen on days when the pressure is off. I am inclined to believe it is off most of the time and this is a serious matter. The Reverend Principal purchased a 3 H.P. engine after the other one became useless, but I doubt if it is large enough. The old engine was a 5 H.P. one, and I continually had complaints that it was too small. Again I would point out the weak condition of the belts used. These are worn out and should be replaced as they are bound to give way just at a time when most needed.

The dining room is again in use as a drying room. Lines are fastened to the ceiling and the clothes hung above the children's tables. The place had the smell of a laundry rather than a dining room.

The floor in the boys' and girls' playroom is badly worn and in places is almost through. I doubt if this floor can be made to last for another year.

The Mackay house is still empty and Mr. & Mrs. Ross reside in the school. The office used as their apartment was in a more tidy condition than when I last inspected the place.

The barns and outbuildings I found to be clean and tidy.

The new Farming Instructor, Mr. A. Young, is a man 50 yrs. of age, and I believe is a good worker and understands farming. He is a man who will be respected and should have no difficulty in handling the boys.

The laundry
ROUND LAKE INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL (CONT'D.)

The laundry matron, Miss North, is a good officer and her work is satisfactory.

The sewing matron is Mrs. Friedlien, but I understand her appointment is only temporary as she lives near the school and must return home before spring opens up.

The kitchen matron, Miss H. Reider, was to arrive March 1st from Winnipeg. I have known Miss Reider for some years, and as she has had previous experience in this line of work, I would expect her to do good work.

Mrs. A. Young, the Farming Instructor's wife, is acting matron. She is perhaps physically fit to do the work, but she certainly does not assert herself as matron of an institution.

In closing, I wish to point out the marked improvement in the physical condition of the children. I was delighted to see the boys and girls in such splendid health, and I have no doubt they receive sufficient wholesome food. The meals served while I was at the school were nicely prepared and there appeared ample for all.

Sir:-

A few days ago I received a letter from the Agent in charge at Broadview, stating that the front sill of the Principal's residence at the Round Lake School had rotted away. He intimated that it would not be possible to determine what the cost of remedying this condition would be until the actual repair work was set in motion. I wrote him in reply, asking whether the Principal was occupying the residence, and have received an answer to say that he is, but, instead of expending money on repairing the foundation, makes the extravagant request to have the building moved one hundred feet nearer the main building. This, in my opinion, is altogether an unnecessary expenditure. It would make no material difference in case of fire, the possibility of which Mr. Ross is continually harping on as his reason for wishing to spend the night in the main building. As the Agent points out, this would entail the expenditure of a great deal more money than is desirable or necessary. In the first place a new foundation would have to be built at a cost of about $300.00; the moving of it based on the figures of a man who was questioned would be $400.00; and, owing to the condition of the plaster, it would probably be ruined during the process of moving and entail a further expenditure of $200.00 to replace it. Thus, this thoughtless whim of the Principal would involve a sum of about $900.00, and I do not purpose to recommend the suggested moving of the building.

Between $100.00 and $200.00 might have to be expended in repairs to the sill, and, if the Department will authorize a more closer investigation to determine what may be necessary and the expenditure of the amount mentioned, I will have the work proceeded with.

Inspector Murison's Report on Schools in the Crooked Lake Agency.

Dear Mr. Graham:

I beg to submit the following report on the Round Lake Indian Residential School in the Crooked Lake Agency, which I inspected on November 7th. This school is under the auspices of the United Church, with the Rev. R. J. Ross as Principal, N. Sinclair, Engineer; H. Gingrich, Farmer; A. Young, Gardener & Fireman; Mrs. Young, Matron; Miss Eva Scoggan, Cook; Miss Jessie Cameron, Seamstress; Miss Mabel McLeod, Laundress; Mrs. Ross, Senior Teacher; Miss Gertie Stromgren, Junior Teacher.

The school building was found clean throughout the interior, and the outside premises tidier than I have ever found them. This school building has been described so often that the Department are quite familiar with it. The new part of the building was erected some eleven or twelve years ago, a portion of the old school being retained. This older portion is of very little use except for storage purposes, being very hard to heat during the winter months. I consider it a menace to the safety of the school. It looks to me like a regular fire trap. I am of the opinion that it should be torn down and replaced. The newer portion of the school, as you know, was badly planned in the first place, and although it was remodeled and greatly improved, it compares badly with other Indian residential schools.

W.M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.

schools with regard to accommodation, comfort and safety from fire.

The pole fire escapes have been improved by providing larger poles. There is easy access to these escapes from the dormitories, but I suggested to the Principal that a measure of safety might be added by providing a small platform outside the exit on the top floor. Hose pipes connected to the water system are provided on each floor, as well as fire extinguishers. The pupils, I am informed, are given regular weekly fire drill. Water storage is provided by two pressure tanks, one of 1,000 gal., and the other 500 gal. capacity. The water supply is obtained from the lake, and a windmill, as well as a gasoline engine, is provided to operate the pump. The water is pumped into a cistern situated in the basement of the school and from there to the pressure tanks by a separate motor. This plant was in good condition and working satisfactorily at the time of my visit.

The school is lighted by electricity, and I believe Mr. Sinclair, the engineer, is a good man for the job.

The exterior of the building has not been re-painted for some time and has a rather dingy looking appearance.

I noted that the floor in the girls' bathroom is broken and should be repaired. The toilets in this bathroom are also in a broken condition and require to be repaired.

The dormitories
The dormitories I found clean and well aired. The boys' dormitory is on the top floor. It contains 31 beds; there are 27 boys in residence, so this dormitory provides ample space for them. The girls' dormitory is on the second floor; there are 46 girls enrolled, and only 41 beds provided. This means that 6 of the smaller girls have to double up with others, which is not a desirable condition. The dormitory has an over-crowded appearance. I examined the mattresses on the beds, and find that at least half of them are in bad shape and should be renewed. These mattresses have been in use for several years.

I noted that some improvements had been made to the laundry since my last visit, but this room is rather small for its purpose. Improvements have been made in recent years to the outbuildings; a good barn, implement shed, as well as an ice house, have been provided. The hen house is very small and is intended to provide accommodation for 60 hens. This is not sufficient for the number of poultry which should be kept at an institution of this kind. The old stone stable is now used as a hog house, and the old horse stable is used for housing loose stock. The superstructure of this old building is in poor condition, and is far from being an ornament to any institution of this kind. The stone work is not in good shape, and I think the whole building would be better torn down and a less unsightly building provided.

The classroom accommodation is provided in a separate building. This building provides two large.
ROUND LAKE INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL (CONT'D.)

large, well aired classrooms, which are well suited for their purpose. These rooms were being re-decorated at the time of my visit. I visited both these classrooms, and both Mrs. Ross and Miss Strongren impressed me as being capable teachers.

A separate residence is provided for the Principal, and is now being occupied by him and his wife. This building is in good condition, with the exception of about 12 ft. of the foundation under the west wall. The sill has rotted, with the result that the wall has sunk some. I am of the opinion that this condition has been caused through faulty workmanship in connection with the window at that end of the building. It is evident that water has leaked from this window down the inside wall, thus rotting the foundation sill. When repairing the foundation, I am of the opinion that it will be necessary to have this window properly re-set. With the exception of this portion, the sills under the rest of the house are in a perfectly sound condition.

FARM

The farm produced this year 1,500 bus. of wheat. In addition, they had 45 acres of barley and 30 acres of oats, which was a fair crop. This grain was not threshed, but is being chopped in the sheaf and used for feed for the stock. This work is done by a large Letz grinder. This is the first occasion I have seen this class of grinder in operation, and it does very satisfactory work. The straw is chopped and the grain in the heads is ground and all well mixed and blown into the
ROUND LAKE INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL (CONT'D.)

into the hay loft. All hay fed to the stock is also cut with this machine, and there is no doubt but that its use conserves feed and the stock obtain more benefit from feed treated in this way.

The herd now comprises 30 pure bred Holsteins of good quality. These consist of 13 cows, 3 heifers, 1 bull, and 13 calves. They have, in addition, 13 head of grade cattle. There were 12 cows being milked at the time of my visit. These provide ample milk for their requirements. They have 9 hogs and 11 horses. Their garden produced sufficient roots and vegetables for the requirements of the school.

This school appears to find favour with the Indians, and I am informed that applications for admission have to be refused owing to lack of accommodation. There are 73 enrolled at the present time, and the Principal informs me that he would have no difficulty in securing 120 pupils if the necessary accommodation was provided for that number.

I was present at the mid-day meal, and it was noted that the meal supplied to the children was ample and comprised wholesome food. The children presented a healthy appearance, and I am informed that they have had very little sickness in the school.

In concluding this report, I may say that I found conditions at this school more satisfactory, in a general way, than I found them on any former occasion.

ROUND LAKE INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL (UNITED CHURCH)

I visited this school on March 18th, and made a general inspection of the buildings and classrooms. There were 74 pupils in residence out of an enrolment of 76. I was pleased with the appearance of the children; they are bright and healthy looking. I was present when they were having their mid-day meal, which comprised ample and wholesome food, including all the milk they cared to drink. I remember stating in a report on this school some years ago that the children were shy, listless, and backward in appearance, and not answering when spoken to. This condition no longer exists; the children appear natural and bright in their attitude towards visitors. The Principal's wife, Mrs. Ross, who is also the senior teacher, appears to have a great deal of natural ability for training children and forming their character. As time has gone on, I note that the general conditions at this school show improvement.

The girls receive instruction in sewing, mending, cooking, milking cows, and general domestic work. The boys assist in the care of the stock and the general farm work, under the supervision of a Farming Instructor.

A feature
ROUND LAKE INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL (UNITED CHURCH) CONT'D.

A feature at this school is the care of the stock. All feed, including hay and sheaves, is passed through a chopper, and it is evident, from the appearance of the stock, that they derive more benefit from chopped feed than from the coarse hay and sheaves. Twenty-three steers are being grain fed for the market, and are in fine condition. This is an object lesson for the boys, and the Indians on the adjacent reserves have taken a great deal of interest in watching this method of preparing the cattle for the market, which is new to them. Several mentioned the matter to me when I was visiting at the homes.

I found the school building clean and tidy throughout. The engineer, Mr. Sinclair, keeps the equipment in good working order.

With reference to the fire escapes, there are two exits from the boys' dormitory, one at the north and one at the south end of the main building; the exit at the south end is a pole escape, a short drop to the flat roof of the verandah, and a second pole escape situated at the east end of the verandah to the ground with a 16 ft. drop. At the west end of the building there is a pole escape with a short drop from the dormitory to a platform between the old and new portions of the building; a second pole escape, about 16 ft. in length, takes them to the ground. I am of the opinion that, as these escapes are easy of access, they will meet the situation.

The girls' dormitory is provided with two fire escapes, one at the north east corner of their dormitory, with access to it through a window; there is a 16 ft. drop.
ROUND LAKE INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL (UNITED CHURCH) CONT'D.

a 16 ft. drop to the ground and a good pole escape. A second fire escape, with access from a window at the west side, with a 16 ft. drop to the ground, provides an exit at that side of the building. The pole on this escape is a 1½" pipe, which is rather small; a 2" pipe would be more satisfactory. The Agent found fault with the position of these escapes, his view being that two of the poles are situated at the east side of the building, and as the prevailing winds are from the north west, he thought that should a fire occur with the wind in that direction, the two east escapes might be cut off. It would be an easy matter to move the pole from the east side of the verandah, at the front of the building, to the west side. I cannot see that it is necessary to add any more poles than what we have at the present time, other than replacing the west pole escape from the girls' dormitory with a larger size pipe.

I reported quite fully on this school at the end of last November, and may say that conditions have not changed to any extent since that time.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Sir:

I am in receipt of a letter from the Indian Agent at Broadview, advising me that the well at the Round Lake Residential School now fails to supply water for requirements. It was sunk on the shore of the lake and the water level being very low, there is consequently no seepage into the well notwithstanding that recently it was dug a foot deeper and the pump line lowered about nine inches. Quick sand has filled the bottom of the well and as this is drawn into the cylinder of the pump it wears out the pump leather. Some steps must be taken to secure an adequate water supply, as at present there is not sufficient in the storage tank for fire protection. The Agent on a former occasion drew attention to a spring in the hill on the opposite side of the lake, and now draws attention to it again as a surer source of supply, pointing out also that it is situated high enough up the hill to enable the water to be piped to the school by gravity. This would be an expensive undertaking as it is three quarters of a mile distant. If this supply were tapped, it would be necessary to build a reservoir at the spring and cover it tightly to keep out contamination. In his earlier letter, the Agent suggests that the cost would be probably $2,500.00. I do not know whether this is a careful estimate, but the suggestion should be given consideration, as many wells have been sunk in the vicinity of the school without securing a permanent supply, and in the long run the expenditure of this sum might prove less costly.

I shall be glad to have the views of the Department on the subject and instructions to take the necessary steps to furnish an adequate water supply for this school. Prompt action should be taken.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Mr. Graham:

I beg to submit the following report on the schools of the Crooked Lake Agency, inspected between January 11th and 26th, 1932.

ROUND LAKE INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL,

The Senior room is in charge of Mrs. Ross, and the grade range from 4 to 8. The roll calls for 35, and the register shows good attendance.

The children are bright, responsive and appear well along in their respective grades. They were well dressed and neat in personal appearance.

Miss Stromgren is in charge of the junior room with 34 enrolled. The grades range from 1 to 3, and I found the children bright and attentive. Miss Stromgren is a qualified teacher, and her manner and personality quickly win the confidence of the little ones. The classroom was well aired, tidy and clean.

The girls' dormitory is bright and the windows are so arranged that plenty of fresh air is at all times available. The beds were all neatly made, and the bedding clean. The girls are provided with night gowns. This dormitory, as pointed out in a previous report, is overcrowded.

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
REGINA — Sask.
crowded, and in five beds two sleep in a bed. The beds are all single and consequently this arrangement is very unsatisfactory. At present there are 46 girls housed in the dormitory.

The boys sleep on the top floor, and as there are only 30 in attendance they have plenty of room. The beds were neatly made and the bedding clean.

Both dormitories I found to be tidy and exceedingly clean. No doors leading to the fire escapes are locked.

The kitchen is now in charge of Miss North who is rendering excellent service. The meals are well cooked, tasty and nicely served. Miss North has a good manner with the girls, and her department, although one of the hardest, is well managed.

The meals served are as follows:

**Breakfast** - Porridge every day except Sunday.

**Sunday** - Corn-flakes or puffed rice; brown and white bread, butter and milk.

**Dinner** - Potatoes, meat or fish, bread, desert varies - puddings, stewed fruits, Sunday - Pie or tart; milk always.

**Supper** - varies - Baked beans, fried or baked potatoes, macaroni and tomatoes or cheese. Soup is sometimes served; also cold meats and eggs. Stewed fruit is served. Cake four times a week, raisin buns twice, and cookies once. Jelly is served on Sunday. Bread & butter and milk always.

The girls are taught bread making; also butter making.

Miss McLeod is matron in charge of the laundry. At the time of my visit she was on leave due to sickness. The laundry is small, badly cramped and is poorly ventilated. In cold weather the drying of the clothes is a big problem as no drying room is provided, which necessitates hanging the clothes in the...
clothes in the children's dining room, and in a vacant room in the old building.

The sewing room is supervised by Miss Donnelly, and is in the old building. The place is cold and drafty, necessitating a box stove to be used in order to keep it fit to work in. The old building is in poor shape and the plaster is ready to fall from the ceiling in several places. An attempt to take any of it down would perhaps result in most of the ceiling plaster falling, so that up to the present nothing has been done. This old wing is past repairing and as it now exists is a real fire trap.

The playrooms were clean and tidy, but the floors are practically worn through and very rough. New floors are needed.

The building throughout was in the best condition I have been privileged to see it, and I believe this is largely due to the close supervision of the matron, Mrs. Therien. She has only been at the school a few months, but appears to have the work well in hand and she is respected both by the staff and children.

The plumbing throughout the school was in working order and the boiler room clean. Mr. Sinclair, who is in charge of this work appears to be a fair mechanic and I believe is rendering good service.

Fire drill is observed regularly and the children get out in less than two minutes. Extinguishers are placed in prominent places throughout the building and the fire hose are in good repair. The fire escape on the front of the boys' dormitory leads out over a sloping ledge of the roof, which in a rush might easily be the cause of an accident. A small platform on which the boys could step out would improve conditions, especially in case of the small children.

The water supply
The water supply would be of little help should a fire occur. At present by careful management a fair pressure is maintained, but I understand that before the Christmas holidays even this could not be accomplished. Should the lake return to its normal level the difficulty would be overcome, but if the dry seasons continue it might be necessary to extend the intake further into the lake.

These children all go home for Christmas holidays and I found that several were late returning; some a day, others three or four days. This holiday breaks in on the year's work, entails a thorough cleaning of the children on their return and often is the cause of sickness. The Principal stated he would willingly give Christmas dinner to all the parents rather than dismiss the children. A number of the parents at the Assiniboine Agency stated they did not wish the children to come home, but when some came it was hard to refuse the others. Since the holidays two or three run-aways have occurred, the only apparent cause being that the children were homesick after the holiday.

The cattle I found in good condition. These cattle are all tested for T.B. and are free of the disease. The school appears to have plenty of milk, and it is served at all the meals. The barns and outbuildings were tidy. The girls as well as the boys are taught milking.

The root cellar was completed last fall and should serve splendidly in the keeping of vegetables. It is dug out of the bank, lined with lumber, and covered by poles, straw and earth. The front is well protected and double doors are used at the entrance. A carload of potatoes were shipped in by the Principal and were in good condition.

The poultry house is now in use. Mr. Ross has secured some very fine Barred Rock birds and has now a good start for next
start for next year.

Hay is purchased from the Indians and it is hauled down a very steep hill to the valley where the school is situated. Mr. Ross has been warned not to allow the boys to drive loads of hay down this hill as the road is narrow and upsetting might mean a drop of anything from 40 to 100 feet. In spite of this the Indians complain that it still goes on, and that the boys are allowed to ride down. I instructed Mr. Ross that he should not allow the boys to drive down or even ride on the load.

Mr. and Mrs. Ross now reside in the residence supplied, and Mrs. Therien apparently assumes the duties of matron.

At present this school has one pupil over the allotted number, making 76, and I learned that 18 of these pupils are from the Assiniboine Agency. In visiting the Indian homes on the Crooked Lake Agency I found that a number of children of school age are not in residence. The parents claim there is no room and are unwilling to send them to any other school. The Assiniboine Agency children might be accommodated in another United Church school in September, thus allowing plenty of room at Round Lake for all of the Crooked Lake pupils; This would be placing no hardship either on the parents or children, as already they are away from their parents.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 20th instant, with reference to continuing the services of the night watchman at the Round Lake Indian Residential School.

In reply I have to say that, in view of your report as to the need of a watchman's services throughout the entire year, the Department will approve of continuing the grant allowed the school towards salary for continuous services. You may therefore advise the Reverend Principal accordingly and he should arrange with the watchman to carry on duties continuously throughout the year. You should submit vouchers, in favour of the new Principal, for the amount of the grant at the end of each quarter in the same manner as you have done in the past.

Dear Sir:

When Mr. J.D. Sutherland visited the Round Lake Residential School recently his attention was drawn to the condition of the floors in the two playrooms and he requested me to obtain prices on the different kinds of flooring for consideration by the Department. Below I have given the total floor area to be covered and the approximate cost of the different kinds of flooring:

1500 feet to be covered, this will require the following quantities:

3 in. e.g. fir flooring, No. 1 quality, 2000 ft. $120.00
13/16 X 1 1/4 in. maple flooring, No. 1 quality, 2144 ft. — 275.00
13/16 X 1 1/4 in. plain oak flooring, No. 1 quality, 2144 ft. — 395.00

While hardwood flooring would no doubt make a much better job and would wear longer, I do not know that the extra cost as compared with fir flooring is justified. I have no doubt that fir flooring, if well laid, would last nearly ten years and the building in which the flooring is to be laid will certainly not last 20 years, therefore it would seem that it would not be wise to spend the extra money required for hardwood.

The above prices are for material only, the school authorities could take care of the labour of laying the floor.

Regarding beaver board for the walls of these rooms, I would say that the cost would be approximately $40.00 to cover the walls all the way around to a height of 4 feet. Material for cupboards in these rooms would cost approximately $50.00. Therefore the total cost of material for floors, walls and cupboards would be approximately $220.00, using fir flooring, or $375.00 using maple flooring.

Your obedient servant,

Sir:

With reference to your letter 108-1-5 of the 13th inst., in connection with request for a new engine for the Round Lake Indian Residential School I am enclosing herewith sketches showing the location of the equipment to be driven by the gasoline engine.

It will be noted that the machinery is all operated from one shaft including pulleys and belts. I do not think that it will be practical to operate this machinery with two engines chiefly because there is very little room in either the engine room or the laundry for any additional equipment but also because the cost of two small engines and fuel to operate would be greater to operate than that of one engine of somewhat larger capacity.

One 6 H.P. engine will operate the machinery at full if used at full capacity which consists of a Fairbanks Morse self oiling typhoon pump with a capacity of 2500 gallons per hour and 100 lbs pressure, a generator shunt wound Fairbanks Morse L.H. Type 1½ kilowatt 42 volts and a washer Globe-Wood 36" x 48" no partition single geared, end movement, but a drier is needed during the cold weather the clothes are dried in the children's playroom, which is far from satisfactory. This would add considerable strain of operation at the same time.

The engine now in use, as well as the pump, were purchased out of school funds and at the time the engine was purchased it was only a temporary measure through a break-down on the old engine - a 6 H.P. -

As stated in my previous letter the life on an engine is shortened by being worked at full capacity and this fact together with the need of further laundry equipment would suggest the desirability of procuring an engine of greater horse power than 6 if possible at the present time.

However, as the Department desires to keep the cost as low as possible a 6 H.P. engine will do the work. I may say that the 6 H.P. Lister Engine at the Cowessess I. R. School has given very satisfactory service as its horse power does not seem to be over-rated.

Your obedient servant,

J. P. B. Ostrander

INSPECTOR'S OFFICE,
W. REGINA, SASK., 30th October, 1934.

Sir:

I am in receipt of a letter from Indian Agent Ostrander concerning the question of the water supply at the Round Lake Indian Residential School.

As you are no doubt aware, an adequate supply of suitable water has always been a matter of difficulty at this school. The present supply is being obtained from the lake. There is a spring north of the school. A sample of the water from this spring had been submitted for analysis and the report is that it is very satisfactory to use for drinking purposes. The Reverend Principal, Mr. H. J. Ross, is anxious to have this water piped to the school.

The distance from the spring to the school is 3600 feet. It would require that number of feet of 2" pipe which costs 35¢ per foot, and the other necessary pipe, elbows, unions etc., would amount to approximately $50.00. Mr. Ross states that the school would arrange performance of any work which could be done with the tractor or team, but the digging and laying of the pipe would entail a great deal of work. It is estimated that the whole project could be completed for about $2,000.00.

If the pipe were laid at a sufficient depth to safeguard it from frost, the project if carried out should solve the question of a water supply for some years and should not necessitate much outlay for up-keep as the spring is considerably higher than the school and I think there would be sufficient pressure by natural gravity to insure that no pumping machinery would be necessary.

As the question has been brought to my attention, I am submitting same to you for consideration.

Your obedient servant,

W. Murison,
Inspector,
Saskatchewan Inspectorate.

Iron Frames

The entire weight of cylinder and tub shall rest on heavy cast-iron frames of neat design, to which driving mechanism shall be attached. Frames shall be clamped to tub by through tie bolts. Trunnions and Bearings

The cast-iron trunnions shall be of large diameter with journals supported on long cast-iron bearing boxes mounted on the frames. Shall consist of three pulleys operating in conjunction with two belts and a worm and cam movement producing a fixed number of reverse revolutions of the cylinder. Sir:— I have to report that the Principal of Round Lake I.R. School reported to me that the washing machine at his school is completely worn out and unfit for further use and requested me to wire the Department for authority to purchase a new one.

I visited the school and found that the machine was in a very poor condition and not fit for further use. I however had the same patched up to do temporarily. The wood in this machine has rotted out and as a result it is almost impossible to get screws or bolts in that will hold it together.

I have taken up with Mr. Foster of Whitewood who has recently done some repairs at that school and he has forwarded to me a cutting of a washing machine which I am enclosing and his letter states as follows:—

"Please find enclosed a cut of the Canadian Acme Washer which we believe is what you want as it seems much like the old one which we have at the School at the present time.

We understand that these machines sell at $825.00 F.O.B. factory but there are none in Winnipeg at the present time but we have been fortunate in locating a repossessed machine which has only been out one year and is guaranteed which we would like to instal in working order for $525.00 which will save you approximately $300.00.

Some of the companies which we received information from advised us that two ordinary electric washers would serve your purpose.

If I could consider this machine it would be possible to make arrangements so that the Indian Agent in Winnipeg could inspect this machine before anything definite was done."

Signed W. G. Foster.

If it is impossible to pay for a new machine before the end of the fiscal year I would be glad to have authority to purchase same immediately after April 1st when I think that arrangements could be made with Mr. Foster to get the machine shown in this cutting installed before that time in case the old machine which has been patched up fails and one is needed urgently. Personally I do not feel inclined to recommend a second hand machine. It may be that the Department could purchase this in the East cheaper than we can get quotations here and in that event I presume arrangements could be made with Mr. Foster to instal it.

Your obedient servant,

J. P. B. Ostrander
Indian Agent.

The 48 inch Super Simplex is a fully automatic Ironer designed for wherever a considerable amount of ironing has to be done at maximum speed and minimum operating cost.

A slight pressure anywhere along the edge of the feed board actuates the automatic mechanism which quickly applies or releases pressure of the shoe against the roll. The operator is comfortably seated while ironing, avoiding fatigue and substantially increasing production. The two open ends of the roll make it possible to iron any kind of apparel, underwear, lingerie, house dresses - in fact anything, even pieces for which the hand iron has been considered indispensable until now.

The construction is exceedingly sturdy, insuring steady operation without breakdowns. The heavy end frames, firmly bolted to the shoe, form a rigid framework. The roll of heavy gauge metal is thickly padded to assure uniform ironing throughout its length. The automatic pressure mechanism is particularly rugged and dependable. An auxiliary foot-operated pressure release makes it possible to instantly drop the shoe away from the roll even in the event of electrical failure, line disturbance or blown fuse.

With the exception of the motor, the 48 inch Super Simplex requires oiling only at infrequent intervals - from two to four months, depending upon its use. A ½ HP, constant duty motor is connected to the driving mechanism by an endless belt; mounted on sliding rails it is easily adjusted at any time to maintain correct tension.

Dear Doctor McGill:

Our Commission which is making a survey of Indian Education, has reached Calgary, and I am taking advantage of Mr. Christianson's kindness to send you a note.

When we got to Round Lake we discovered that the grant for Nightwatchman had been cancelled for the five summer months; I would like to point out that in my opinion this is a very serious mistake. The United Church has two schools which require a Nightwatchman the year round — Norway House and Round Lake. We have had four incipient fires at Round Lake and three at Norway House in the five years that I have been associated with the Board of Home Missions, and in no single case did the fire originate in the furnace room. In so far as Round Lake is concerned there would be very little hope of getting the children out with the stairs and other facilities which are available, if the fire had gained any headway. We have some other schools which receive a grant for Nightwatchmen, which are practically fire-proof and have adequate fire escapes, but in these two instances I feel that a general rule has been made to apply, and that it should be rectified at once.

Thanking you for your kind attention to this important matter, I am,

Yours very sincerely,

WHY KESTER IS FLUX-FILLED

All common metals oxidize or rust at room temperature; but if they are heated they oxidize much faster. Aluminum, like other metals, is no exception. They too oxidize faster when heated, as they must be for soldering, and unless a flux is used such oxides prevent the solder from sticking properly. Any one who has used ordinary soft solder realizes the importance of a fluxing agent.

It is true, that certain manufacturers of Aluminum Solder have stated that their product does not require a flux. Since the function of a flux is that of reducing the oxides accumulated on the surface of the metal to be soldered, it is an unquestionable fact that the use of a flux makes the soldering of aluminum a much easier accomplishment.

Other manufacturers have claimed that their aluminum solders contain a flux which is supposedly intermixed with the metal itself. Naturally, anything of the sort is an impossibility, as it is a well known fact that flux and solder will not mix in any manner whatsoever.

It remained for the Kester Solder Company to be the first to produce Aluminum Solder with an efficient fluxing element sealed within the solder body and make successful aluminum solder a reality.

Sir,

I beg to advise that certain pieces of the equipment at the Round Lake School having outlived their usefulness require replacing these are:

- Toilet in the boys Dormitory
- Toilet in the Girls Dormitory
- Toilet in the girls wash and play room.
- 3 water taps in Laundry and wash rooms.

3 of the taps required are the automatic shut off, the others, one with hose spout for the laundry room and two for the tubs in that room.

They also require two pulleys,
one in the laundry room for driving the machine 8" in diameter by 8" wide, this could be a solid pulley as it can be placed on from the end of the shaft which is 1 15/16 in. in diameter.

Sir:

I have received a letter from the Reverend Principal of the Round Lake School asking whether there has been sanctioned any expenditure for painting at his school for the fiscal year 1937-38.

He states that the office and staff rooms, the dining room, the laundry, the two play rooms could get one coat; the halls and pantries could be calaminated and all the buildings need outside paint.

His idea in asking is that if an expenditure has been allowed in the estimates he could employ his night watchman who will finish his duties at the end of this month with the work. He states he would be willing to pay the salary of this man if the Department would provide the paint. There is no doubt if this method was adopted far more work would be able to be performed with what money was available than otherwise.

It is noted in page 10 of the estimates the sum of $450.00 was placed for this work.

Your obedient servant,

Sir:-

I have to advise that the Revd. Principal of the Round Lake School writes as follows:

"Our engineer noticed a discharge on Saturday on the switchboard of the generator when no lights were on. He investigated and found a short in an upstairs back room used as a store room. It was just where the cord entered the ceiling. The insulation had perished with age and the swinging of the cord when turning on the switch had evidently cracked it and thus caused the short. I regard this matter of sufficient importance to report it. This discovery has made our engineer more alert than ever."

Information passed on for your instructions please.

Your obedient servant,

Eben A. W. R. McKenzie
Indian Agent.

Ottawa.

Stockholm, Sask., October 20th, 1937

Mr. Evan A. W. R. McKenzie,
Indian Agent,
Broadview, Sask.

Dear Mr. McKenzie,

Dr. R. G. Ferguson of Fort San warned us that if our matron were to continue to look after the health of the Indian children and treat the many cases of trachoma that we have in the school, it would be necessary for us to safeguard her health in every possible way. We immediately sent for an Ostermoor mattress as the one she was using was one of the children's mattresses and a poor one at that. I am forwarding four copies of the bill in the hope that the Department will pay it.

I may say that Mrs. Therrien's health shows a continual improvement. She herself attributes a part of this result to the comfort of her mattress.

Yours truly,

R. J. Ross.

Sir:-

I beg to advise that Mr. Ross, Principal of the Round Lake School phoned me this morning that the generator at the school had burnt out and that they were without light, and he further advised me that Mr. Kendrick, living near there, has a suitable generator that he would instal taking the old one in exchange for the price between $26.00 and $30.00.

Mr. Kendrick has previously furnished the Cowessess School with a Generator that is giving satisfaction and in view of this I have authorised him to instal a generator in the Round Lake School.

As all of the money for painting for that school cannot be used owing to the lateness of the season could this be made a charge against the funds as authorised in your letter 108-1-5 of August 20th last, and please advise.

Your obedient servant,

Eben A.W.R. McKenzie,
Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of December 30, the Department is prepared to purchase the paint which you state has been requested by the Principal of the Round Lake Indian Residential School.

In view of the cost of the paint, it will be necessary to have it purchased by our Purchasing Agent and to enable him to do so, very definite information will have to be supplied regarding what you consider necessary; for instance, please state the colour of the house paint and the barn paint. We are not prepared to favourably consider the purchase of the furniture, etc. owned by Mrs. Therrien.

Dr. Harold McGill, M.D.,
Director, Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Canada.

Dear Dr. McGill,

We received your circular letter dated Feb. 10th to Principals of Indian Residential Schools.

Our supply of water comes from a well situated a short distance from Round Lake just where the Qu'Appelle River flows out of the lake. The water seeps through the sand which acts as a natural filter. During the past winter no water flowed out of the lake. The result was that the well filled slowly. Sometimes we had only enough for our ordinary needs.

When the diggers were sinking the well, they encountered quicksand and were not able to make the well as deep as they had intended. I see no other way of getting a greater supply of water from this well, a supply sufficient at all times for the fire hoses should the need arise to use them, except by enlarging the diameter of the well.

I think this work should be done by next fall and that the cost, if the work is done by local well-diggers, should not exceed Fifty Dollars.

Yours very sincerely,

R.J. Ross,
Prin. Round Lake Indian Res. School.
Ottawa,

Extract from letter dated July 6, 1938, received from Dr. J. J. WALL.

It is with respect to the fire hazard at night in four of our Schools. They are Sandy Bay, Man., Round Lake and Cowessess of Broadview, Sask., and lastly and especially Hobema, Alta. In any of these institutions, should I sleep there, I always have the flash-light, overcoat, socks and gloves available and prepared for a sudden dive into the winter night. This fear in these four places certainly has not become an obsession but it has started to bother my conscience.

I know how foolish it would be in these hard times to imagine that funds are available for proper reconstruction. But is it not possible to get proper escape apparatus installed. Every second for evacuation time must be conserved. I am not frightened so much of the flames at night but I am fearful of the superheated gases developing and flooding the halls. Only a partial lung-ful of this and a person is out. All the fire fighting equipment possible will not avail such a case. That was my experience years ago at the Royal Victoria in Montreal when we had that terrible movie fire which took so many children. It was not the flames, as I recollect, none were even scorched.

My belief is that this problem can be solved in preparing proper escapes. Iced poles of iron, narrow snow or ice filled metal stairs on the outside possibly open to a wall of flames from some window it passes will only add to the panic at night. Poor lighting over these meager affairs will not assist.

The panic in the children when a real fire does break will be stupendous. The stoical Indian in such case is a figment on the part of certain popular authors.

Dont be sore at me, Phil., as I am prepared to lay a two to one bet up to $100 bucks that in case of such an eventuality in any of the four, happening in winter between ten at night and four in the morning, the mortality will exceed...
thirty per cent.

The ideal thing would be an inspection of each by an officer, like the Chief of the Montreal brigade, who has had plenty of experience dealing with such institutional hazards. His first consideration would be to figure the route the fire and gases would take so that adequate methods and routes of escape can be instituted. Steel fire doors would undoubtedly be installed on each floor above the first. Steel tower-like escapes as on the Kent Street School at Ottawa would replace at strategic points the old dangerous poles and narrow stairs. Lists of pupils to utilize each escape would be posted at all times and each child's name checked from list as it passes by a responsible guardian. Many of the children otherwise, in the event of a genuine alarm will, if not watched, take refuge in a clothes closet or under its bed.

Night watchman was a step in the right direction but much can happen in the winter when he is punching in the outbuildings and barn and the time he returns to the school.

Much as I hate to bring your attention to this whole question in these four places, please understand it is not done so with any sense of butting in. It is for these poor kiddies sake, many of whom one becomes attached in his duties. In case also, should any catastrophe arise, we all shall be scourged properly at any investigation especially at the hands of politically conscious lawyers who cynically will give little credit to those who really and truly have the fullest interests of these tots at heart.

Sir:-

Concerning Department letter 106-1-5 of April 13th last, re-amount of years appropriation for Round Lake I.R. School, the Revd. Principal writes as follows:

"In getting our Gurney furnace ready for the winter, we found that two of the sections, 2nd and 4th from the front, are leaking and should be replaced. The number on the furnace seems to be 106-425. If there are gaskets we would need gaskets for four sections. We need also the water glass assembly (the glass and two valves).

When we ordered the dryer last fall, we expected it to be delivered in time to be installed before the cold weather arrived. When it came the weather was too cold to install it as we would have to let the fires out in order to do so. We set it up in the spring but did not need to use it during the summer. To have it work properly we will need a return pipe back to the furnace. We will also need lumber enough to close up three windows. When we estimated the cost of this dryer, we set the figure at $200.00 or less. The dryer itself cost about $120.00 or so. We would still be within the estimate if we got the pipe and lumber. We should have 100 feet one inch galvanized pipe, 8 elbows, 4 couplings, 1 union, 1 valve or tap so that we can shut it off, 1 reducer from 2" to 1", and 1 reducer from 1" to 1/2". 100 feet of drop siding and 100 feet of rough lumber would close up the windows and a couple of small doors in the room. We have the nails and paper for the job.

We are nearly half through with painting the school buildings and find that it is taking much more paint than we estimated. We will need 30 gallons French Gray Paint and 5 gallons White Outside Paint and 3 gallons Shingle Paint, permanent, enamel, to finish the job. We should also have 4" paint brushes, and one each of 2" and 1" paint brushes. We would also have 3 gallons tar to patch the rubberoid roofing, and a sheet of galvanized tin for patching around the chimneys.

We will need at one for the principal's residence one bag of cement to stop the leak in the cement cistern, one plank 2 x 10 and 15 feet long to make a step at the back door and a bag of plaster to repair walls and roofs."

With regard to the paint as it is for finishing the job if allowed might I suggest that the Revd. Principal orders this and then he would be able to specify exactly what is wanted in this case.

May the necessary authority please be granted as he requests for these repairs.

Your obedient servant,
