Sir:-

I beg to advise that a new Principal has arrived at the Round Lake I. R. School in the person of Mr. Huston. He has taken up his residence in the principal's residence which is apart from the school building.

He asks if the Department will authorise some repairs now to at least make it habitable.

This house has been unoccupied for several years as Mr. Ross lived in the school, and is in a very bad state of repair. The plaster in every room needs replastering, the chimney needs rebuilding from the roof up, each window leaks water to the inside and there are not sufficient storm windows for the house. The foundation requires refacing around the basement windows. These are urgent repairs to make the house habitable but only temporary as the whole outside of the building and roof badly need repainting.

Out of the appropriation of $850.00 the sum of $480.00 has been vouchered for and with another approx. $160.00 for that authorised there should be a balance of about $270.00 out of the original appropriation.

I would think that it would cost in the neighborhood of $300.00 to make it fit to carry on through the winter but it is almost impossible to fill out a form 374 for this work as it really needs an estimate from a competent builder.

The new Principal has no other place than this house to live in and it is not fit to live there as it is at present and asks that authority may be granted as soon as possible to get a competent estimate of it and proceed with the work.

Memorandum:

MR. BAILEY

I attach account for $164.35 in favour of the Sherwin-Williams Company covering the cost of paint and material for the Round Lake Residential School.

A quantity of paint for this school was ordered in February, 1938 (your order No. 2956).

However, on September 10 the Indian Agent advised that due to the fact that the building had not been painted for many years it was found that more paint was needed than had been previously supplied. At that time there was a possibility that the weather might turn cold and the Agent requested authority to purchase the additional quantity of paint necessary in order that the painting could be completed at the earliest possible date. He was, therefore, authorized at that time to purchase the additional quantity covered by the enclosed account.

Please issue purchase order so that the account may be paid.

R. A. Hoey,

Broadview, Sask.

Dear Mr. McKenzie,

The other morning we discovered a leak in the large return pipe to our furnace in the heating system. When the engineer tried to repair the pipe he found it so badly rusted that anything he did to it only made the leak greater. We had to immediately let the fire out, keep letting water into the furnace to replace what leaked out until the furnace cooled and replace the old pipe with new pipe which we were able to get in Stockholm. Fortunately for us the day was mild and we suffered no inconvenience.

You will find enclosed four copies of the invoice for the new pipe etc.

Yours very sincerely,

R.J. Ro-xx.

Dear Sir:

Re: Crooked Lakes 1940-41 Estimates,
Page 8, Principal's Dwelling House.

I am today in receipt of a letter from the Rev. Mr. Huston, Principal of the above referred to school, asking if it is possible to have the work on his dwelling done this season. He points out that the house in its present condition is very cold and unfit for habitation during the winter. He states that last year they had to use Arctic robes brought from the north on their beds at night, but this provided no solution for the cold during the day.

His recommendation is to cover all over the outside with an imitation brick. This material is a heavy tar, paper and sand mixture made to look like bricks. The testimonies of people in Whitewood who are using it seem to indicate that it is 100% satisfactory.

He states there is yet time to have this done this season. He also states that they have an excellent furnace but it has no effect under present conditions.

I may say that on my last visit to this school I went through this house and found conditions are as outlined by the Principal. The necessary work to have this house made habitable this winter would be the outside insulation and the providing of 16 storm windows, at a total cost of about $580.00.

I would therefore recommend that this work be done if funds are available. Failing this, the Principal will have to get rooms in town for his family.

Dear Sir:— As requested I have this day visited the house of the Reverend Principal at the Round Lake I. R. School.

I find the outside construction very poor. It consists of the following:— 1 inch lumber, paper and siding. The paper has perished giving no resistance to wind or cold.

The inside is plastered right to the studs.

The floors are of one thickness. There is no sub-floor as is customary in home construction.

There is no insulating in any part of the house.

The furnace is not doing the heating it should for the reason that there are only 2 cold air pipes 12" in diameter for the whole of the house, none from the upstairs at all. There should be at least two double headers from the upstairs and two more from the ground floor to get results from the furnace.

Yours truly,

Signed, W. R. Webb.
Sir,

With reference to your letter of the 18th instant to Inspector Dr. Robertson concerning the matter of the necessary repairs to the house of the Reverend Principal of the Round Lake I.R. School in order to make it habitable, the complaint being it was impossible to keep warm in the winter. This afternoon on the instructions of Dr. Robertson visited this school with Mr. W. Webb of Broadview and thoroughly went into the whole matter.

There are several causes for the cold the most important being that whatever was done satisfaction would not be achieved until the furnace was altered. At present there is not sufficient cold air shafts and as a consequence the cold air stays stationary and does not give the hot air a chance to circulate. To remedy this more cold air shafts would have to be put in and the whole affair remodelled at a cost of $50.00.

The inside walls are too thin and the paper used as building paper when the house was built is perished and there is no resistance for the cold from the walls.

The top part of the house around the eaves and roof has no insulation whatever which also again does not prevent the cold from coming in.

The casings around the windows and doors outside are worn out and need renewing.

The main ground floor is only ordinary flooring with no subfloor and this should be reinforced over the present floor with an oak flooring.

I may say that within the last two days the plants have already frozen in the house.

I do not know what appropriation the Department have to spend on this house but the Reverend Principal has asked me to convey his wishes that the whole of these repairs be authorised and give him a house in which he can live and also that the Department were authority for the work to proceed at once as winter seems to have set in already as snow is on the ground and last night it was down nearly zero.

I am enclosing a booklet showing on page 2 the Perth Blend insulated siding proposed to put on the outside of the house.

I am also enclosing copy of Mr. Webb's letter on the matter and form 37½ enumerating material required and cost of labour.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir,

I have now received a report from our sanitary Officer, Mr. J.E. Hockley, in connection with the plumbing system at the Round Lake Indian Residential School.

The report is very discouraging. Mr. Hockley states that in his opinion the system is in such bad condition it cannot be improved short of complete replacement. I quote from Mr. Hockley's report: "The system is in a very poor state of repair, and in my opinion requires replacing and major over-hauling. There are only four clean-outs in the entire building, all visible stacks, drains, and waste pipes are full of holes which have been plugged with wooden pegs. The holes have been bored from time to time to permit the insertion of rods for clearing obstructions. Ceilings and walls even to the third floor show stain and plaster breakage due to leakage of pipes or from overflowing fixtures.

The waste pipes, stacks and floor drains are heavily corroded. One length of 1/2 inch pipe shown to me was so heavily corroded that there was only about 1 inch opening remaining. Fixtures, particularly closet bowl water seal chambers were so heavily corroded the services of a plumber was necessary to clear them. One closet was completely plugged.

In the basement a two inch pipe was carried from the laundry tub waste up to and along the ceiling to the soil stack, then downward and connected to the stack near the floor level. This was apparently supposed to be a vent.

A four inch stack rising through the dining-room ceiling terminates in the boy's playroom. At one time a water closet was connected to it at this point, but the water closet has been removed, and the stack has been reduced to a two inch pipe and apparently carried into the ceiling above and is deflected a few feet and is carried through the boys' and girls' dormitories as a vent.

As shown in the sketches submitted, there is only one staff bathroom which contains one water closet, and there are a total of five water closets in three different rooms for the pupils. No separate accommodation has been provided for the male members of the staff.

The septic tank contained about four feet of sludge and has not been cleaned out for a considerable length of time. At various points along the drain from the building to the septic tank and between the septic tank and absorption field, the pipe had to be broken to enable the operators to insert the cleaning rods so that obstructions could be removed. The discharge pipe from the septic tank was apparently solidly plugged and some of the tile drains in the absorption field are completely plugged and not operating. Furthermore, the sewer pipe to the septic was reduced from six inches to four inches where it enters the tank, the siphon had to be broken into so that it could be cleaned and obstructions removed. The liquid level in the septic tank had at one time risen to a height several feet above the inlet and outlet pipes with the
result that sewage backed up into the building."

It is quite obvious that the plumbing system at the school is in a very bad condition, and it seems to me that it was not properly installed in the first place. Furthermore, there are said to be seventy to eighty pupils, yet there are only five water closets and no urinals for the boys. In addition, the water closets are located at various points in the building with not more than two in any one location.

It is also evident that insufficient attention has been given to the operation of the septic tank. No system of sewage treatment will eliminate solids or convert them entirely to a liquid form. Consequently, the resulting sludge must be removed from treatment units periodically. The septic tank at the school is scarcely large enough for the requirements, but regardless of the size it could not function properly unless the sludge is removed before it accumulates to a depth in excess of about two feet. Cleaning operations may have to be carried out two or three times a year or oftener.

I trust that this matter will be brought to the attention of the proper authorities and that early action will be taken to correct the many faulty conditions in the plumbing system. If such action is not taken, it may be necessary to close off the water waste system entirely.

Yours truly,

J.G. Schaeffer, B.Sc.,
Sanitary Engineer.

REPORT ON
INSPECTION OF ROUND LAKE INDIAN RESIDENTIAL
SCHOOL
STOCKHOLM, SASKATCHEWAN.

With reference to the above, I wish to report
that on the last ultimo, in company with Indian Agent
McKenzie of Broadview, Saskatchewan, and Mr. G. Havens,
his successor at the Crooked Lake Agency, I carried out
a thorough inspection of the School and found conditions
to be as follows:

The building is a frame structure consisting
of three stories and basement which has fallen into a
very bad state of repair. Approximately one-half of the
building has been in service for forty years, the re-
mainder having been erected as an addition in 1918.

Foundation walls, basement floor, heating
system, plaster work, wood floors, window frames and sash,
and interior trim, are all in need of repair, while the
plumbing and electric wiring systems, upon which I was
specially instructed to report, have depreciated to the
point of requiring almost complete replacement.

With reference to the plumbing, it is evident
that this division of work was poorly installed initially.
Clean-out access fittings were omitted from soil stacks
and waste lines, and when these became blocked by heavy
waste matter, corrosion and alkaline deposits, access has
been obtained by drilling the pipes to accommodate clean-
ing rods. The holes thus created have been filled by
wooden blocks which gradually decay and from time to time
drop out completely permitting the passage of waste matter
and sewer gas. Flaws, holes or cracks in soil lines are
violations of the Provincial Health Regulations, and it is
understood that the Provincial Department of Public Health
has already indicated that they will insist on the replace-
ment of all defective plumbing.

The School is occupied by seventy-five pupils,
forty girls and thirty-five boys, as well as a teaching
and non-professional staff of fourteen. The girls are
served by three W.C.'s, one in their recreation room toilet
and two in the dormitory toilets. The boys are served by
two W.C.'s, both in their dormitory toilet. The whole
school staff, both male and female, is at present served by
one bathroom.

No new plumbing work should be considered which
did not include one additional W.C., (four in all) in each
of the following locations:

(1) Girls recreation room toilet.
(2) Girls dormitory toilet.
(3) Boys recreation room toilet.
(4) Boys dormitory toilet.
An additional bathroom for the male staff is also absolutely necessary. A suggested location adjacent to the School workshop was pointed out to the Indian Agent. The bathroom now serving the whole staff could thus be released for the use of the female staff alone.

Many of the fittings belonging to the plumbing fixtures are broken or missing and should be replaced. Connections between the fixtures and soil lines are faulty, in many cases allowing the escape of soil content which has saturated the adjacent floors. All plumbing fixtures should be removed, cleaned and re-set.

The septic tank when viewed was functioning satisfactorily but since it receives toilet, kitchen and laundry waste, will eventually cause trouble. An additional four-inch vitrified tile drain, eighty-five feet in length, to carry off laundry and kitchen waste to the river, without passing through the septic tank, would eliminate trouble in this regard. Most of the hot and cold water lines are heavily corroded and should be replaced.

With reference to the electric wiring system I may say that this is of the knob and tube type and is in a badly depreciated condition. There are no permanent lighting fixtures, lighting being provided by drop cords and sockets from the outlets. Switches have been removed, wiring has been altered by the school staff and the whole system disarranged. It will require considerable repair work to restore the electrical system to a satisfactory condition.

The steam heating system appears to have sufficient capacity and the boiler and equipment is functioning satisfactorily. The supply and return piping, however, has become corroded and many of the connections are leaking. Radiators have become loosened and in some cases have been moved to new positions, and the system generally will require extensive adjustment.

As has been pointed out repairs will be necessary sooner or later to the whole building; in addition to whatever is now required to provide satisfactory plumbing and lighting services. It is felt that to be handled economically, all work should be undertaken at the same time and that until funds are available to this extent major repairs should be deferred.

Under the latter circumstances, the frequent services of a local plumber will be necessary.

The attitude of the Saskatchewan Department of Public Health will undoubtedly determine to a great extent the action to be taken by the Indian Affairs Branch in this matter.
If and when replacements and renovations are undertaken the cost of the necessary work is estimated to be approximately as follows:

**PLUMBING SYSTEM**

Replacements, repairs and new work to conform to Provincial regulations ... $1,250.00

**ELECTRIC WIRING**

Repairs to wiring, outlets, and switches, additional outlets and fixtures ........................................... $80.00

**GENERAL REPAIRS TO STRUCTURE**

Repairs to basement concrete floors, radiator connections throughout, new heating piping, new plaster work, interior wood work (including window frames, sash, doors, trim and flooring,) painting .................................................. $1,100.00

$2,900.00

Contingencies .................................................. $500.00

Total .............................................................. $3,400.00

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER:

Re: Round Lake Indian Residential School,
Crooked Lake Indian Agency,
Electoral District of Melville, Saskatchewan.

The main building at this school was built approximately 40 years ago by the Presbyterian Church. The Department purchased the buildings and land (approximately 400 acres) at this place in the fiscal year 1922-23, at a total cost of $7,152.46. Following the purchase of the building, considerable money was spent in repairing it and in the erection of an outside classroom, barn and other outbuildings.

The Round Lake School is now conducted under the auspices of the United Church of Canada. In the Crooked Lake Agency there is also the Comessass Residential School, conducted under the auspices of the Roman Catholic Church. About one-half the population of the Crooked Lake Agency are adherents of the United Church of Canada and the remainder are Roman Catholics.

The Round Lake Residential School has an authorized enrolment of 75 pupils.

A few months ago the Sanitary Engineer of the Department of Public Health, Province of Saskatchewan, visited this school and reported very unfavourably on the plumbing system. He pointed out that in his opinion the whole plumbing system would have to be replaced.

Arrangements were made to have Mr. Buck, Architect of the Surveys and Engineering Branch, visit
this school and I enclose, for your information, a copy of his report.

As you will note, Mr. Buck's report indicates that the main building is in very bad condition and to place it in anything like satisfactory shape there would be required a much larger expenditure than that suggested by Mr. Buck. An amount of $3,000.00 was provided in the current year's appropriation for repairs, improvements and purchase of new equipment at this school. Of this amount it has been found necessary to expend $65.00 for a new pump and consequently $2,935.00 is still available.

On two occasions the officials of this Branch have discussed with Mr. Buck the situation at Round Lake and after considering the matter from all angles it is felt that if it is decided to make any repairs we should confine our efforts to replacing the plumbing system only, at an approximate cost of $1,250.00, and leave the other repairs mentioned in Mr. Buck's report until more funds are available.

The other alternative is to close the school immediately.

Last week Reverend Dr. Dorey, Associate Secretary of the Board of Home Missions of the United Church of Canada, visited this Branch and the condition of the Round Lake School was fully discussed with him. He had recently been at Round Lake and he agreed that the school required very extensive repairs. He also admitted that it looked like a waste of money to spend any large sum on repairing it. Dr. Dorey expressed the opinion that a new residential school was absolutely required and that, due to the fact that the United Church population was scattered, it would not be feasible to operate one or more day schools. He felt, however, that the Department should make some endeavour to effect the most necessary repairs in order to obviate the necessity of closing the school.

I hesitate to make any definite recommendation in this matter and submit the above for the decision of the Minister. If there is any other information that is required, I will endeavour to supply it.

Director.

Dear Dr. Robertson;

At long last I am going to put into writing a description of the type of building I feel would enable us to give the Indian boys under our supervision more adequate training in vocational work. Enclosed you will also find the contractor's estimate on costs, also a diagram of building.

Building 20' X 50' divided into two rooms, carpenter shop 20' X 20' and a machine shop 20' X 30'. Underneath the outer wall there would be a cement foundation one foot high and one foot wide. The floor in the carpenter shop could be made from heavy two inch lumber while that in the machine shop would be made of cement except that portion just inside the big door which would be left without a floor to admit a tractor with lugs. This building could be covered on the outside, roof as well as walls, with corrugated sheet metal. Plenty of windows, two foot high that can slide up and down and be inserted in all four walls. Small sufficient light and the work benches could be installed underneath the windows. The building itself could be lined on the inside of the studding with shiplap and some type of insulating material could be used between the studding. Instead of a ceiling there could be placed a floor on top of the ceiling joist this would provide a place for seasoning lumber.

During the months December to March inclusive local carpenters would be glad to accept steady indoor employment and a man could be hired to give the boys daily instruction in the repair of wagons and sleighs. The boys under his direction could in a heated workshop of this type repair all the furniture, make wagon tongues, neck yokes, whipple-trees. In fact all our repairs and necessities in wood-work could be handled there. What the school would save would hire the staff carpenter and the boys themselves would get the training. Besides all this we have our six hundred acre bush from which we could obtain our poplar lumber for the manufacture of home furnishings. Imagine what a difference it should make in the homes on the reserves if we could produce furniture, beds, cupboards, chairs, and tables well made and nicely painted at prices far below even the cost of second-hand furniture. Furthermore the boys would benefit by the training and the parents themselves would prize the furniture not alone for its usefulness but as a product made by their own boy.

In the heated machine shop every piece of machinery on the farm even to the engines could be gone over in the slack time during the Winter months. The boys could do all this under the direction of our mechanic. It would save us money as well as precious time in the Summer and the boys would learn how to repair and re-assemble the very things they are going to be working with when they leave school.

The cost of a building of this type should not be great. It will be little more than a shell in structure. The walls will only be nine feet high and no expensive lumber or materials will be required to complete its construction.

After nine years experience among Indians in various parts of Canada I am convinced that the emphasis we are now placing upon vocational training in their education comes the nearest to anything yet attempted in preparing the graduates for life on the Reserve. In a former letter I stated that a boy or girl whose academic training ended at grade four yet was supplemented by a practical knowledge in the art of doing things stood better equipped for life as they would find it than he or she who had nothing more to show than a grade eight certificate. After all only about five percent of the graduates will ever be able to capitalize on a purely academic education. The others whether they like it or not will go back to the Reserves or to the neighboring towns and farms for the making of their livelihood. If we think we should be aware of this and seek to train them in useful arts. If we do this the graduate instead of feeling like one emerging from a sheltered cloister will know what he is better prepared to meet life than he could otherwise have been apart from the school.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6333, file 661-5, part 4)
The Indian Residential School in order to justify its existence must adjust itself to meet these new demands. This type of school was built originally to hasten the civilizing process and to isolate each new generation from the trachoma and tuberculosis infecting the old. The school has been a great factor in hastening this process and one might say that work is almost accomplished. The new character of this school is an advanced step. We are now faced with the task of making citizens and in preparing each boy and girl for the business of making a livelihood in a world entirely different from that which their fathers knew.

If we can face this task the Residential school will reveal it is only yet in its prime but if it fails then we might as well confess Old Age has overtaken us. Two things are needed however; Vision and the ability to see it realized. A principal is not worthy of his position if he lacks this first requirement. The Board of Directors are expected to supply the second. That rest with the Department. They have the ability to enable me to realize the type of building I have visioned for this school. If they will support me in the same fine spirit as in the past I feel sure they will have every reason to feel my visions do meet a real issue.

Trusting that you are well and wishing you the very best throughout the New Year, I remain,

Yours sincerely,

"A. G. Huston"

DIRECTOR,

Christianson, General Superintendent of Indian Agencies, Regina, in which he states the engineer is of the opinion that $200 additional will be required to repair the heating plant at the Round Lake School. Dear Sir:

With further reference to our letter of October 3rd, asking authority to purchase a 3 H.P. engine for the Round Lake School at approximately $150.00. On receipt of your telegram we secured competitive prices and purchased a 3 H.P. I.H.C. High Speed engine but it was not at all suitable for the work and was returned. What is needed is a 57 H.P. self-oiling engine costing $346.08.

The engine is used generates the power, keeps up the water pressure and runs the laundry. The original engine was a 7 H.P. but the one now in use is a makeshift engine of several borrowed parts from other engines, to keep things going, when the other engines are needed the parts have to be put back.

I regret the necessity of asking for the larger engine. At the time our letter was written the Rev. Principal thought that a new 3 H.P. engine would be sufficient and was anxious to avoid unnecessary expense to the Department. However when the 3 H.P. engine was installed it was quite evident that it could not generate electricity and keep up the water pressure at the same time, as a result it would not afford the necessary protection in case of fire.

I would recommend for your consideration the larger engine. The above quotations include belts and pulleys costing $57.03, from the Fairbanks-Morse Co.

Your obedient servant,

In addition to the Residential Building there is a separate Classroom Building which was erected in 1925 and a Principal's Residence.

New floor, new windows, repairs to plastering main floor, east wing, original portion of building ..................... $1,100.00

Repairs to plastering male staff quarters original portion of building ........... $50.00

Contingencies and supervision .................. 150.00

Total estimated cost .................. $1,000.00

Memorandum:

Re: Indian Round Lake Residential School,
Stockholm, Saskatchewan

With reference to alterations and repairs authorized to be carried out by this Service on the Residential Building at the above, I may say that the work was executed during October and November under the supervision of Engineer Snelson of our Banff office.

As you are aware the work included repairs and replacements to the plumbing and drainage system, the addition of a number of plumbing fixtures, and the installation complete of a male staff bathroom, which items were estimated to cost approximately $1,250.00.

During operations Mr. Snelson uncovered additional defective plumbing and heating work, which involved an additional expenditure of $550.00.

Upon completion of his duties at the school, Mr. Snelson reported under date of the 27th ultimo as follows:

(a) All corroded and mutilated soil, vent, and water piping was replaced, new soil pipe and extra cleanouts were installed where required, vent pipes system was corrected, to comply with Provincial regulations.

(b) Existing plumbing fixtures were repaired, one water closet and tank replaced, four new water closets installed, and missing fittings and accessories replaced on existing basins and bath tubs.

(c) Complete new male staff bathroom was installed including plumbing fixtures, partitions with door and trim, radiator and sky light.

(d) Kitchen and laundry waste was diverted from passing through the septic tank by means of new tile drain.

(e) The steam heating plant was overhauled. Heating mains were cleaned and reconnected. Radiators were inspected, repaired and fitted with new valves and accessories, where necessary. A new smoke pipe was installed on the boiler. The jacket heater on the domestic hot water system was taken down, thoroughly cleaned, and reset.

(f) Pressure tank and pump were disconnected, cleaned and reconnected.

Water is pumped by a windmill from a well 6' x 10' x 15 ft. deep located 100 feet north from the bank of the DuPage River where it flows out of Round Lake. The well is cobbled with plank and contained water to a depth of four feet on October 31st, 1940. The soil between the well and the waters of the lake is mostly sand and gravel. On the above date the surface of the water in the well was 0.5 feet higher than the water surface of the lake. The water surface of Round Lake is eight feet lower than the high water marks on the bridge, pointed out to me by an Indian who had lived in the vicinity for some fifteen years. The elevation of the lake is between two and three feet lower than it was three years ago.

However, I would anticipate no shortage of water or work to be done on this intake system for many years to come, as undoubtedly the well receives seepage from the higher hills to the northward as well as from the lake.

There is also located in the pump-house a Myers pump connected to a new John Deere 1½ H.P. gas engine. This is used when there is not enough wind to operate the windmill or to augment the windmill pump supply when necessary. The water is pumped from the well 400 feet through 1½" galvanized pipe to a large concrete cistern under the basement floor of the boiler room. I was informed that this cistern would hold 5000 gallons.

From this cistern the water is pumped directly into the two pressure tanks which have a combined capacity when entirely filled with water of (1000+500) 1500 gallons. The pump is a Fairbanks-Morse Typhon with a capacity of 2500 gallons per hour at 100 pounds per square inch pressure. It was new in 1920 and is in good condition. The pump is run by a belt from a 6 H.P. engine. As mentioned in an accompanying report, the water pipes from the pump to the services in the building were cleaned and are now in satisfactory condition. Each floor of the building has a fire hose and rack. All floors are well equipped with fire extinguishers. There is a fire alarm system in the building and a night watchman. I would consider the fire protection of this building as satisfactory. It is not anticipated that any further expenditures on the water system in this building will be necessary for some considerable time.

Power is generated by a "Standard" Dynamo, volts 40, Amps. 25, Kilowatts 1.0, shunt wound, speed 500 R.P.M., Serial Number 151668. Built by Robbins and Myers of Springfield, Ohio, U.S.A. The Switchboard is Fairbanks-Morse. Fair condition. Switches in perfect working order. Insulation in good condition. Wiring throughout building; in fair condition but may need some occasional repairs. A new engine has just been purchased by the school to run this dynamo and also the pump but not both at the same time.

The sewage system as far as the outlet from the septic tank has just been relaid with new materials and may be considered as in excellent condition. There are now in place, 310 linear feet of 4" field tile between the outlet of the septic tank and the river. This should be replaced with six inch sewer tile as soon as convenient. It will cost approximately $150.00 for tile and $90.00 for labour and engineering, say a total of $240.00.
The Round Lake School is located three miles westerly and up the Capelle valley from a junction with the main North and South Highway between Stochholm and Whitewood. This junction is approximately twelve miles south of Stochholm and fourteen miles north of Whitewood. The road from the junction to the school is clay and not gravelled. It is almost impassable in wet weather. The main highway is gravelled. A road winds southerly from the school buildings. The southern side of the valley is wooded, cottonwood, birch; the northern side is mostly bare.

many thanks for your letter of enquiry dated January the eighth. The repairs listed under sections (A) and (D) are absolutely essential. Those under (B) and (C) are only minor. Year after year we have tried to induce the department to give us the materials for a poultry house. Our desire was to provide every child in the school with an egg ration. Personally I fail to see anything wrong with an idea of that kind. We believed in it so thoroughly last summer that we produced the hens and got the walls for the house 20x40 erected. That was all we could afford so we put a straw roof on it. We have two or three buildings about the place with straw roofs, bye and bye our institution will present the appearance of a bohemian barnyard. You will have to read the sign at the entrance twice to make sure its a government institution. You see my point. When its bath tubs and running water versus properly shingled roofs give me the latter.

Would it not be within reason and within the range of what may still be possible even in these difficult times for one to request a few shingles and some common lumber. In many parts of the interior of the Round Lake school paint is very much needed, there were amounts of about $200.00 in the 1940-41 estimates for this purpose.

The amount that would make the school more sanitary and pleasant are as follows:
10 gallons Pale Green Wall Paint
5 " Blue "
5 " Ivory "
10 " Light Grey Floor Paint

The Boys' Playroom is in poor shape and 500 board feet of V joint lumber is necessary to put it in good condition, and would cost about $25.00.

If this material could be supplied the school staff are willing to perform the necessary labour during the summer vacation.

We well know that every saving possible should be made in these times, but the above is very necessary for the upkeep of this school.

Your obedient servant,

W. J. D. Kerley,
Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

Re: Wood Furnace at the Round Lake Day School.

The furnace in the Round Lake Day School is an old #416A Famous Magnet manufactured by the McClary Co., Winnipeg, Manitoba, with a 4' 6" fire box. The fire box and the drums are all burnt out and is now beyond repair. This furnace has been patched up several times and has been unsatisfactory for several years. On real cold days last winter school had to be cancelled as the building could not be properly heated. A new furnace is urgently needed for the coming winter.

This item is in the 1941-42 estimates, would the Department purchase a new wood furnace with a 4' 6" fire box to heat this building containing 19200 cubic feet, consisting of 2 classrooms and cloakrooms.

The labour for the installation would be about $20.00 plus any new material needed in connecting the present two hot and three cold air ducts. The nearest available tinsmith is Mr. F. Garland of Whitewood, Sask.

If possible this work should be done during the summer vacation, so that the school could be cleaned after the installation of the furnace. The school rooms were painted during the Easter vacation and are now black with the smoke from the old furnace.

Your obedient servant,

INSPECTION REPORT
Electrical Inspection & Licensing Act,
Section 19.

To: Mr. Curley,
Dept. of Indian Affairs, Broadview, Sask.

The Electrical installation of Round Lake Indian School at Round Lake was inspected on the 22nd day of Sept. 1941.

DEFECTS:
Circuits overloaded. Outlets extended with flex cord and W.P. wire. Wires not properly supported. Outlets having live wires, loose and uncompleted at ceiling and wall outlets. Fuses plugged. W.P. wire used within buildings on branch circuits.

The above does not conform to the requirements of the Canadian Electrical Code and constitute a danger or a potential danger to life or property. The following changes must be made within 60 days from the date hereof:

Overhaul wiring. Tape up and otherwise complete free ends of wires at outlets. Remove flex cord used to extend outlets. Properly fuse all circuits and support and insulate all conductors in conformity with requirements for open wiring where necessary. Reduce loading on branch circuits to 640 watts or provide additional circuits if required.

Failure to have the defects remedied within the time specified may result in discontinuance of service to the premises.

Dated at Regina, this 21st day of October 1941.

Acting Chief Inspector,

17th November, 1941.

Crooked Lake Indian Agency,
Dear Sirs;

In regard to the defective wiring located by Mr. Carpenter at the Round Lake Indian School on the 22nd of Sept. 1941.

I have been to the school as I was instructed and have listed all the material required and the cost to make the repairs needed. Also I have listed the cost of labor.

The labor listed does not include the cost of repairing plaster that might have to be removed.

The Principal has mentioned to me about the heavy voltage loss at his residence, and I find that the line used to carry the power is no. 10 which is too small a wire for such a distance and no. 4 would be required to reduce the voltage drop. However I am listing the cost to make this alteration if you think it should be altered.

Trusting that you find the labor and material listed satisfactory, I remain

Yours very truly,

A. Kendrick
Dear Sir:

Re: File No. 108-1-5, October 30th 1941.

With reference to the above noted letter, I beg to forward herewith the estimate for material and labour received from Mr. A. Kendrick for the repairs at the Round Lake Indian Residential School, after he had consulted Mr. Carpenter, Inspector of The Saskatchewan Power Commission.

The total cost as listed is $207.15, the item of $78.60 for 1200 ft. of #4 wire leading to the Principal's Residence is not in Mr. Kendrick's opinion absolutely necessary or dangerous, but Mr. Huston requested him to include this, as though there is plenty of power generated at the school, the wires to the house being too small there is a heavy voltage loss, and the lighting not satisfactory.

Your obedient servant,

W. J. D. Kerley,
Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

I regret to report that a fire occurred recently in the engine and boiler room at the Round Lake Residential School, causing damage to two doors and transom and the paint in the passage and laundry. Two doors and frames will have to be replaced and the laundry and passage painted.

In its present state the boiler and engine room is a fire hazard. While it is not practical to change the present arrangements of the boiler room, much of the danger would be eliminated if the interior were lined with Gyproc, which is a fireproof material.

I am enclosing requisition for the material required. The prices being quoted by the Security Lumber Co., Broadview, Sask.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir:

We have received a communication from Mr. A. Kendrick, Marieval, Sask., with reference to the electric light system at the Round Lake Residential School, Whitewood, Sask., in which he writes as follows:

"After making a final inspection of the Round Lake Indian School electric light system, I find that they have not got a cutout on the switch board, and any time the engine might stop when there is no attendant around, the batteries will discharge through the generator, running the generator as a motor. I am forwarding this information for your consideration.

Dear Sir:

I wish to inform you that Mr. Huston, of the Round Lake School, was in the office last Saturday morning in connection with the File Hills School.

While here he made the following request. At the Round Lake School there is no Chapel and the present arrangement is to hold Church in the classrooms of the school, which are in a separate building from the main school building. To provide seating accommodation it is necessary to carry out benches that are used by the children in the dining room and the Principal was wondering whether our Branch would furnish him with collapsible chairs. He claims these would cost $2.25 each and could be piled up in the back end of the school during the week and set up to be used for Sunday Church Service. Mr. Huston wants 100 chairs, which would mean $225.00.

If our Branch will not agree to this Mr. Huston would like to know if he could be given a grant and he would take up a collection amongst the employees and donate something himself for the purpose of getting the chairs in question.

Yours truly,

M. Christianson,
General Superintendent of Indian Agencies.

Dear Sir:

I beg to enclose herewith Requisitions for Material for repairs and painting at the Round Lake Indian Residential School, Whitewood, Sask.

Roofing is badly needed for the Day School Building as roof is leaking and damaging the plaster. The eavestroughing is needed to replace broken parts. The flooring in both the boys' and Girls' playrooms is badly worn and needs to be replaced.

If the paint is granted the staff will perform the necessary labour.

Your obedient servant,

W. J. D. Kerley, Indian Agent.

Ottawa, Ont.
Memorandum

Mr. R.A. Hoey

We received yesterday Mr. Kerley's two requisitions for material for repairing and redecorating the Round Lake Indian Residential School.

As I am given to understand that the roof is leaking, it will be in order for Mr. Kerley to arrange for local purchase of the slate surfaced roofing and eaves-troughing in accordance with his estimated cost of $27.60.

Please obtain from Mr. Kerley the following information to enable us to place order with the least possible delay.

(a) Is the paint for outside or inside use?
(b) More detailed description of item 5 - plain paper.
(c) The name of the firm or firms in a position to supply the material at prices indicated on his requisition. If these were written quotations, showing the f.o.b. point, please send us same.

[Signature]

Departmental Purchasing Agent.

Dear Sir:

A situation has arisen in connection with merchandise sold to the Indian Residential Schools in the Province of Saskatchewan and, of course, this would apply to Indian Residential Schools in other provinces, as it relates to the matter of Provincial Taxes and discounts. Payments for merchandise supplied by our Company is received direct from the School and not from the Federal Treasury office in Ottawa.

Accounts are carried at the present time for the following schools:

File Hills Indian Residential School, Balcarres.
Thunderchild Indian Residential School, Delmas.
St. Michael's Indian Residential School, Duck Lake.
Indian Residential School, Marieval via Greyson.
Muscowegun Indian Residential School, Lestock.
Round Lake Indian Residential School, Whitewood.
St. Anthony's School, Onion Lake.
St. Barnabas' School, Onion Lake.
All Saints School, Lac la Ronge.

Some of the schools listed above include Eskimo pupils as well as Indian pupils and in connection with the various denominations interested in the operation of these schools, we understand that at least some operate schools which do not come under the Indian Affairs Branch.

Recent invoices covering merchandise to Round Lake Indian Residential School included certain charges for Provincial Education Tax and Provincial Gas Tax, and this has been questioned by the Principal, and in order to clarify this whole matter, we would like to have an opinion from you as to whether or not the schools listed above are regarded as being under the Indian Affairs Branch, and if they are considered as Federal Government Accounts.

We should like to have from you at your convenience a complete list of Indian Schools in the Province of Saskatchewan showing the denomination of the Church operating the school and the identity of any other denomination operating schools so that we could determine which schools would be classified as being under the Federal Department of Indian Affairs, and which schools are private schools subject to Provincial taxation, etc. If these schools are considered as under the Department

Dominion Public Bldg., Searth & Victoria, Regina, Sask.

I attach copy of a letter from Indian Agent Kerley, also a copy of letter from the Gurney North-West Foundry Company, with reference to the Round Lake Residential School.

No provision for a new boiler at this school was made in the current year's appropriation, nor was any request for a new boiler contained in the estimates forwarded by Indian Agent Kerley for the fiscal year 1943-44. You will, therefore, appreciate that it is impossible for the Department, at the present time, to give favourable consideration to this request.

In addition, it would take months to secure a new boiler and possibly, due to present conditions, it would not be possible to do so. I should, therefore, appreciate your discussing the matter fully with the Agent and the Principal of the Round Lake School at the first opportunity, with a view to ascertaining if the present boiler could be repaired in such a manner as to make it last for the duration of the war.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, OTTAWA.

I wish to acknowledge receipt of your letter No. 108-1-5 of the 8th instant regarding the boiler in the Round Lake School, Crooked Lake Agency.

Immediately upon receipt of this I got in touch with Mr. Huston, the Principal, and I am herewith quoting his letter in part:

"Last Autumn we had to repair one. This will give you an idea what was involved. It was a centre section. All other sections from the front to that one had to be removed before the one needing repair could be taken out. When each weighs about one thousand pounds it is easy to see it was no little task. Then we had to get the broken one out of the cellar, up a narrow staircase, load it on a truck, take it to Rocanville a distance of sixty miles, return for it in four days time, put it back in the furnace, replace and connect the other sections and then reputty the whole exterior of the furnace with asbestos cement. The repair job cost $26.00 and involved travelling a total mileage of 240 miles with a truck. Then a short time after all this the same section cracked again but in another place. If a break should occur in the Winter with roads blocked we could not use our truck as we did last Autumn. Anyway mileage restrictions would prohibit us going with the truck to the only man within a reasonable radius."

Mr. Huston also makes a good suggestion that when the school closes for summer holidays we send an experienced furnace man to check over the boiler and bring about any repairs that may be needed in order to make it last for another year if possible.

You will understand the reason the Principal did not place this in the Estimates. It was impossible for him to see from the outside whether there was anything wrong with the boiler or not and it was not until fires were put on in the Fall that the section in question cracked.

The Chief Inspector of Steam Boilers, and I believe you have a copy of his report, had the following to say:

"I am in receipt of your letter of the 13th, regarding the condition of the heating boilers..........."
"condition of the heating boilers at the Round Lake Indian Residential School. I have the report of Inspector Auckland, which states that the boiler is in very poor condition. Two sections are cracked and leaking and there is likely to be trouble with others due to accumulation of scale. I note that one section has been welded, but that it has cracked again.

It is the opinion of the Inspector that a new boiler is necessary."

I would therefore suggest that if this boiler lasts out through the Winter an experienced man be sent there next Summer and you people can either make the arrangements there or I will endeavour to get the nearest man available to the school. I quite realize that we would have to wait a long time for the boiler and the only thing is to try to repair it so that it will last for the duration. The Principal states the way the roads are now if there was a break in the boiler the only solution would be to send the children home. However, we hope this can be avoided.

M. Christianson,
General Superintendent of Indian Agencies.
Ottawa,
March 5, 1943.

INSTRUCTIONS FOR THE INSTALLATION, OPERATION AND MAINTENANCE OF

The American Globe Washer

FOREWORD

The purpose of this bulletin is to furnish necessary instructions for the proper installation, maintenance and operation of the American Globe Washer, and to assist in ordering any repair parts required.

The American Globe Washer has been designed to meet the demand for a low priced yet substantial frame washer. This washer embodies mechanical features and workmanship found in no other washer of this class.

To obtain its highest efficiency, certain important instructions should be followed to insure proper installation, operation and maintenance.

Read and carefully follow the instructions contained in this bulletin and preserve it for future reference.

Prior to shipment each Globe Washer is completely assembled and tested under power for a given period, which assures that the machine is in perfect condition when it leaves the factory.

INSTALLATION

1.—The washer, as received by you, requires no assembling except in the larger diameter belted motor types; the machine is then shipped with the top shaft and supporting brackets removed and must be reassembled.

2.—Gutter.—The washer is usually placed over a gutter. When a gutter cannot be provided the washer may be set on a substantial concrete floor. A curb at least four inches high around the machine should be provided to direct the water to the drain connection.

3.—Concrete Floor.—Should be provided to withstand the weight of the machine fully loaded, which is approximately 125 pounds per square foot, based on the overall floor space occupied by the washer.

4.—Piping.—The piping required for each size of Globe Washer is specified in the table. When connections are being made, care should be taken not to strain or spring any of the pipes located on the washer.

6. Alignment.—The machine must at all times be level in both directions. A leveling lug is provided on each foot and the machine should be leveled at each end. Lengthwise level is determined by placing a spirit level on the intermediate driving shaft. Where necessary, sheet metal shims may be placed under the feet of the machine until it can be used to obtain level. Improper alignment may cause broken gears, undue strain and noisy operation.

Washers having a center leg may be leveled in the same manner as described above with this exception, that before leveling, the cap is removed from the center bearing and the center leg is shimmed up so that the bearing fits the shaft properly. The leg is then leveled transversally; the usual grouting process is completed and the bearing cap replaced.

By using the above method, care being taken that the center bearing fits the shaft and that the shaft is not drawn out of level by the bearing, a quiet running machine is assured.

7. **Belt Drive.** Washers are furnished with pulleys as listed below. The line shaft pulley should be straight face, of correct diameter and width.

**Drive Shaft Pulley.** In addition to having the washer set perfectly level, it is also essential that the pulleys on the belt-driven machines are parallel with the line shaft.

If otherwise the belts will not shift properly. This will eventually cause the belts to wear and be reduced in width, resulting in improper timing of the shifter, which if not corrected, will cause the clothes being washed, to become tangled and torn.

To determine the diameter of the pulley to be placed on the line shaft to operate header pulleys at speed indicated, proceed as follows:

(a) Multiply the diameter (in inches) of the header pulleys by the number of revolutions stamped on one of them.

(b) Divide this product by the number of revolutions per minute of the line shaft and the results will be the correct diameter of the pulley to operate the pulleys on the machine at their rated speed. If this answer is an odd size in pulleys use the next lower pulley size.

**Example**—Pulley required to operate a 36-inch Globe Washer elevated header when line shaft rotates at 200 r. p. m.

\[ \text{16 inches (diameter of pulley on header)} \times 210 \text{ r. p. m. (r. p. m. stamped on header pulley)} = 3,360. \]

\[ 3,360 \div 200 \text{ r. p. m. (r. p. m. of line shaft)} = 16.8 \text{ inches}. \]

Correct diameter pulley to use on line shaft, 16-inch diameter.

The worm of the reversing header is driven by one of the loose pulleys known as the worm pulley. This pulley must operate continuously in the direction of the arrow stamped on it. The belt which drives the worm pulley must, therefore, be wide enough so that when it is shifted over to the tight pulley on the header, it is still sufficiently lapped over the loose worm pulley to drive it. This belt is therefore 1/4-inch wider than the other, and its location on the header may be determined by the size of the loops of the belt sifter. In crossing one of the belts for the reverse drive of the cylinder, be sure not to change the direction of rotation of the worm pulley from that indicated by the arrow stamped on its face.

On machines under 64 inches in length, this device is equipped with an eccentric lock which by means of a lever may be brought in mesh with main gear when machine comes to a stop.

OPERATION

1. After the machine has been set up and piping connected, lubricate it thoroughly according to instructions given in paragraph on lubrication. The machine is now ready for operation. Before starting, however, familiarize yourself with the following features:

2. Belt Shifter.—By means of a weighted lever attached to the shifter slide on the header, the belts may be shifted from the tight to the loose pulleys. On the elevated header and belted motor driven type washers an extension on this weighted lever is provided to bring the control within reach of the operator.

To start the cylinder:
(a) Be sure the gear lock, or on larger machines the worm lock, for main gear is released.
(b) Be sure the cylinder doors are closed and the door latches have entered the pockets provided for them.
(c) Throw the weighted lever forward until it engages with the cam bracket. As the cam bracket moves to the right or left the weighted lever will engage with the slot in the cam bracket and one of the belts will be shifted to the drive pulley.

To stop the machine:
(a) Throw the weighted lever backward and at the same time move it toward the slot in the stop for slide. This disengages the cam and shifts the belts to the loose pulleys.
(b) To spot the cylinder the belts may be slowly shifted on and off the tight pulley until the cylinder door is in proper position for unloading.
(c) Always lock the main gear when loading or unloading the washer and when the machine is idle.

The motor on belted motor drive is controlled by a switch located on the machine. The motor should be stopped when the machine is idle for any length of time, but not between loads.

3. Cleaning.—The inside cylinder and case should be cleaned before being placed in regular operation. This is to remove any foreign matter which may have collected on the staves of the cylinder or case and also to take up leaks due to the drying of the wood.

The following method of cleaning is suggested:
(a) Loosen all hoops on outside case before any water has been admitted to the case. This will prevent many broken hoop lugs and bulged cases.
(b) Fill the case with cold water until six inches shows in water gauge glass. Run machine for five minutes and discharge.
(c) Fill with the same amount of hot or cold water as before, add several pounds of a good washing compound, turn on steam until water is brought to a boil, allow to run for fifteen minutes and discharge.
(d) Again fill the machine to the same height, heating water as before and run for five minutes. Discharge and fill with cold water, run for five minutes and discharge.
(e) Draw hoops tight and machine is ready for operation.

MAINTENANCE

1.—To properly maintain the Globe Washer, the machine should be carefully inspected at least once every two weeks.

(a)—A level should be placed over the leveling lugs to determine if the machine is still in true alignment, as it frequently happens that a foundation will settle and in this way throw the machine out of line. If the machine is found to be out of level the alignment should be corrected in the same manner as when being installed.

(b)—All loose bolts and screws should be tightened.

(c)—All bearings should be properly lubricated. (See paragraph on Lubrication.)

2.—Belted Motor Driven Washer.—Before starting the washer inspect the oiling devices of the motor. Two oil reservoirs are provided, one near each end of the motor shaft. Be sure that the oil ring of the ring oiled motor bearings rides on the motor shaft, and that this ring turns when the motor is running. Use a good grade of medium motor oil, filling the oil reservoir to its proper level when motor is not running.

After the motor has been in operation for one week it is recommended that the drainage plugs located at the bottom of each motor bearing oil reservoir be removed and old oil drained off. Replace the drainage plugs, sealing them in place with red lead or shellac to prevent leakage and refill the reservoir with fresh oil. Keep the oil reservoirs well supplied with oil at all times.

Should the motor bearings become badly worn, replace them promptly to avoid damaging the rotor, armature or field coils of the motor.

Keep an extra set of motor bearings on hand.

Cylinder bearings, drive and intermediate shaft bearings and all other points on the washer should be lubricated as described in the following paragraphs.

Keep all bearings clean and well lubricated at all times.

3.—Motor Temperature.—The motor on the motor driven type performs, as regards to the temperature rise, in accordance with the fundamental physical law, viz.: When one form of energy is transferred into another, the resultants are first, motion; second, heat.

The motors applied to Globe Washers operate with safety at a temperature rise up to 40° Centigrade or 72° Fahrenheit. Therefore, if the heating limit is in question, measure the temperature rise before assuming that the motor is running at an excessive temperature. This may be obtained by the following method:

First —Use either a Fahrenheit or Centigrade thermometer.

Second —Read the temperature of the room.

Third —Place the bulb of thermometer on the laminations of the Alternating Current motor or the Commutator of the Direct Current motor and hold until the maximum temperature is reached.

Fourth —Subtract the two readings and the result is the temperature rise of motor.

Example—Motor Lamination or Commutator Temperature. 176°F = 80°C

Temperature of room 104°F = 40°C

Temperature rise of motor 72°F or 40°C

KEEPING AN EQUIPMENT RECORD—A SUGGESTION

One of the most important factors in the successful operation of any business is an accurate record of the equipment. In case of fire, such a record would give a complete and accurate inventory of the entire equipment and enable the laundryowner to obtain an equitable settlement of his insurance claims. Without it, the statement of equipment loss would only be an estimate and the loss would not be fully covered.

A record of this kind need not be expensive—a simple effective system can be installed at a negligible cost. The first step would be the assigning of an equipment number for each machine. This number should appear on the machine in the form of a metal tag or plate and be securely fastened to the machine. A standard 4 x 6" Card drawer with cards similar to the one illustrated on Plate No. 4, would be sufficient to take care of this system. Each card should carry the equipment number, name of machine, serial number of machine, original cost (which should include freight, drayage and labor incidental to its installation).

As repair parts are ordered for the machine, they should be charged against the machine under "Maintenance," and a full copy of the invoice, including the part number, should be entered on the card. The American Laundry Machinery Company's invoices always show part numbers which are extremely valuable to the laundryowner in that he can order repairs understandingly and in that way obtain prompt service.

One of the many advantages of keeping such records is that the cost of maintaining each piece of equipment may be ascertained at a glance.

As we all know, there is a point where the cost of repairs (including the time the machine is shut down awaiting such repairs) is such that it is more economical to discard the machine and replace it with a new one and this card will enable the laundryowner to tell quickly and accurately when this time arrives.

For the convenience of the laundryowner who feels that the number of machines in his plant does not warrant the starting of a card system, we are incorporating on this page a full size 4 x 6" card on which the person in charge of repairs can enter same and then the entire bulletin can be filed as a record. Machine shall be constructed with such characteristics and shall be equipped with such accessories as specified in our letter of proposal, to which this specification is attached, and as described below:

**CYLINDER** — Shall have heads, staves, and ribs of selected, long leaf white pine.

Staves and lifting ribs shall be rabbeded at heads. Staves shall be accurate to the heads by wooden dowels.

Heads shall be gained to receive the three lifting ribs.

The above shall be cut from stock as follows:

| Diameter of Cylinder | 30 | 36 | 40 |
|----------------------|----|----|----|
| Heads                | 2  | 3  | 3  |
| Staves               | 1½ | 1½ | 1½ |
| Lifting Ribs         | 3 by 3½ | 3 by 3½ | 3 by 3½ |
| Door Closing Ribs    | 3 by 3½ | 3 by 4 | 3 by 4 |

Lifting ribs shall be secured to each cylinder head by a galvanized iron through cylinder hoop, rib, and extending into recess in the head.

To assure tight fitting of the door, the door-closing rib at bottom end shall operate against a fitted with a stainless-steel angle; door-closing rib at top of door opening shall be fitted with a stainless-steel channel.

Door shall be wired well ribbed, made of brass and shall rest on cylinder the full length of hinge. Hinge buttress shall be of brass.

Door shall be fitted with heavy, wide lips and provided with suitable finger grips.

Cylinder shall be banded with wide, heavy stainless-steel hoops spaced evenly around the door. On doors 27 inches or longer, a hoop shall be fitted between the heads and shall encircle the cylinder completely, except at the door opening.

Door shall be 18 inches wide on 30-inch diameter; on 36 and 40-inch, shall be 12 inches wide.

Mechanics Metal trunnions shall be attached securely to cylinder heads.

**TUB** — Shall have heads and staves of clear or better fir. Staves shall be tongued, grooved, and rabbeded to fit over heads to which they shall be secured by wooden dowels.

Heads and staves shall be cut from clear or better stock, sizes of which follow:

| Diameter of Cylinder | 30 | 36 | 40 |
|----------------------|----|----|----|
| Heads                | 2  | 2  | 2  |
| Staves               | 1½ | 1½ | 1½ |
| Size of Stock        | 2  | 2  | 2  |

An upwardly sliding tub door, equipped with a supply door, shall operate in guides provided on adjustable, encircling hoops, fitted and taken back.

A water-level glass shall be suitably fitted into left end of tub to indicate the height of the liquid in the cylinder.

A short ladder type apron shall be provided at bottom of door opening to protect the leaves.

**FRAMES** — Shall be cast iron of one-piece, heavy construction, rigidly bolted to tub heads, and shall support weight of the entire weight of tub, and driving mechanism. Also see Belted Motor Drive.

**BEARINGS** — Journals of cylinder trunnions shall operate in solid-steel cast-iron bearings supported by the frame and equipped with easily-accessible lubricators.

**GEARS** — Shall be machine-cut from solid blanks and covered with a narrow, polished gear guard.

Cylinder drive gears shall be mounted at right end of machine only; except on 40-inch diameter with elevated header; double gearing shall be furnished, when so ordered.

On all machines, main gear shall be of solid-hub type; main gear shall be of solid-hub type; on all other sizes main gear shall be of split-hub type. All main gears shall be keyed to trunnion.

**WATER VALVE** — A 2-inch water pipe connection shall be provided at rear of tub; length over 30 inches shall have two inlets connected by a manifold.

**OUTLET VALVE** — Shall be the foot-operated, positive-close self-sealing type, 4 inches in diameter on the 30, 6 inches on the 36 and 40-inch diameter machines.

**GEAR LOCK** — A gear-lock, for locking cylinder in stationary position while the washer is being loaded or unloaded, shall be provided.

**INCHING DEVICE** — On 36 and 40-inch diameters, gear lock shall be combined with a handwheel on worm-gear shaft for bringing the cylinder door into alignment with the tub door.
Globe Washer—30, 36, 40-Inch Diameters—Belt and Belted Motor Drives

AUTOMATIC REVERSE-HEADER MECHANISM—Shall consist of three cylinders and a worm gear system to assure that the number of cylinder revolutions between reversals shall be uniform with but slight difference in either direction of rotation. Fulleys shall be of such widths as to carry belt of the widths shown below:

Belt-shifting mechanism shall be mounted on a heavy, cast-iron support arm, adjustable to belt at various speeds. Header mechanism shall be supported by a bracket arm bolted to cast-iron frames of the washer. Header shall embody strength, simplicity, and reliability.

BELTED MOTOR DRIVE

Machine shall be belt driven type, with end header, to which motor and transmission equipment shall be attached.

FRAMES—Two heavy iron uprights bolted to frames at each end of machine. Frames shall be equipped with overhead drive shaft; motor and starting device shall be attached to these uprights. A through tie bolt shall act as a stiffener for the two uprights.

ELECTRICAL EQUIPMENT—Shall conform to applicable sections of standards of the National Electrical Manufacturers' Association. All electrical units mounted on or within the machine shall be furnished insulated in accordance with the National Electrical Code.

MOTOR—The motor motor shall be ball-bearing, grease-lubricated type, of ample capacity to operate the washer under continuous operating conditions without the motor temperature rise exceeding the limits allowed by N.E.M.A.

CONTROLLER—A recording controller or controller in a sheet-metal enclosure with a removable cover shall be furnished mounted on the machine, for control of the drive motor. Needed operating controls shall be located on controller.

Where needed, controller shall incorporate protective resistance and relays.

WIRING—In conduit, shall be furnished connecting motor, operating switch, and controller, with provision at controller for service connections. Service disconnect switch shall be furnished by customer.

SPECIAL ITEMS (Furnished When Ordered)

GALVANIZED TRIM—Hinges and latches shall be galvanized iron.

HEAVY METAL COVERED RIBS—Standard wood ribs shall be encased in sheet brass or sheet Monel, as ordered.

SHEET METAL RIBS—Substitutes for standard wood ribs shall be sheet brass or sheet Monel, as ordered, hollow, with riveted joints.

BRASS TUB DOOR—Shall be upwardly sliding and be equipped with supply door.

DIAL WATER-LEVEL GAGE—Shall be a hydrostatic-type gage, located in a glass-covered compartment for observation. The gage shall be calibrated to indicate the height of water in the cylinder, in inches. The water-level gage glass shall be omitted.

OVERHEAD PIPING—Water inlet-connections, at the rear of the tub, shall be connected with galvanized piping, extending beyond the end and upward the height of the washer, branching into two separate inlet-connections for hot water and cold water. Inlet valves shall be mounted at the front of the machine, at convenient height.

AMERICAN QUICK-OPENING VALVES—Each water inlet-connection fitted with a quick-opening globe valve with renewable disks, so designed that only one complete turn of the handle will cause the valve to open the full 90 degrees.

HEUBSCH TUWAY, CHASE, FLOATLESS, DIAL, OR CHASE FLOAT VALVES—Shall be fitted to the hot and cold water inlet-piping and shall automatically close when the predetermined quantity of water has entered the cylinder.

HEUBSCH WASHOMETER—Shall be connected so as to cause at a predetermined time, the outlet valve to open and a bell to ring. Washometer shall consist of a stylus and tape to record washing cycle and operations of outlet valve.

STEAM VALVE AND PIPING—Boiler piping, extending beyond the end of the washer, shall be connected to the spray-head type steam inlet-connection at the bottom of the tub. Machine over 54-inch diameter shall have two inlets. The piping shall be fitted with a globe valve, the control for which shall be mounted at the front of the machine, at convenient height.

THERMOMETER—Shall be located in a position convenient for observation. The bulb shall extend below the washer and between the bottom of the cylinder and the tub, and be connected to the thermometer by a tube.

Safety Devices

END HEADER WASHER

Shall consist of a hook for holding cylinder doors open, tub door interlock, fully enclosed gear guard.

ELEVATED HEADER WASHER

Shall consist of a hook for holding cylinder door open, tub door interlock, covered drive shaft and fully enclosed gear guard.

BELTED MOTOR DRIVE

Shall consist of hooks for holding the cylinder doors open, tub door interlock, covered drive shaft, fully enclosed gear guard and fully enclosed belt guards.

I wish to bring to your attention that a letter was written from this office, our File No. 304-11 A.U., on the 4th instant in connection with the washing machine at the Round Lake Indian Residential School.

I am surprised that we have not heard from you by this time. I have a letter from Mr. Huston, the Principal, this morning, and by the tone of his letter he is about ready to throw up his hands and I do not blame him. You can imagine what it is to be short handed and have between children and staff somewhere in the neighborhood of 100 people, and all of the washing having to be done by hand. Also, Mr. Huston informs me last week the jacket heater at the school cracked. This heater heated the water for washing and bathing purposes, in fact it heated all of the hot water for the school. Mr. Huston drove about 200 miles to different towns trying to get the crack in the heater welded but was unsuccessful.

I can assure you the situation is bad when they have neither hot water at the school with the exception of what can be heated on the stove, nor a washing machine, causing everything to be done by hand, and as Mr. Huston will be coming to the city this coming week I telephoned some of the firms here. We can procure a heater and I would like to have authority for this.

I would also like to know what is going to be done about the washing machines. If you were to ask me I would get all of the children out of the school and then put dynamite under it because it has been nothing but a bill of expense from beginning to end. However, you are not asking my advice on the matter so I do not suppose it will be blown up.

M. Christianson,
General Superintendent of Indian Agencies.

This will acknowledge receipt of your letter of May 22, in which you express surprise that you have not received information with respect to the purchase or repair of the marginally noted washing machine.

The records here indicate that this matter was first brought to the attention of the Department in a letter dated Regina, May 4 and signed by John Reichman. This letter reached the Records office on May 7 and the Training Division on May 8. On May 10 we communicated with Mr. E. A. Guillaume, of the Canadian Laundry Machinery Company, Limited, Toronto, in an attempt to discover if machines of this type were available or if repairs to the machine now in operation could be undertaken. In order to avoid delay, however, a requisition for a new machine was sent forward to the Purchasing Agent. The Chief of the Training Division informed you, in a letter of May 21, that parts for this machine could be secured at a cost of $151.00. You will note, therefore, that despite the limited staff at our disposal here, this matter was handled promptly and certainly in a way that should not give rise to surprise on your part.

We are sorry to note that you have not indicated the size or the approximate cost of the new heater that may be required at this school. As your letter seems to indicate, however, that an emergency exists, you are authorized to secure a heater, if a heater of the type required is available.

Director.

Dear Sirs:

I wish to inform you that we have an Indian Boarding School down at Round Lake which is 17 miles north of Whitewood. The power washing machine there is an antiquated one that had been furnished a few years ago by some firm in Montreal and is beyond repair. We have a 7 h.p. gasoline engine which provides the power for the washing machine, and I would like to know what one of your washing machines that would be suitable would cost. Also, would the 7 h.p. engine be sufficient to run it in the event we purchased one of your machines.

Mr. Huston was in the office here the day before yesterday and advised me Mr. Webb had told him the matter of repairing the washing machine is absolutely hopeless and since Mr. Webb is a practical man and a good carpenter and mechanic I think we can pretty well take his advice.

Dear Mr. Christianson;

The Newly reconditioned washer has arrived from The Stanley Brock Limited, Winnipeg. It now rests well covered from the weather just outside the school Residence. We thought we would wait a rainy day before we would call the men from the hay for such a task as removing the old washer and installing the new.

Mr. Kerley was here to-day with the Auditor and we undertook to investigate the washer and to tell you truthfully it is not what one might expect for $525.00. The mechanical part of course is newly painted and its difficult to determine its condition until it is in operation for awhile. The wooden sections are constructed mainly of fir lumber with the addition of four or five pieces of hardwood. Mr. Webb of Broadview when called to give an estimate on costs about two months ago suggest Cyprus as the ideal lumber for the job but doubted if such could be procured under existing circumstance.

The workmanship with the lumber used had certainly not been the best. Indeed I would say it lacked what you would expect to find from the hand of an experienced and particular workman. The washer is smaller than our former one. Indeed I would say that one should be able to secure its like in the neighbourhood of two hundred and fifty dollars.

Now of course we have to place all this criticism over against the fact of war. We have to have a washer. The war is on. It is impossible to get a new one and what can we do about it. There seems to be no alternative. However I do feel that it would not hurt to bring all this to the notice of the company. They will soon be looking about for post-war business and I would say that unless they have a monopoly of the washer business that they are putting themselves in the way of losing business. You could consult Mr. Kerley as to his opinion and I will let the washer stand until I hear from you.

Yours sincerely,

Ltd., of Winnipeg, are attached for your information. Since the latter does not include installation costs, the quotation is of no value to us.

We are now in receipt of a reply from Mr. Gow dated the 14th instant, which reads in part as follows:

"One of our engineers will be visiting the hydroelectric stations in the lower Qu'Appelle Valley about the end of the month and as the Indian School is in the same vicinity he could readily visit the school without additional expense.

"I do not believe any member of this staff can qualify as a heating expert and any report we could make would have to be based upon opinions of the school engineer and a heating expert, such as Mr. Robertson of the Regina Plumbing and Heating Limited. This particular firm is a most reliable one and in view of the heating equipment situation today I am sure that Mr. Robertson would not suggest a new boiler unless in his opinion it was really needed.
