AIR MAIL

Regina, September 24, 1943.

Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, OTTAWA.

I wish to inform you that yesterday the Regina Plumbing and Heating Company telephoned to this office regarding the heating plant they are to install in the Round Lake School. This morning when I arrived here from the Crooked Lake Agency I called Mr. Robertson, Manager of the Regina Plumbing and Heating Company and he informed me he had been awarded the contract for installing the heating plant in the Round Lake School by the Purchasing Agent at Ottawa, Mr. Davidson. Upon receiving it Mr. Robertson had immediately got in touch with the Gurney North-West Foundry Company Limited, of Toronto and received a wire from them to the effect that they would not guarantee to deliver the heating plant required for the Round Lake School under five or six months' time. Therefore we would probably get the furnace on April 1st next.

Mr. Robertson is of the opinion that if our Branch got in touch with the Gurney Foundry Company in Toronto and explained to them how urgent this boiler is needed they might be able to do better than they have promised. Therefore if you think this feasible I would ask you to get in touch with these people because something has got to be done to protect the children at the School before the Winter sets in.

Would you kindly advise me as soon as possible.

M. Christianson,
General Superintendent of Indian Agencies.
Ottawa,
September 27, 1943.

Memorandum

Mr. R.A. Hoey

Replying to your memorandum of the 27th instant, (file 108-1-5), please be advised that Gurney Foundry Company Limited, Toronto, notified us this afternoon by long distance telephone that in view of our representations regarding the urgent need for a new sectional boiler at Round Lake School, delivery would be made by Nov. 1st, 1943, instead of April 1st, 1944, as previously promised. This promise of delivery was accepted as owing to current conditions and orders on hand for war work it is impossible for the firm to turn out the boiler any sooner.

I trust that in the meantime, the school authorities can arrange to carry on. If the old boiler or substitute heating device is not available, I would suggest that they consult with the Regina Plumbing & Heating Company, with a view to obtaining the loan of a small portable boiler.

With the present priority restrictions, scarcity of raw materials, (particularly metals) shortage of man power, and other wartime conditions, we are finding it increasingly difficult to obtain manufactured products promptly. It is therefore highly desirable that Indian Agents should, wherever possible, anticipate their requirements, so that orders can be placed in time to secure delivery of goods by the time they are actually needed. In the case of this boiler, the school authorities must have known its condition several months ago.

H.J. DAVIDSON

Dear Mr. Hoey:

Your letter of the thirteenth addressed to Stockholm received today. Our post-office address is now Whitewood, Sask. Only the odd folder now comes to Stockholm, consequently we go there very seldom. Whitewood is on the main line of the C.P.R., and unlike Stockholm it has a doctor and a bank. In the future will you please address all mail to us, Whitewood, Saskatchewan.

You will find enclosed copies of purchase order #5185. I regret you had to write concerning this. Early in July I developed sciatic pains which eventually confined me to bed. Several local doctors had a chance to give advice and after having accumulated enough drugs to set up a drug store I finally followed the instructions of a city surgeon and went to Winnipeg. I had to travel by train and ambulance. Under the skilled hands of two specialists I had a ruptured disc removed from my spine. All pain ceased and since then I have been progressing wonderfully in health. I do like to relate all this out of sheer gratitude for the restoration of my health but under present circumstances I tell it hoping it may prove a worthy alibi for my neglect in tending to the above matter.

During the time when I was in the hospital the school was inspected by a representative from your Department. I can never understand why these men come unannounced. It would have meant a great deal to me to have had the opportunity of talking with him. You see our schools are so isolated in some instances that we are out of touch with sources of inspiration and help. In my own case I welcome inspectors and regret that we have so few of them, but they may find by suddenly dropping in on a school is not half so important as what they could contribute by contacting the principal and staff, learning their aims and problems and giving them, in turn, to feel that there is after all a direct line of interest between the Department at Ottawa and the local work.

Mr. Butchart for example is your auditor and yet he is more than that. He affords us a very helpful social contact with your office. To be sure we appreciate his business like manner and we know that all your representatives must come for business reasons but we do feel that they all can if given the opportunity render another service equally as important.

Trust my letter may be interpreted in the kindly spirit in which it was written. I remain,

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

Extract from letter from Mr. J.P.B. OSTRANDER,
Inspector of Indian Agencies, Regina, Sask.,
dated October 22, 1945.

The only fire escape which had been in operation on the west side of the building, being that part of the building which is most likely to afford a means of escape from the dormitories, if there was a fire, had been eliminated by building at the foot of it an outer porch over the door to the boys' play room. I was annoyed when I saw this on my visit to the school on September 5th and drew Mr. Card's attention to it. He said he would have it moved to another window on the same side of the building where it would not have interference from the porch. The fire escape had not been moved when I again visited the school on October 10th.

The broken panes of glass at the time of my visit on September 5th ran into dozens. Every building on the premises had some broken windows and some of them had many. None of these had been repaired on October 10th, in fact I believe even more had been added to the number in a little over a month. The school grounds are receiving no attention whatever and there are tall weeds in front of the main school building which have been growing all summer, and were still there on October 10th.

All the buildings of the school needed painting but broken boards here and there and other damage resulting from carelessness and lack of discipline with the children have rendered the buildings unsightly and unfit for painting until considerable repair work has been done. The flooring of the boys' play room had dangerous holes in it and many boards of the flooring ready to break through at any moment. Mr. Kerley, the Agent, informed me that there has been flooring at the school for some months for repairs to these floors but nothing has been done to repair them. Some of the dormitory floors are practically worn through in spots, also, and much repair work is needed.
Ottawa, November 6, 1945.

With reference to the fire escape on the West side
of Round Lake School, I beg to report that up to date this
has not been erected. I sent the necessary piping from

to get 28 ft. in one length I had two lengths welded and
made a smooth joint. The Principal was notified, but the
pipe is still in Whitewood. His attitude appears to be
that this is all unnecessary. He stated that any fires
had always started on the other side of the building. I
pointed out to him that a fire might start anywhere and there
was no such thing as too many fire escapes in a building of
this kind. He also makes the excuse of not having enough
help at the school. He seemed reluctant to move the porch
and would prefer to extend a wooden platform along the side
of the building beyond the porch. I pointed out that this
would not be a safe arrangement as the platform should be
of metal construction and not too long.

As regards the 2800 ft. of flooring authorized on
Purchase Order 5422, being unable to purchase birch
flooring, edge grain fir was sent to the school on Nov. 28th,
and no attempt has been made as yet to lay this. Instead
of being put in the school it was stored in the loft of the
cow barn.

A saving of over $200.00 was effected by the
substitution of this flooring. Would it be possible to
get authority to hire men and see that the fire escape
is constructed and the flooring laid in the boys' playroom
and girls' dormitory.

(Over)
There appears to be a lack of co-operation on the part of the Principal, even after the Department has purchased the necessary materials for urgent and necessary work.

With reference to Department letter of the 6th ultimo, No. 108-1-5, addressed to Mr. W.J.D. Kerley, Indian Agent, Crooked Lake Agency, copy of which was sent to this office, in connection with the fire escape and the flooring in the boys' playroom in the Round Lake Indian Residential School, I am now enclosing copy of a letter received from Mr. Kerley referring to lack of co-operation on the part of the Principal of the school in carrying out this very necessary work.

I cannot understand the attitude of the Reverend Mr. Card, the Principal, in these matters. The floor in the boys' playroom is actually dangerous and might easily be the cause of a broken leg or some other injury while the boys are playing on the floor in its present condition. To store this flooring in the loft of the cow barn as soon as it was received instead of taking immediate steps to lay it would almost indicate that Mr. Card is not interested in the welfare of the pupils.

Much worse, in my opinion, is his failure to remedy the dangerous condition of the fire escapes. The building is an old frame building with poor heating arrangements and it would burn very quickly if a fire started. The only fire escapes in operation are in parts of the building where a fire is almost sure to start, making it very important to have a useful fire escape on the other side of the building. To have eliminated this fire escape, as I reported, subsequently taking no action to remedy the situation even after being supplied with good material, is inexcusable.

I think the Church Authorities should be informed, in no uncertain terms, that Mr. Card must comply with the Department's instructions where they relate to the health and welfare of the children, as well as the care of the buildings immediately. Failing this he should be replaced by someone willing to assume some responsibility to promptly complete repairs for improvements where the welfare of the children is concerned.

Dear Sir:

Re: Purchase order No. 6564—V 30 tank heater.

Shortly after my arrival at Round Lake School as Principal the former heater became so encrusted with alkali that the water would not circulate. We sought advice only to learn that it could not be cleared.

We took up the matter with Mr. Kerley, Indian Agent and Mr. Ostrander, Inspector of Indian Affairs only to be informed that, since our heater had lasted so short a time, viz., something over two years—the School would be responsible for the purchase of the new heater.

Shortly afterward I was in Regina and called at the Office. I discussed the matter further and offered to make payment out of our School funds if a heater could be located. Mr. Ostrander agreed to take the matter in hand with the result that a heater was shipped from Crane Limited, Regina and we made payment for same.

Our supply of water is pumped from the lake and is very high in alkali content. So much so, that the Company supplying water softening systems sent back a negative report when asked to supply a softening system.

The new heater is a size smaller and much lower in cost than the former but I believe that, with care it can be made to serve for a longer period.

Enclosed are two copies of Invoice, one of them being receipted. I trust that the Department may see fit to reimburse the School for this expense since we have further financial problems to present under separate cover.

Yours truly,

Dear Sirs:

May we bring to your attention the condition of the plumbing in our school here. This refers chiefly to toilets in the girls and boys wash rooms where 5 out of seven toilets are not in condition to use.

Now, I do not believe that this is due in any large measure to misuse or abuse although these Indian girls and boys are in some measure careless.

From what I have been able to glean concerning the work done last time it would seem that all the old equipment that had not been functioning satisfactorily was tinkered up and reinstalled.

At any rate I feel that we should have a qualified plumber come out here and get these toilets in good running order.

May we be granted permission and funds sufficient for this work as soon as possible?

Yours faithfully,

J. A. Card, Principal.
Reverend Sir:

With further reference to the matter of the account of Messrs. Steele & Lang, Limited, of Yorkton, for plumbing repairs at your school, and your letter of the 1st instant enclosing a letter from the company in question dated the 22nd ultimo, I am still unable to forward the account to Ottawa with my certificate.

In case you did not keep a copy of the letter from Messrs. Steele & Lang, I will quote therefrom:

"In regard to our labor or work charge of $114.10, we had 1 man @ $1.35 per hour for 38 hours and 9 hours overtime; 1 man @ $.70 per hour for 38 hours and 9 hours overtime which is by no means the maximum for this labor. I also charged 6 hours time for myself on my two trips there."

I am sure you will see that it is impossible to reconcile this information with the figure $114.10. I am not saying that the charge is incorrect but we have to account for all of it on the voucher and not just a part of it. In another part of the letter there is the following sentence: "It would take a matter of hours to give a description and catalogue number on each article but these are all standard fittings from the Crane catalogue, in most cases."

I am aware that you have not had much experience previously in submitting an account for payment by our Branch and I assume that Messrs. Steele & Lang have not had much experience of that nature. I should point out for your information and guidance that cheques in payment of accounts are not issued indiscriminately at Ottawa and all accounts paid are very completely analyzed at a later date. With this in mind I am not in a position to forward this account with my certificate in its present form as I have no means of checking. I would suggest that, as you incurred the indebtedness without proper authority, you pay it from school funds. Later, with the assistance of Mr. Kerley and the company concerned, you have an invoice prepared which will satisfy the Department. Have the invoice receipted then submit a voucher in favour of the school for refund of the amount paid.

Dear Sir:

When I wrote letter of August 25th, copy of which is enclosed, I had been here as Principal only a short time. It was my first experience in Indian work and there was no one to coach me or give me instruction in proper procedure when new equipment or major repairs were necessary. Hence I erred in the matter of the plumbing.

After I wrote on August 27th last year the situation became worse. Finally I contacted Steele & Lang Ltd. of Yorkton and asked them to examine our XXXXXX plumbing and list our needs. This was done and we were notified that they had a shipment of fixtures and repairs coming in soon and could take care of our needs. They requested our reply by return of mail in order that they could take care of our needs.

Rather face the winter with conditions in the building as they were I asked them to come right along.

The work was done in November and the account dated November 30th. This account reached Mr. Ostrander, Inspector of Indian Agencies but was not satisfactory and was returned for further details. Again it was sent to Mr. Ostrander and again returned. This time with the suggestion that we at Round Lake School pay the account with the possibility that the account may receive official approval at a later date.

This is impossible in our present state of finances. In the year 1945 this school received in Government grant the sum of $9806.37 as compared to $12,802.62 in 1944. It is true that the average attendance of pupils was lower but the difference was only 4 per cent whereas the Government grants for 1945 was some 22 percent less. The figures are tabulated on a separate sheet.

If you can direct me in regard to this account of Steele & Lang Limited in order that it might be certified by the Regina Office it will be greatly appreciated.

Yours truly,

Re: File No. 106-1-5 (W.T.I) Jan. 16, 1947.

Replying to the above mentioned letter, there were three window panes cracked, one of these was patched with a piece of glass 7" x 4" and there are storm windows on, I requested the Principal to obtain the glass and send the account to this office, it will cost about $3.50.

Under ordinary circumstances one coat of paint would put these rooms in good shape, but the paint there now is a cream ceiling and green walls with a brown wainscoating. To make a good job it would certainly require two coats of paint over the whole surface including the blackboards. The plaster that needs repairing is 40 square feet in different patches on the ceiling, this was caused several years ago when the roof was leaking. The steps in question are badly worn and the best way is to construct new ones.

Attached is a requisition for the decoration and necessary repairs, the quotation is from Messrs Webb & Melanson, of Broadview, Sask. They are willing to do the work a little later on when the roads are opened up again, (It can be done before the 31st of March). I might add that Webb & Melanson are Veterans and have been doing this kind of work on various schools in this district for the past year.

W. J. D. Kerley,
Indian Agent.

Ottawa, March 16,

Mr. J.F.B. Ostrander,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies,
Regina, Saskatchewan.

We have your letter of the 10th instant,
file 436-304-11 A.U. (108), enclosing requisition
for paint for the Round Lake School.

Owing to lack of funds it is not possible
to authorize any further expenditures at the present
time. We are prepared to order paint and have it
delivered to the school immediately after April 1st.

In your letter you do not mention any ex-
penditure for labour. Are we to understand that the
school management is supplying the labour without
cost to the Department? If not, what will the labour
cost?

Bernard F. Neary
Superintendent of Education

Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, OTTAWA,

I have to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 16th instant, File No. 108-1-5 (L.1), in connection with the requisition for interior painting at the Round Lake School.

The requisition referred to was sent in the hope that there might be funds available before the end of the current fiscal year. However, we shall be pleased to have the paint ordered after the 1st of April.

As to the labour in connection therewith, it is suggested that as it is all interior work, and the building is not very valuable, the labour can be performed by the boys of the school from time to time after the paint is supplied.

MAR 30 1948

A.M.

for J.P.B. Ostrander,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies,
Saskatchewan.
